mnemonics.meaning: First of all, there's a cross making up the middle, which automatically makes this a religion-based radical. That cross is the frame of someone's body and the things coming off of it are wings. This is an angel.

This looks like a tail with some hairs coming off of it. It shouldn't be confused with fingers though, because it's curved, and the things sticking out are more erratic, like hair or fur would be. That's why this radical is the animal radical.

There's a little speck of something on your plate (皿). "What is that?" you ask. Oh no... that speck is BLOOD!!! I hope it's blood from a nosebleed you suddenly have and not someone else's blood. (Your waiter is probably gonna get fired, btw.) At least your platelets should stop the bleeding soon. Haha, get it? PLATE-lets? Japanese blood jokes.

This radical looks like the fire from the burner of a stove or the steam coming up off of a pot of water. That's because this is the boil radical. You need to boil a bunch of water over some flames. This radical looks like all of those parts at once!
This box is open. There could be any number of things inside, but for now all you need to know is the meaning of this radical, which is box.
You already learned the kanji 市, which means city. We're treating it as a radical too, since it pops up in many other kanji. When used as a radical, it still means city.

There's a lid on a lion. And you're stuck under the lid with the lion, which means you will surely meet your death. Or if you don't want to die, think of the poor lion. If you leave a lion under a lid for too long, death will come for it too. Either way, somebody's gonna die today.
You put on your hat and go outside to kick something white. It's a big white goose and you killed it with your kick. That's because you're going to cook and eat it. Yum!

Someone has a toe in their mouth. They are a fortune teller telling your fortune. But for her to do it, she has to take one of your toes and taste it. This better be a good fortune for you to let someone put your foot in their mouth.

This is a tree with a slide cutting off the top. What do you cut off the top of trees and plants? The grains. Imagine taking a sickle and slicing the grains off rice or wheat. The plant you leave behind will look like this radical. It's a sign that you got a grain of some sort from it.

This is like one of those jets that have the little nose-wings going on too. Imagine you're looking at the jet from the top down, this is what it would look like. It's also why this is the jet radical.
This is a knife. See how it has two sharp sides? And there's a little handle at the bottom for the... well the handle. Be careful you don't cut yourself!

There's a person in a prison. Why is this person in prison? Because they lack the stuff humans need to be around other humans. If you're lacking something (kindness, self-control, etc.) you may do something that makes other people put you in prison. Try to fix what you lack so this won't happen to you.
There's a ladle scooping up two drops of liquid. See the handle and the scoop part of the ladle? Imagine ladling some water into your mouth. Mmm.

This L-shaped radical is the lion radical, because "L is for Lion." It also looks like a lion's mouth being opened really, really wide. Imagine a lion opening its mouth to yawn. It looks like this radical!

You have a modified key radical on top of the kick radical. You kick the key as far as you can, then measure the distance. How long did it travel? How long will it take you to find it? How long will you be in trouble for kicking a key into the woods?
This radical is just like the katakana character "ma" (マ). So let's keep things simple and make the radical mama.

There are some horns on the ground that you want for yourself. You pick them up and you attach them to your neck. Imagine these horns sticking out of your neck. No one can slit your throat now that your neck is protected.

This is a sheep and you're looking at it from above. See the two ears and the body of the sheep going back (with all its wool poking out to the side) and then the little tail sticking out the back. What a cute sheep!
Something is sticking out of a mouth. Something with a thousand little tastebuds on it. It's your tongue!

The evening radical is under the ground. Who's doing things underground at night? The Yakuza. Picture Yakuza members sneaking around in the subway, or in the sewers. They're definitely up to no good down there.

Kings with hats. Did you know that all kings wear hats? Think of as many kings as you can think of. Guess what, every single one of them (aka all of them) wear hats! Think of strange hats, funny hats, and normal hats. Just make sure you're amazed by the fact they all are wearing them.
mnemonics.reading: But, as you're going through all the kings, it turns out not all of them have hats after all. The last one you come to does not have a hat. He is the king of Zen (ぜん) Buddhism. He has simple clothes and a shaved head, unlike all the other fancy kings standing around nearby. To add to this story and make it more memorable, you can imagine the other kings getting upset, saying things like "All kings must wear hats! You are no king!" The king of Zen Buddhism just ignores them and begins to meditate.

mnemonics.meaning: If you loiter around to poop in winter you never know what could be happening behind you. After you're done you could turn back to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold. Imagine trying to loiter while you poop in the winter. You're just trying to take your time as you squat over the snow, but soon you hear things behind you.
mnemonics.reading: You finally look behind you and see Godzilla (ご) and a giant こういち having a violent battle back there! Godzilla and こういち were going at it behind you the entire time you were just lazily taking a poop in the snow?! Ahh, that's so embarrassing! And also dangerous, they could have crushed you! You should look behind you more.

mnemonics.meaning: The blood radical and blood are the same in looks as well as in meaning. There'll be some bad blood between us if you're not studying your radicals, especially when they're the same like this kanji!
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading けつ, we use the word "ketsup." The perfect mix of ketchup and catsup! The radical is technically blood, but you know that radical is just a drop (of blood) on a plate. So, you ask yourself... Is that really blood on the plate? Could it be? You decide to take a gamble and lick it off. When you taste it, it's definitely not blood. No, it's ketsup (けつ). Feel the relief that you didn't just lick up someone's blood. Taste the ketsup taste, too. It's pretty good. Not quite ketchup, but not quite catsup. Yum!

mnemonics.meaning: Under the ground, which you dug into, you found two great finds. You found both a mountain and a head, two strange things to find underground. You'll want to focus on the part where you find both, not so much the things themselves. Think about how you can't believe you did so well finding both things at once. Usually you only find one or the other when you're searching.
mnemonics.reading: But, you dig too deep and water flows into where you are. Your only hope is a row (りょう) boat floating off in the distance. Also think... "What's that row boat doing here?" But, it's your only hope, so you have to focus on it really hard.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun AND the moon are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly bright outside. Look up at both of them, hanging out in the sky together. Make them super bright, so bright you have to shield your eyes.
mnemonics.reading: When do things start to get bright outside? I'd say when things start getting sunny, and that is the month of May (めい). If you live in the Southern Hemisphere, it's bright in May because of all the snow, or because that's when all the streetlights come on. Depending on where you live, you might want to come up with a different reason for all that brightness in May. Perhaps it's because of Mother's Day, since we all know how brightly mothers shine. The important thing is to remember just how bright the month of May is, for whatever reason!

mnemonics.meaning: There is a lid covering all the mouths that are too small to feed themselves, forming the capital. All of the small mouths come together and create a place where everyone can support each other. Picture the capital of your country. How many mouths have come together to support each other there? A thousand? A million? More?!
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading きょう we use the Japanese city, Kyoto, which is spelled きょうと. It was once the capital of Japan! It was soooo full of mouths that came together that it was the capital for a long, long time. When you think of the capital, think of きょうと!

mnemonics.meaning: A leader with a spoon is a powerful thing. Even something like a spoon when given to the right man or woman can make great change in the world. Imagine your leader-hero holding a spoon out, then doing something awesome with it to totally change everything for the better. It's amazing the change this person can do with such a blunt, small, device!
mnemonics.reading: Then, this hero of yours takes their spoon and says some magic words into it, changing it into a car (か). Of course, doing something like this is utterly amazing. Feel amazed in your imagination, because if you don't, then it'll be hard to remember the reading for this kanji. If you are amazed, you'll know that spoons going to cars = the reading is か, so make sure you take the time to be amazed.

mnemonics.meaning: The mouth of the king extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his country, give or take a few drops. Imagine his talking taking physical form. As he talks, waves extend out from him, and stop right at the border of his country before getting to the next one.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out the king of this country loves drinking Coke (こく). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast. Would you drink that much soda for breakfast? Now this king says he wants to pass a law requiring everyone in the country to drink nothing but Coke! That's crazy!

mnemonics.meaning: You scoop some grains into a ladle to do science. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science course. Imagine carefully ladling grains into different piles so you can do science experiments on them. This course is going to make you an expert. You'll be the best in this department!
mnemonics.reading: Using your science skills, the right temperatures and measurements, you manage to get these grains to grow into a car (か). This is the science department's special car now! From your science meddling, these grains grow huge, red, and sprout sports cars when they're ripe. This is the true power of science!

mnemonics.meaning: If the yakuza hands you a spoon, death is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death. This spoon isn't for pudding, it's for death!
mnemonics.reading: Death comes in the form of a sheep (し). The death sheep works for the yakuza, and kills anyone who has their spoon. Picture the death sheep. He looks like a black shadow, and he has a scar on his face. He's holding a bunch of spoons, from all the other people the yakuza marked for death!

mnemonics.meaning: The radical death and the kanji death are the same. This thing is deceased. It ain't alive anymore.
mnemonics.reading: Your death will be because of a bowling (ぼう) accident. Oh, you didn't know? You're going to be hit by a giant bowling ball and crushed flat. You didn't want to know what would cause your death, you say? Well that's a shame. I guess you could try to avoid bowling from now on, but that won't do any good. Mark my words, your death will be bowling-related.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a close-up of a leaf in a rice paddy inside of a box. Wait, it's not a box, this whole thing is just a drawing. Look closely at this box-shaped drawing. See each little stroke, smell the paper and the lead.
mnemonics.reading: The drawing seems to have something else in the rice paddy, behind the leaf. You realize the drawing is actually of a gargoyle (が) and a cock (かく). You see the cock sitting on top of the gargoyle, crowing into the sky. Picture the entire drawing. There's a cock sitting on a gargoyle, watching over this rice paddy. It's actually quite beautiful and idyllic.

mnemonics.meaning: A dirt alligator lives in the earth, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary. You can think of this word as ground too, because that's kind of what earth is made of. Imagine seeing the earth moving as a dirt alligator rises out from the ground. You should run.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to keep this dirt alligator from dragging you under the earth and eating you is to feed it cheese (ち). That way it won't lead you to a horrific death under the earth by dragging you under and spinning you around until you eat dirt (literally). If you ever see someone throwing cheese on the ground, now you know why. They aren't crazy, they're saving us humans from what's lurking under the earth.

mnemonics.meaning: Behind that tree the sun is rising in the east. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too. Picture the sun behind the tree, don't picture the sun alone, you'll burn your eyes. It's slowly coming up behind it. Now think: where does the sun rise? In the east!
mnemonics.reading: You walk east for a few hours until you finally come to a city. It's とうきょう. Oh! とうきょう is in the east. I get it now! When you think about East Japan think about とうきょう. And if you're bad at geography, just look at a map for a while. Or, stand outside in the morning, watch the sun rise behind the trees, and point that way. That's east, it's where とうきょう is!

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for eat and the kanji for eat are the same! Lucky you. If you know the radical, you basically know the meaning(s) of this kanji. There is a second meaning added to it, though, and that is meal. Just think about the things you eat? What are they? In the simplest form, they are just meals. So, if you know "eat" you should be able to remember "meal" as well.
mnemonics.reading: Thank goodness, you finally get to eat your meal. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a shock (しょく) from somewhere. So, do you keep eating and keep getting shocked? Or do you not eat and continue to starve? What is worse? Obviously you're in one of the Saw movies, or something, too, so feel the fear. What will you choose? Life with shocks or death from hunger?

mnemonics.meaning: You accidentally stab your cross into the eye of a lion. This is a terrible thing you did and you need to fix it right now. I'll be direct with you, this is something you have to fix on your own. How will you fix this mistake though? Maybe if you build a time machine you can go back and stop yourself from throwing your cross around so carelessly. Whatever you do, focus on how important it is to fix the mistake, more than anything.
mnemonics.reading: As you try to fix the lion's eye, it starts to choke (ちょく) and make what can only be described as a jikijikijiki sound (じき). Through its choking jikijiki sounds, it coughs up a gear. Wait. Is this a machine lion? You're relieved! You don't know how to fix a choking, eye-stabbed lion, but you can absolutely fix a ROBOTIC one. Robots are fixable.

mnemonics.meaning: There are some horns on the ground and a moon knife in front of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason. This kanji means before too. Something that's in front of you is before you, after all. Perhaps it's some kind of magic, but you don't care. Why are these strange objects always in front of me? Why won't they stay put? This will get pretty freaky after a while. Try to run. Try to hide. Spin around. Do whatever you need to do. No matter what, these objects are always in front.
mnemonics.reading: You're going crazy with these things in front of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a Zen (ぜん) master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked! Go ahead and do some Zen Buddhist meditation. Maybe it'll help you to remember this kanji's reading better (and calm your mind so you're ready for the next kanji!).

mnemonics.meaning: A narwhal and a moon is all you have. Imagine one of each under your arms. You don't have anything else. This is it. All you have.
mnemonics.reading: Everything you have (except the narwhal and the moon) were taken from you by a roving gang of youths (ゆう). They came and took your things. Now they have all your stuff, and you only have the moon and a narwhal. You don't have much anymore, but at least you have these things still.

mnemonics.meaning: Your private grains are meant to stay private! You shouldn't be sharing them with the whole town, they're just for you. This kanji also means I. Why? Because what's more private than you? I mean, I! Basically, some things are only the business of you (I) and those things should be private. Look at your private grains. Who are those for? Why, they're for I!
mnemonics.reading: You're getting into the zone, thinking about yourself (I) and how much you love having things that are private and just yours, when you realize there is a sheep (し) in this grain bag. And it's eating all of your (I's) private grains. No! The moral of the story is: don't let a sheep sneak into your private stash of things just for you (I). I'm sure this is a metaphor for something important...

mnemonics.meaning: Just before saying something important, you take an arrow to the mouth which seals your lips together, making it so you can't talk. Someone doesn't want you to share what you know with someone else. Imagine being so surprised by this arrow. Then, think of all the things you know that need to be said and told to everyone. Maybe you have information about nuke codes. Maybe you have information that will save the President. Whatever it is, make sure you know important things that need to be said (but also things that people want to prevent you from saying, even if it means shooting you in the mouth with an arrow).
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading ち we use the word "cheese." One of the things you know is actually very strange but very important. The president's cheese (ち) has been poisoned and only you know. If you could just say something then maybe you could save her... but... you have an arrow in your mouth. Try saying the words "cheese" with an arrow in your mouth. What would that sound like? Go ahead and pretend out loud.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami of tongues is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... lively! Your entire body wakes up, you feel so lively! The tongues are making you more aware of yourself and your surroundings than you've ever been. You want to dance, you want to sing, you want to live your life.
mnemonics.reading: This lively feeling isn't just happening to you, the tongue tsunami is licking it into all of the cats (かつ) in your neighborhood too! You and the cats are running around playing together, because you can't seem to get the lively feelings to stop. You have to get the energy out, but the cats have sharp claws and they're scratching you.

mnemonics.meaning: The long radical and the long kanji are the same!  This kanji also means leader, because the longer a person is, the better a leader they'll be. Or maybe it was... the longer they've been somewhere? Whatever, longness = leaderness, you know? As long as you know the radical long, you know the kanji long as well.
mnemonics.reading: You see a very long person. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who has made herself long, like her street. "I made myself long so I can watch more of the street, my domain. I'm the leader of these streets. Watch yourself not-long person," says Mrs. Chou. Long isn't an idea that's easy to imagine in any specific sense, but you can try some other things too, as long as it gets associated with Mrs. Chou. For the most part, when you see a kanji with the radical 長 the reading will be ちょう.

mnemonics.meaning: Twenty mouths are together. That's a lot of mouths. What do they do? They sing beautiful music together. Listen to the twenty mouths. They sound great. Have them sing your favorite music. Also note that this kanji also means "bend." Imagine the music coming out at you bending all around in strange shapes through the air.
mnemonics.reading: The twenty mouths make so much music that they literally cloak you (きょく) with it. They cloak you with the music. Imagine how you feel as they cloak you with music. Feel the music all around you, enveloping you. Become the music itself.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical neck and the kanji neck are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: The only thing you do with your neck is use it to swallow lots of cool beans (くび). Mm mm. Feel those cool, cool beans sliding down your neck. You don't really taste them, but you know they're there. Look at yourself in a mirror as the cool beans make their way down your neck. You can see them, like little ants marching all the way down to your tummy.

mnemonics.meaning: You lack ice. So you go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next! Feel a little frustrated you can't find ice. Have the words "next next next" echoing through your head as you go from store to store, irritated.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading じ, we used the word "Jesus" - Finally, when you're at the last store in existence, you decide it's time to pray to Jesus (じ), asking for a miracle. He comes down from the heavens with ice in his hands. Imagine him coming down. Imagine your surprise. He hands you the ice, and it's cold. You thank him, and he flies away.

mnemonics.meaning: A leader is wearing a lid and is standing outside in winter. Plus it's raining and she's covered in drops of water. On top of all this, it's night. If it helps, you can come up with a reason why she's outside in the winter at night. Also, why is she wearing a lid on her head? Probably because she's protecting her people from something that comes at night.
mnemonics.reading: Question is, what is she protecting them from during the night? Turns out, it's the Yankees (や) baseball team. They're out for blood, and only the leader can protect us. Imagine the Yankees stomping towards the leader, baseball bats in hand, blood on their faces. They're here to eat, and nobody will stop them. Feel the fear of their approach. Will you survive another night with them on the prowl?

mnemonics.meaning: The only woman in this city is your older sister. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city. You want to go to the city someday, but you're not old enough yet, like your older sister is.
mnemonics.reading: Your older sister may have moved to the city, but she kept her pet sheep (し) with her. Now the only woman in the city is your older sister, and the only sheep is her pet. Picture your older sister and her sheep walking through the city. Everyone turns to stare at them, because they're the only ones of their kind.

mnemonics.meaning: Your fortune boils down to a single point in time. One point in time determines how the rest of your future will go. Imagine actually going somewhere to get your fortune told and watching a big boiling pot of goo. As it boils, it melts down to a single point at the very bottom. Where this point is determines your future.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the point, you watch in awe as it moves to the ten (てん) spot in a long series of numbers. Is the ten spot good? Are you going to live a long life or does this point mean you're only going to live ten more years?! Ahh!

mnemonics.meaning: With a roof over her head, a woman can relax. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a safe place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super cheap, so she can even relax about her finances. Picture the super relaxed woman lounging under her cheap but sturdy roof. Ah, she doesn't have a care in the world!
mnemonics.reading: As she relaxes, she pulls out the cheapest, most relaxing food in the world: anchovies (あん). Think about it: anchovies cost next to nothing, they come in cans, you don't have to cook them or cut them up. You just munch them down. There's nothing more cheap and relaxing than eating anchovies under your own roof.

mnemonics.meaning: On the dirt you've made a roof over the ground where you can be in private. This is your room! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself. Imagine the room you live in now. Take away all the stuff and you're left with a roof and the dirt on the ground. It's your own little private place.
mnemonics.reading: The only problem with your room is that you can't always be alone. Because of your dad's shih tzu (しつ). The shih tzu likes to come into your room and pee everywhere. Ruining your privacy completely. Imagine watching the little shih tzu come into your room and lift its leg to all your things. This isn't fair. The shih tzu has its own room to pee in. Why does it have to ruin yours?

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami is coming, so you point your gun out the window at it. "You better turn back, sea, or I'll shoot!" You'll have to think of the "sea" as its own entity, controlling the tsunami, otherwise you might confuse and combine the two. So when you point your gun out the window, aim it at the "sea," not the "tsunami." It's like aiming for the head of a zombie and not the arms or legs.
mnemonics.reading: The sea decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way. You hop in your kayak (かい) and chase after it with your gun, to make sure it actually returns to the sea and doesn't just drown someone else. Imagine paddling in your kayak, your gun still in one hand, as you chase the sea back to its home.

mnemonics.meaning: The sheep radical and the sheep kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning. You are no sheep—you study your radicals, unlike most Japanese learners. You'll learn sooo much faster!
mnemonics.reading: To remember よう, we use the word "Yogurt." The sheep are after you. There are too many of them, and they're chasing you down, stalking you... because you stole their sheep's milk yogurt (よう). Now you're running and crying and trying to eat the yogurt before the sheep catch up and stomp you down with their hooves. Imagine the taste of this yogurt. You're scared and tired from running, but it tastes great!

mnemonics.meaning: A long time ago, someone put up a canopy over their fortune telling booth and created the first shop. This store was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up! Picture the very first store in history. A fortune teller decided enough was enough, they should be in some kind of structure where it's safe, official looking, and more permanent.
mnemonics.reading: This shop quickly turned into ten (てん) shops! It was a good idea, after all, so all of the other people selling goods and services decided to copy it and create their own shops. The next day there were ten more. Picture ten shops, all made up of someone selling something under a canopy. The first one is the fortune teller, but the nine others are whatever you want them to be!

mnemonics.meaning: The cross you're holding above your head to keep your horns dry keeps pulling you south. Probably because it's warmer in the south of Japan, so it's easier to keep things dry. Look down and see the compass pointing south and feel the cross pulling you in that direction.
mnemonics.reading: You finally make it down south, and it is dry, but you're really hungry. When you try to find southern food you realize every single store is only selling naan (なん). Imagine being in the south and taking big bites of naan. It tastes good, but now your mouth is dry just like your horns. Too dry...

mnemonics.meaning: The sun that gives life is our very own star (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well. Imagine all sorts of stars all around the universe giving life to planets as suns. These are all the stars you see in the sky and there are billions of them. I hope you don't feel overwhelmed by how minuscule we really are when you look up at all of them.
mnemonics.reading: This star (the sun) and all of the others are yours to protect with your trusty saber (せい). If you could protect your land from the West, then you can certainly defend the stars too! Now you're soaring through between the stars, swinging your saber through the silence of space, and... wait. No that was a dream. You roll over and pat your saber. The two of you are ready just in case the stars need your help.

mnemonics.meaning: Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three drop drop drops in the large river that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's states or provinces. Also, another way to think of this is that the river radical is actually just three rivers, separating drops, which are capitals of various states. Rivers are usually great ways to divide up a country, and states are one way to do it!
mnemonics.reading: Each state has its own shoe (しゅう) to represent it. The bottom of each shoe is the shape of the state, so when you step it leaves a state-shaped imprint in the ground. The state shoes also have things like the state birds, state flowers, and state fish printed on each of them. They're quite collectable, you should buy a pair for your favorite state!

mnemonics.meaning: You come across an angel wearing a hat that's covered in flowers. So, you do the only natural thing. You take this angel, chop him up into tiny pieces, and dry him out. Then, you make tea out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat, though. How does this angel-flower tea taste? Be sure to imagine it. Probably heavenly *rimshot.*
mnemonics.reading: In your tea you find a little metal button. I guess you missed it while you turned the angel into tea. You look at the button - on the back it says "To Chad, you'll make an awesome angel." Looks like you're drinking Chad the Angel. It gets kind of weird when you know their names... Usually you just make them into tea without knowing who they are (easier that way). This one... this one is Chad, and you remember it vividly, because now you feel kind of bad.

mnemonics.meaning: In a rice paddy you find a heart and it makes you think. You think a lot of thoughts like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?" Think, think, think. Think about this rice paddy heart.
mnemonics.reading: As you are thinking these thoughts, you spot someone on the edge of the rice field. He really reminds you of someone. But who? That's it! He reminds you of that bartender on The Simpsons. What's his name? You think some more. What is it? Oh! Moe (おも) is his name! If you don't know Moe from the Simpsons use a different Moe, perhaps the one from the Three Stooges? You should be able to come up with one. Think really hard about the Moe you know best and imagine them standing watching you from the edge of the rice field.

mnemonics.meaning: You stop at a small slide. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were walking. Question is, what made you stop? Imagine yourself walking at a nice casual pace... then imagine something that would make you stop that's incredibly interesting and strange. Maybe an alien is going down the slide? He would say "keep walking, friend."
mnemonics.reading: So, you're walking around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a hoe (ほ) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you. Of course, imagine the pain of your face. Did your nose break? After bringing yourself together, look down at what hit you. It's a hoe! How did you manage to step on just the right spot to flip it up on you like that? Examine the hoe. Pay close attention to it. Whose hoe is this? etc.

mnemonics.meaning: A drop hits your mustache. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from yonder," you say, facing that way. Yonder is a bit of a weird word, but it fits the meaning of this kanji quite well. You'll have to trust me that it's more useful in Japanese than it is in English. When you imagine through this mnemonic, make sure the drop comes from the side and hits you in the mustache with quite a bit of force. That means it came from a far distance thus making you look over "yonder."
mnemonics.reading: Who shot this drop at you from yonder? You look over yonder, and see a figure. It is こういち. "Who is that over yonder!" you yell. "It is I, (こういち)," he yells back. "I shot at you over yonder because you weren't doing your kanji reviews often enough and you're taking up space on our database." "But I'm paying you!" "Oh, that's true. Well, I'm going to walk over yonder and leave you alone, then."

mnemonics.meaning: Who's that woman pretending to be a jet? That's my younger sister. *Sigh* Imagine a little girl (your younger sister) running around with her arms out, pretending to be a jet, too. Prwoooooo!
mnemonics.reading: Your younger sister is giving some mice (まい) a ride on her back like a jet.  Ew, gross. Your younger sister is such a weirdo! Why does she have mice on her back while pretending to be a jet?

mnemonics.meaning: This shares one of the meanings you learned for the kanji: after. You can differentiate this one from 後ろ (which you may or may not have seen yet) thanks to the で on the end. Some people believe that after something's dead (で), it goes to an afterlife.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  After. Everything happens after. It's a cause and effect chain. One thing happens, and then another thing happens after. This is life. This is the universe. Everything is after. It's an automatic (あと) cycle that just keeps going and going and going.

sentences: 後でいっしょにお茶でもしませんか。
Why don’t we have some tea together later?
後で、「言わんこっちゃない」って言わせないでよ。
Don't make me say, "I told you so," later.
その映画を見終わった後で、もう一度それを見るために違う映画館へ向かった。
After the movie, we headed across town to watch it again in another theater.

mnemonics.meaning: This has a little hiragana attached to it but nothing that suggests it's a verb or an adjective. That means you can assume this word has the same meaning as its parent kanji.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the すべ part, which is an admittedly difficult sound to remember. You have to think of the concept of all or entire. When you think of that concept, think of someone's entire fortune. All their money. You want to get all of Beth's money, so you sue Beth (すべ) for all she has.

sentences: 全てうまく行きました。
Everything went smoothly.
申しわけございませんが、げんざい全てのおせきがうまっているじょうきょうでして...。
I am sorry, but all the seats are fully occupied at the moment, so...
僕が先だよ。ウィキペディアが僕の宿題を全て真似したんだ。
I was the first to do it. Wikipedia copied my entire homework assignment afterwards.

mnemonics.meaning: You know 日本 means "Japan." So, now you have the kanji for all added to it, making this word All Japan (as in "All Japan Railways" or something like that).
mnemonics.reading: You know the reading of 日本. Now just add the on'yomi reading of 全 and you should be able to read this word.

sentences: これは、全日本バレーボール大会のしあいの写しんです。
This is a picture of a Japanese National Volleyball tournament match.
コウイチは、けん道の全日本せん手けんのしあいを見るために、日本に行っています。
Koichi is in Japan to watch the All Japan Kendo Championships.
全日本が生クリームに包まれている。
All of Japan is covered in whipped cream.

mnemonics.meaning: You have something that's before (or in front of) noon. What is before noon? That is AM.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このデパートは、午前十じにひらきます。
This department store opens at 10:00 am.
わたしのむす子は、まだ午前中にあさねをするひつようがあります。
My son still needs to take a nap in the morning.
今日は午前9時にテレパシーで投稿する予定にしているので、もし君がその時何か面白いことを考えたら、それは私の仕業だから。
I’ll be posting telepathically at 9AM today, so if you think of something funny, that was me.

mnemonics.meaning: What is the neck of your leg? Think about it. It's your ankle.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know the kun'yomi reading of 足 from previous vocab and you know the kun'yomi reading of 首 from learning that kanji. So, you should be able to read this kanji so long as you remember that it's all kun'yomi.

sentences: 足首をひねってしまいました。
I twisted my ankle.
右の足首がすごくいたいんです！
My right ankle hurts a lot.
宙に舞う羽から逃げる途中で、足首を捻挫した。
I sprained my ankle while running away from a feather floating in the air.

mnemonics.meaning: The year that is next is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is annual?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今年の年次けいかくを立てましょう。
Let’s decide on this year’s annual project.
マリ子は年次有きゅう休か、何日もらえるの？
How much annual paid leave do you get, Mariko?
生徒たちの日本語がどれだけ上達したかに関する年次報告書を作成する。
We write an annual report on how much our Japanese language students are improving.

mnemonics.meaning: The hiragana attached to this word doesn't suggest it's a verb or an adjective, so we can assume it's a noun. While 後で (you may or may not have seen this word yet) means "after," this one means all the other meanings you learned with the kanji: behind, back, and rear. Think of the ろ as a hint. It's like saying you're on the "road" (ろ) and you're driving so fast you're leaving everything "behind."
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Continue to think you're driving on this road. You hit something, then look behind you, seeing you hit a cow. Know the word for cow in Japanese? It's うし, which is also the reading for this word.

sentences: あなたの後ろのドアをしめてください。
Please close the door behind you.
チャイルドシートは、かならず後ろのざせきにせっちしてください。
You must install the child carseat on the rear seat of the car.
振り返って後ろを見た後、さらにもう一度振り返ったら、僕のことが見えるよ。
If you turn around to look behind you and then do it again, you’ll see me.

mnemonics.meaning: When the thing that is exiting is blood, you are probably bleeding.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.  Note that the しゅつ from 出 gets shortened to しゅっ. That's a small つ there, not a big one.

sentences: なかなか出血が止まりません。
The bleeding won’t stop.
トーフグはぜっさん出血大サービス中です。
Tofugu is providing you with a huge discount!
指を抜いていれば、鼻からの出血は止まると思います。
I think my nose would stop bleeding if I kept my finger out of it.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You cut yourself and there's blood everywhere. You need to stop the bleeding with something, but the only thing nearby is a block of cheese. You grab the cheese and stuff it into your gash, but the blood comes out the holes (it is Swiss cheese, blargh!). Imagine this in great detail to be able to remember it well.

sentences: シャツに血がついていますよ。
There is blood on your shirt.
うんちをするときにおしりから血が出るのはなぜなんだ！
Why does my bum bleed when I poop?
血が滴るぐらいのステーキが好きです。
I like steak when it still has lots of blood in it.

mnemonics.meaning: Here you have both directions / ways. Every time you have to choose between something it's like having to choose between two ways. That's why this word is simply both.  Close to the kanji is the meaning both sides, as well. Learn either for 両方, they're pretty similar.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 姉も妹も、両方とも大さかにすんでいます。
My older and younger sisters both live in Osaka.
じかんはあるんだから、両方やってみたら？
You've got time, so why don't you try it both ways?
ダメだよ！両方とも僕のだよ。
Nope. They’re both mine.

mnemonics.meaning: Kanji doesn't go together much better than this. Both plus day equals both days. This is a bit of a formal word though, you'll hear important people say it more than your friends.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 日 uses the reading じつ for this one instead of にち.

sentences: 両日とも、会ぎが入っています。
I’ll be in a meeting both days.
とうふまつりは、両日ともせい天にめぐまれた。
The tofu festival had good weather for both days.
iPadの使い方についての講義に両日とも参加したが、まだ使い方が分からない。
I attended the iPad lecture session on both days, but I still have no clue how to use it.

mnemonics.meaning: Don't use one hand when you can use both hands. This is simply both plus hand put together. It can also mean both arms.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with both kanji. No problemo for a kanji master such as yourself.

sentences: 両手を上げて、バンザイをしました。
They raised both hands and shouted banzai.
女の子は両手を広げてストレッチをした。
The girl spread her arms and stretched.
バランスの良い食事とは、両手にチョコレートクッキーを持つことです。
A balanced diet is a chocolate cookie in both hands.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji plus the hiragana るい. Words that end in い are usually adjectives, and this is no exception. What's the adjective form of bright? It's also bright.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the あか portion. What is あか in Japanese? It is "red." So, think of something that's really bright. Now, imagine it being totally red (aka あか). In Japan, the color red is associated with the sun, and the sun is pretty bright. If you can remember this you can also remember the reading of this word.

sentences: このへやは明るい。
This room is bright.
トーフグのみんなは明るい。
Everyone at Tofugu is cheerful.
未来はまだまだ明るいよ、おじいちゃん。
Your future is still bright, Grandpa.

mnemonics.meaning: What is the color of tea? You'd think it would be green, assuming it's Japanese... but this word came from China. What color is Chinese tea? It tends to be more brown. Think Oolong tea, for example.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.

sentences: ★に入るばんごうを、茶色にぬります。
Please color the number that best matches the ★ with brown.
明るい茶色にカラーリングしてください。
I'd like to dye my hair light brown, please.
私の白いTシャツ全ての脇のところに、茶色のシミがある。
All of my white t-shirts have brown armpit stains on them.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji part of this word is like saying "the doing way" ... aka the way you do something. So, when you don't have a way to do something, there's nothing you can do. Thus is born the popular Japanese phrase: 仕方がない, which means can't be helped, it's no use, or there's no other way. This is a very good expression to know if you're in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for the kanji portion are in line with the readings you learned with the individual kanji, so as long as you know those you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: かれがおこるのは、仕方がないよ。
If he’s angry, it can’t be helped.
泣いてばかりいても仕方がないよ。
There's no use in just crying.
お前は本当に仕方がないやつだ！
You’re really hopeless!

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cheap? It's also cheap. Time to go to a 100円 shop and get some 安い goods, ammiright?
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  "Would you like this item for cheap?"  "Uh, yes (やす) please!"

sentences: そして、でん車は安い方がいいです。
Also, the cheap train is better.
タイのぶっかはアメリカよりも安いです。
Prices in Thailand are cheaper than America.
アパートの屋根から投げて粉々になるのを見てみたかったので、昨日すごく安いラジオを買った。
I bought a very cheap radio yesterday just so I could throw it off the roof of my apartment and watch it shatter.

mnemonics.meaning: The middle country... who could that be? Let's think about it. Who invented kanji and therefore probably thinks they're the middle of the world? Who also is just a huge country that ruled much of Asia? That would be none other than China.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: 来月は、出ちょうで中国に行きます。
Next month I’m traveling to China on business.
冬休みに、中国でりゅう星ぐんを見ました。
During winter break, I watched the meteor shower in China.
どうして日本人は中国を支那と呼ぶことをやめて中国と呼び始めたんだろう。
Why did Japanese people stop calling China "Shina" and start calling it "Chuugoku?"

mnemonics.meaning: The company leader is the company president, manager, or director. Be sure to greet your 社長 with a hearty good morning when s/he stumbles in!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 社長は会ぎ中です。
The company president is in a meeting.
あの人気サービスのねだんを下げるなんて、トーフグの社長はどうかしてるよ。
The president of Tofugu is insane to lower the price of that popular service.
全社員は社長のことを嫌っているが、私は単に彼は少し意地悪なだけだと思っている。
All my coworkers hate my boss, but I just think he’s a little mean.

mnemonics.meaning: What do you use to show that a word is lively? Conjugation! Lively things are happening, so you have to conjugate your words to match.  It also has another meaning. When you want to actually use something lively you are making practical use of it. I mean, you're using it, after all. So as long as you aren't pretending to use it, it's probably practical.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は、どうしの活用をべんきょうします。
Today we will learn verb conjugation.
ちょこっとあいたじかんを活用して、ワニカニで日本ごをべんきょうします。
I make use of small pockets of time and study Japanese on WaniKani.
このデータをうまく活用して、何かできないかな。
I don’t know if I can put this data to good use.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  Tell me about your country. Now imagine that everyone in your country has cool knees (くに). That's because the national dress code is shorts, so everyone's knees get chilly. That why they have cool knees. You could also imagine cool knees in the sense of trendy knees. What makes for cool knees, in your opinion?

sentences: お国はどちらですか。
Which country are you from?
この国は安全だと思っていたのに、がっかりです。
I thought this country was safe, but now I'm disappointed.
私の国には、猫が焼くアップルパイのお店がある。
In my country, there is a shop that sells apple pies made by a cat.

mnemonics.meaning: Writing has changed our entire culture. In fact, when someone reads a good piece of writing it changes them, and changes their culture too. What writing has changed you so much it has changed your culture and the way you act?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本の文化にきょうみがあります。
I’m interested in Japanese culture.
この国の文化にはなれましたか？
Have you adapted to the culture of this country yet?
コスプレは日本の文化の一つですか？
Is cosplaying part of Japanese culture?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji for death and body put together make for a dead body. Hopefully you don't have to use or see this vocab too much.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: だれが死体を見つけましたか。
Who found the dead body?
だれが死体いきのようぎでたいほされたって？
Who did you say was arrested for abandoning a corpse?
私が初めて死体を見たのは、六歳の時です。
The first time I saw a dead body was when I was six years old.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: その死は早すぎました。
Their death was too soon.
人は死をのがれることはできない…コウイチい外は。
People cannot escape death, except for Koichi.
愛犬の死に打ちひしがれています。
I’m stricken with grief over the death of my pet dog.

mnemonics.meaning: The way you say things could be translated as your accent... but this is much bigger. This is an entire "way" of speaking. This is a dialect.  You can even think of the 方 as being "direction" where you go in different directions in a country and discover different dialects, if that way of thinking helps.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 方言のじしょを作っています。
I’m making a dialect dictionary.
ああっもうっ！かれしの方言がうつっちゃってるずら。
Damn! My boyfriend's dialect has rubbed off on me.
私の国の東側出身の人達は変わった方言で喋るので、彼らが何を言っているのか全く分かりません。
People from the eastern part of my country use such an odd dialect that they are impossible to understand.

mnemonics.meaning: The direction yonder over there is still just the direction of something, though a complicated way to say it, I think. This direction is the "what direction did he go in?" sort of direction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: わたしは、方向が分からなくなりました。
I lost my bearings.
めっちゃ方向音ちなんですよ。
I'm super terrible with directions!
こっちの方向であってるの？チャッキー・チーズは反対方向だと思ってたんだけど。
Are we going in the right direction? I thought Chuck E. Cheese was the other way.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the adverb version of the kanji early. It's a little thing you can begin sentences with to say you're doing something early or quickly.
mnemonics.reading: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 早い, you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: きのうはどうして早く学校に行きましたか。
Why did you go to school early yesterday?
ゆっくり休んで早くよくなってください。
Please get plenty of rest and feel better soon!
早く食べなさい。
Eat quickly.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Although this is a single kanji all alone, it uses the on'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

sentences: 一まいのはっぱが、ひらりと地におちた。
One leaf fell lightly to the ground.
コウイチはむかしはおおものだったけど、イノシシとのたたかいにまけてから、ひょうばんが地におちたよね。
Koichi used to be a big shot, but his reputation hit rock bottom after he lost a battle against a wild boar.
しかし、コウイチ氏は意外と地に足をしっかりつけ続けています。
And yet, Koichi himself remains charmingly down-to-earth.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You see a man walking east, toward the sun rising behind that tree, but it's too bright. He trips and he gashes (ひがし) his foot on a root that was sticking out of the ground. His foot is torn up really bad, but he tries to take another step and, oh no, he gashes his foot again! This guy is not having an easy time going east.

sentences: えきの東がわにあるきっ茶店で会いましょう。
Let’s meet in the cafe that's on the east side of the station.
どっちの方角が東？
Which direction is east?
空港の東側に住んでいます。
I live on the east side of the airport.

mnemonics.meaning: The East direction is Eastward.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 東方の空が明るくなりだした。
The eastern sky grew bright.
あの外国人は、大さかえきの東方やく五キロのところに住んでいる。
That foreigner lives about five kilometers east of Osaka Station.
日本はイギリスの東方にある。
Japan is to the east of Great Britain.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have lively energy you have more than enough energy for everyone to start noticing. They come up to you and compliment you on your amazing liveliness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful because かつ is being shortened here to かっ. It's a pretty common change for on'yomi ending in つ, so keep your eyes open for more that do this!

sentences: この町は、とても活気があります。
This city is very lively.
ニッカはいつも活気にあふれている。
Nikka is always full of energy.
市場は活気にあふれていた。
The market was overflowing with energy.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have a name (that is known to people) or you have famousness, you are probably someone who is famous.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: いえの近くに、有名なすしやがあります。
There is a famous sushi restaurant near my house.
このきじはトーフグを一やくちょう有名にした。
This article suddenly made Tofugu super popular.
俺は有名だけど、お前はどうよ？
I’m famous, are you?

mnemonics.meaning: Famous music that you know the name of is famous music.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: クリスマスソングの名曲といえば、何だと思いますか。
Speaking of famous Christmas songs, what do you think?
この曲は名曲だと言われているけど、わたしには他の曲と大してかわりない。
This is known for being an excellent piece of music, but to me it's just like all the others.
ベートーベンの「スモークサーモン」は名曲だ。
Beethoven’s "Smoked Salmon" is a masterpiece.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have a fast mouth, you're probably a fast talker, right motormouth?
mnemonics.reading: Remember how body parts often change even jukugo words to kun'yomi readings? That's what happened here too. Both readings are kun'yomi, making this one はやくち.

sentences: わたしの兄は、とても早口です。
My older brother is a really fast talker.
お前のことが一ばん大すきだよって、何でそんなに早口で言ったの？
Why did you say that you love me the most so quickly?
こんなに早口の赤ん坊なんて見たことないよ。
I’ve never seen such a fast talking baby before.

mnemonics.meaning: An outside country is one outside of your own country. That is a foreign country, other countries, or overseas.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしたちはまだ外国に行ったことがありません。
We haven’t gone to other countries yet.
外国へでんわをするのはこれがはじめてです。
This is my first time making an overseas call.
もし外国にいるなら、有名人になっても構わない。
I wouldn’t mind being a celebrity if I was in a foreign country.

mnemonics.meaning: You know 外人 the word that means "foreigner," but that word is a bit informal and can come off as rude. The nicer, more politically correct version of the word is the one above. An outside country person. To differentiate this from "foreigner" we're going to use the more polite English version of this word as well (just like in Japanese): Foreign Person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今日、外国人の友だちと、かいものに行きました。
Today, I went shopping with my foreign friends.
その外国人の目は血走っていた。
That foreigner's eyes were bloodshot.
いいえ、私は人種差別主義者ではありません。世界中の全ての外国人に会って、それぞれ個人的に嫌いになっただけです。
No, I’m not racist. I’ve met every kind of foreign person on the planet and I just hate each of them equally.

mnemonics.meaning: Four tens plus two. That equals forty two.  P.S. Please don't panic. "The Answer" is NOT a correct answer for this. It is just a reference to the greatest book of all time. Sorry for the confusion and so long and thanks for all the fish.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But! Don't forget, 四 uses the kun'yomi reading, since the on'yomi reading sounds too much like the word for "death."

sentences: とうなんアジアを、四十二日かんりょこうしました。
I took a forty-two day trip around Southeast Asia.
フランス人グルメは五月だけでさらうどんを四十二さらたべた。
The French gourmet had 42 plates of Sara udon in May only.
そぼがトイレットペーパーを四十二ロールもかってきた。
My grandma bought forty-two rolls of toilet paper.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  What's in front of you? Think about it. Make it something ridiculous. Now look at a tag that's on it. Who does this thing belong to? Oh, wait, it's my (まえ) thing there in front of me. Say that out loud for better memory.

sentences: 前は花やで、花やのとなりはさかなやです。
In front is a flower shop and next door to it is a fish shop.
毎あさ、会社に行く前に、スクワットを五百回します。
Every morning I do 500 squats before leaving for work.
赤信号の前にいる時、「もうすぐ青に変わるぞ！」と思うとかなり興奮する。
When I’m in front of a red light, I get very excited at the thought of it turning green soon.

mnemonics.meaning: When you put all your power into something, you're putting your full effort into it. Hopefully that's what you put into your kanji learning as well!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: えきまで、全力で走りました。
I ran with all my might to the station.
その中国人の女は、王子が自分とけっこんしてくれるよう全力でせっとくしたが、しっぱいにおわった。
That Chinese woman tried her best to persuade the prince to marry her, but she failed.
そのゾンビは、死から蘇ろうと全力を尽くしていた。
That zombie is using up all its strength trying to come back from the dead.

mnemonics.meaning: If you exit somewhere in order to go to your company, that's going to the office, arriving at the office, and coming to work.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for  the しゅつ, which gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.

sentences: 今日は、八時に出社しました。
Today I arrived at the office at 8 o'clock.
出社前って、どんな風にすごしてますか？
How do you spend your time before going to work?
もう出社しているはずなのに。
They should be at work by now, though.

mnemonics.meaning: You have correct and fix. When you're always fixing things to make them correct (for example, someone's lies!) you are a very honest person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 川田さんは、とても正直な人です。
Kawata is a very honest person.
かれの正直なところがすきなんです。
I like his honesty.
僕は水中で息をしている火星からきた王子だし、他の人の模範となる必要があるので、いつも正直でいようと心がけています。
I try to be honest all the time because I’m an underwater-breathing Martian prince and I need to set an example for people.

mnemonics.meaning: You have your origin state. For Japan (since this is a Japanese word), that would be the main island, the big one in the middle: Honshu. You'll have to know some minor Japanese geography for this. Go look at a map of Japan and study it over real quick to see where I'm talking about if you don't know already.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この後、本州に行くつもりです。
After this I plan on going to Honshu.
本州とは、いったいぜんたい日本のどこにあるんですか？
Where the heck in Japan is Honshu?
本州がどこか分からなければ、パソコンでしらべたらどうですか？
If you don't know where Honshu is, why don't you look it up on your computer?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: If you're lucky, you already know this (very) common word's reading. It's the word for "I," probably one of the first things you'd learn in Japanese. The reading for this is わたし. If you don't know that already, just think: "What, a し?" referring to the reading of the kanji, which is し.

sentences: メーリングリストから私を外してください。
Please remove me from your email list.
私がえいぎょう部のせきにん者です。
I'm the director of the sales division.
昨日の夜、バーデビューしちゃった。私もちょっとずつ大人の階段登ってるって感じ？
I went to a bar for the first time last night. I feel like I’m slowly becoming an adult.

mnemonics.meaning: A country king is still a king, just of a bigger area.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの国王は、とてもよくばりです。
That king is very greedy.
わたしは、国王のことをじょじょにりかいしてきました。
I'm starting to understand the king.
18歳という若さで国王になった。
I became the king as a youth of 18.

mnemonics.meaning: This is heaven country. Where is that? Probably just in heaven (or if you want to be fancy, the kingdom of heaven).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 国 is changed to the reading ごく, though because of rendaku. Even heaven changes a little bit.

sentences: ポチはきっと天国にいるんだよ。
Poochie is definitely in heaven.
天国がこんなとこだったなんて、本当にがっかりです。
I am so disappointed to learn the Kingdom of Heaven is that kind of place.
タバコを天国で吸いましょう。
Let’s smoke cigarettes in Heaven.

mnemonics.meaning: The nine states. This refers to a section of Japan from a long time ago that was presumably made up of nine states. Now it's just one big island, though, and that island is Kyuushuu. Go take a look at a map and find this giant island, it's a cool part of Japan!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 九州のりょうりはおいしいです。
Kyushu cuisine is delicious.
九州までは、フェリーでかた道一じかんです。
It takes an hour to get to Kyushu by ferry.
九州には、綺麗な女性が多い。
There are many beautiful women in Kyushu.

mnemonics.meaning: The soil of the earth is the portion of the earth that is made up of land.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the on'yomi reading, but 土 gets modified to と for some reason. Just remember that the land you're standing on is made of toes... millions of them. Yuck.

sentences: ここは、あなたの土地ではありません。
This isn’t your land.
コウイチはマインクラフトに広大な土地をもっている。
Koichi owns a vast tract of land in Minecraft.
もし自分の土地があれば、ようやくそこに自分のベッドルームを手に入れることができるぜ！
If I had some land of my own, I’d finally get my own bedroom.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have life and are lively that right there is true life. What is your 生活 like? Do you live?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: アメリカと日本の生活のちがいをおしえてください。
Please tell me the difference between American and Japanese life?
あなたとの生活をもう一どやり直したいんです。
I want to get back together and live with you again.
毎日の生活でアニメを見ながらマシュマロを食べることができたら、とても幸せです。
I would be very happy if I could watch cartoons and eat marshmallows every day of my life.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of long? It's also long.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have something that's really long. It's this crazy hair growing out of the tip of your nose. You don't really care either way if it stays or goes, but you're too lazy to cut it off. Your parents, though, keep trying to nag (なが) you to trim it. Imagine this process happening and be irritated about it. What naggers.

sentences: このえいがは長かったです。
This movie was long.
あそこのドアの近くに立ってるかみの長い女性が、たん当しゃの方です。
That lady with long hair standing by the door is the one in charge.
長い距離のランニングを避けるため、自分の足の骨を折ってしまおうと思っている。
I'm thinking about breaking my own legs to avoid going long distance running.

mnemonics.meaning: 宝 is a treasure. くじ is a lottery. So if you have a treasure lottery (you win treasure if you win the lottery) then you have yourself a lottery.
mnemonics.reading: The reading uses the 宝 vocab reading, たから.

sentences: 「妹が宝くじに当たったのよ。」「すごいね！で、いくら？」「一万円。」
"My little sister won the lottery." "Oh cool! How much?" "10,000 yen."
きぼうてきかんそくでは、来年あたりに宝くじに当たるはずです。
It's wishful thinking, but I'll probably win the lottery at some point next year.
父親の秘書が宝くじに当たったんだけど、それをフェイスブックに書いた時に秘書を秘密と書き間違えてしまい、みんなが勘違いしてたくさんおめでとうコメントを残してくれました。
My dad's secretary won the lottery, but I made a spelling mistake when I posted it on Facebook. Secretary was spelled secretly. It confused people and I got a lot of congrats.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 文字 means "letters". So, what are "small letters"? That would be lowercase letters.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 小 is an exceptional reading. You know it means "small," so think about what else is small: a child. How do you say "child" in Japanese? こ. You also know how to say the 文字 portion from the previous level, so combine those together and you have こもじ.

sentences: どうやって小文字と大文字を切りかえますか。
How do you switch from lowercase to uppercase?
パスワードには、かならず大文字、小文字、すう字を一つい上つかってください。
Passwords must contain at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter and a number.
君のEメールアドレスって、全部小文字なの？本当に？ちょっとおかしいんじゃないの？
Is your email address in all lowercase letters? Is it really? Are you crazy?

mnemonics.meaning: The diagram of the earth. What could that be other than a map?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: スマートフォンで地図を出しました。
I got out the map on my smartphone.
地図をかた手に東京を歩きました。
I walked around Tokyo with a map.
先生、もし世界地図を忘れたのなら、私の額にタトゥーの世界地図がありますよ。
Teacher, if you forget your world map I have one tattoo'd on my forehead.

mnemonics.meaning: Grass covering the earth is a meadow. Or, if you're less creative, it's grassland.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

sentences: 一とうの牛が草地をのんびり歩いていました。
There was a cow walking leisurely in the meadow.
アイルランドには、ぼく草地や草地が多い。
There are a lot of pastures and grasslands in Ireland.
この金は、あそこの草地に隠そう。
Let’s hide this money in the meadow over there.

mnemonics.meaning: The water star is the planet Mercury. That's where we hid all of our secret moon water. Mercury looks enough like our moon, so we put it there so no one could find it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 水星には大気がありません。
Mercury does not have an atmosphere.
こんなはずじゃなかったんですが、もう十年も水星でホームレスをしています。
This isn't what I asked for, but I've been homeless for 10 years on Mercury.
水星は、日の出直前、または日没直後しか見ることができない。
I can only see Mercury just before sunrise and right after sunset.

mnemonics.meaning: The middle of the east is more simply known as the middle east.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: けさ、テレビで中東のニュースを見ました。
I watched the news on the Middle East on TV this morning.
きんきゅうじたいで中東に行かなくてはいけなかったんだから、けっこんしきに来れなかったのは仕方がないよ。
You can't help it that you couldn't make it to the wedding because you had to go to the Middle East for an emergency.
中東で一番楽しまれているゲームは何ですか？
What is the most played game in the Middle East?

mnemonics.meaning: Death and deceased. That's a lot of death. This is mortality.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: やさいをたくさん食べると、死亡リスクがへるそうです。
I heard that when you eat a lot of vegetables you can lower your risk of mortality.
山田さんの弟さんの死亡のげんいんはなんですか？
What is the cause of Mr. Yamada's younger brother's death?
チーズバーガーの発明により、全先進国の死亡率が三倍に跳ね上がった。
Since the invention of the cheeseburger, mortality rates in all first-world nations have tripled.

mnemonics.meaning: A country's treasure is their national treasure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私のきおくが正しければ、これは国宝ではありません。
If I remember correctly, this is not a national treasure.
「どうしてこのそうじきは国宝なんですか？」「ニコラス・ケイジがつかったことがあるからだよ。」
"Why is this vacuum cleaner a national treasure?" "Because Nic Cage used it before."
crabigator.churchに国宝が隠されている。
A national treasure is hidden in crabigator.church.

mnemonics.meaning: When something involves all the country you know it's nationwide or national.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 全国でインフルエンザがはやっています。
The flu is spreading nationwide.
リンゴのしゅうかくりょうが全国で一ばん多いけんはどこですか？
Which prefecture is the largest producer of apples nationwide?
彼は全国規模のサイバーいじめのスキャンダルに関与していた。
He was involved in a nationwide cyber bullying scandal.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You learned the reading for this word via the kanji, so you should be able to read this word just fine.

sentences: パソコンのしすぎで、首がいたいです。
I’ve been using my computer too much so my neck hurts.
首をねちがえました。
I cricked my neck in my sleep.
腺ペストって、首から胸が生えてくる病気のことですか？
Is the bubonic plague the illness that made people grow boobs on their necks?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  Someone yells out "NEXT!" because the first thing didn't work on you. That was a single guillotine. Now they are going to try two guillotines (つぎ) and see how that works on your thick neck. NEXXXXT!

sentences: 次のでん車にのりましょう。
Let’s catch the next train.
次のよていは、決まり次だいお知らせします。
I'll let you know once we decide on the next plan.
このバスツアーの次の目的地は、マイケル・ジャクソンの家です。
The next destination on this bus tour is Michael Jackson’s house.

mnemonics.meaning: The next time you look at this kanji, you should know that it means next time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 次回の作ひんも、たのしみにしています。
I’m looking forward to the next production.
次回なんてないんだよ。人生は一どきりなんだから。
There is no next time. We only live once.
兄貴、心配するなよ。次回は絶対あいつらを仕留めてやろうぜ。
Don’t worry, bro. We’ll get them next time, yo.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  It is the night, but it is your (よる) night.

sentences: きのうの夜、パーティーに行きました。
I went to a party last night.
きのうの夜は、こうふんしてほとんどねむれませんでした。
Last night, I was so excited that I barely slept.
夜には、モンスターたちが床から這い上がり、私のベッドの下でお茶会を開くんだよ。
Night is the time when monsters crawl up through the floor to have tea parties under my bed.

mnemonics.meaning: If you think about direct going (aka transportation) how would you make it better? You'd make it so everything was nonstop and direct. Just imagine how much nicer it would be if every airplane you took was direct and you never had to stop. So nice!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The ちょく of 直 is shortened with a small っ, though, so make sure to take note of that.

sentences: このひ行きは、東京に直行します。
This airplane is nonstop to Tokyo.
今日は、日本との会ぎの後、トーフグとのアポに直行します。
Today after the meeting with Japan, I'll go directly to the appointment with Tofugu.
ごめんなさい、今は話せません。トイレへ直行しているところなのです。
I’m sorry, I can't talk right now. I’m on a nonstop trip to the bathroom.

mnemonics.meaning: You know the word 足りる from Level 4. What is this one? it's the opposite (negative form on a verb is ない). So, what is the opposite of 足りる (To be sufficient)? The opposite is to not be sufficient or not enough.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 足りる (たりる) which you should have seen in Level 4.

sentences: お金が十円足りないんです。
I’m ten yen short.
もしスペースが足りなければ、べつの用しについきして、それをてんぷしてください。
If there is insufficient space, attach a separate sheet with additional information.
ビル・ゲイツは私の息子なのだが、それを証明するための証拠がまだ足りない。
Bill Gates is my son, but there isn’t enough evidence to prove it yet.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're years above someone else, you are older than that person.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is an exception, because it uses kun'yomi readings even though it is a jukugo kanji. You already know the separate kun'yomi readings from the vocabulary of the last level, but you will have to remember to actually use this knowledge when this word comes up.

sentences: 年上の人と、デートするのははじめてです。
This is my first date with an older person.
人生はよそく不かのうだ。お前が年上のび人とけっこんするかのうせいだってゼロパーセントではない。
Life is unpredictable. It's not a zero percent chance that you will get married with a beautiful older woman.
お父さんが、お母さんのお母さんはピラミッドよりも年上だと言うんだよ。
My dad says that my mom’s mom is older than the pyramids.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is your older sister, by the way. Not somebody else's.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet,  so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Picture your older sister (even if you don't have one), her birthday is coming up and there's only one thing she wants from you. A necklace (あね). She's wanted a necklace for years and you're finally going to give her one. She'll be so happy.

sentences: 姉のいえに行くところです。
I’m just about to go to my older sister’s house.
わたしは、姉の五ばいのりょうの本をもっています。
I have five times as many books as my older sister does.
姉はスチュワーデスをしています。
My big sister works as a stewardess.

mnemonics.meaning: The お makes the word more polite. You're elevating the "older sister" title because you're a good younger sibling. Otherwise, the meaning of this word is the same as the kanji - just the feeling is different. You can also use this word to refer to a youthful-looking woman that you don't know, as in "Excuse me miss!"
mnemonics.reading: The reading is different too. It has some hiragana attached to it, which is a clue that this uses a kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to learn that reading.  Imagine your older sister (even if you don't have one). She is, for some reason, a horse. Imagine petting her, giving her carrots, and doing other horse-related things with her. What do horses say? They say nehhhh (ねえ).

sentences: みどりちゃんのお姉さんはめがねをかけています。
Midori’s older sister is wearing glasses.
あなたのこと、てっきりビエトくんのお姉さんだと思ってたんですが、ちがったんですね。
I totally thought you were Viet's older sister, but you aren't, eh?
私のお姉さんは、バイクを買うことが彼氏を見つけることに繋がると考えています。
My older sister thinks that buying a motorcycle will help her get a boyfriend.

mnemonics.meaning: If 歩 is "walk" and you take one walk, then really you are just taking one step. When there's a number before 歩, it refers to the number of steps you're taking. The most common is this one, and you'll see it on urinals when they kindly ask you to please take one step forward because peeing isn't a game and somebody has to clean up after you.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is pretty standard in its trickiness. The いち shortens to an いっ and the ほ rendakus to ぽ. One step at a time, right?

sentences: ようやく、ゆめに向かって一歩ふみ出しました。
I’ve finally taken one step forward toward my dream.
千里の道も一歩からって言うでしょ？
They say, a journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, right?
最初の一歩を踏み出すのに勇気がいる。
It takes courage to take the first step forward.

mnemonics.meaning: The outside of the sea is someplace overseas. It can also be foreign or abroad if those words are easier to remember for you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: しょう来は、海外ではたらきたいです。
I want to work overseas in the future.
ほけんぎょうかいに八年つとめた後、アメリカへ海外りゅう学しました。
After having worked in the insurance industry for eight years, I went to America to study abroad.
私はどこか海外で住みたいと思っているが、旅行は嫌いだ。
I want to live somewhere overseas, but I hate traveling.

mnemonics.meaning: Something is flat and relaxed. That is you. What words does that describe? To me, that would be peace and tranquility. Just imagine something that is flat and relaxed, like a field of grass with happy people in it. It's so peaceful! It's so tranquil! This is also the way you write the Heian period of Japanese history.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 平安じだいはいつですか。
When was the Heian period?
平安をみだす人がいないワニカニフォーラムは、わたしの心に平安をあたえてくれる。
The WaniKani forums don't have any trolls, so it gives me peace of mind.
ブリティッシュコロンビアの古の森を歩く時、心に平安を感じる。
Walking through the old growth forests in British Columbia was so peaceful.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen 生活 before, right? So what about the "life" of I? Whose life is that? Why, that's my own personal life.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチの私生活は、ひみつのベールにつつまれています。
Koichi's personal life is cloaked in secrecy.
生まれつき人よりめんえき力が弱いので、私生活ではいつもマスクをしています。
My immune system has been weaker than most people's since I was born, so I usually wear a mask when I'm on my own.
