mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このどうしの活用形を教えてください。
Please teach me the conjugated form of this verb.
昨日から、じょどうしの活用形をべんきょうし直してます。
Yesterday, I started re-learning the conjugated form of auxiliary verbs.
この辞書アプリでは、活用形から動詞の逆引き検索も可能です。
In this dictionary app it’s possible to look up verbs using their conjugated forms.

mnemonics.meaning: When you write down your day (and do it every day) that's your diary.
mnemonics.reading: This jukugo word uses the on'yomi readings, except the 日 (にち) is shortened with a small っ, making the reading にっき.

sentences: あなたの日記も、この本と一しょにここにおいておきます。
I’m going to leave your diary with this book here.
北米には、こうかん日記みたいな文化はないんだよ。
We don't have a culture of diary exchange in North America.
昨日の夜、フグの日記を読んだんだけどさ、実はとても悲しい日記だったんだよね。
I read Fugu’s journal last night and, to be honest, it was really sad.

mnemonics.meaning: A street you can see with your eye isn't soooo big you can't see it (like a town would be), but it's still pretty big because it has a street. This section of the town is the district of a town, or a city block (though specifically one of an irregular size).
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, so use those and you'll be A-Okay.

sentences: ぼくのかの女は、同じ町の二丁目にすんでいるミイコちゃんです。
My girlfriend Miiko lives in 2-chome too.
その台風で、一丁目と二丁目がしん水してしまいました。
The typhoon flooded both 1-chome and 2-chome.
この桃、三丁目の田中さんから頂いたの。
I got this peach from Tanaka of 3-chome.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is person shaped that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of doll or puppet.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 人 is pretty normal, though the reading for 形 is different from the one you learned. To remember this, think of a doll... made totally of gyoza (ぎょう) dumplings. This doll is crazy (like most dolls) and it's eating itself and trying to get you to eat some of it too. Hey... why you no eat me? Mmmm. Gyoza doll.

sentences: たん生日プレゼントに、人形をもって行きます。
I’m going to bring a doll for her birthday present.
その人形、ちゃんと元のところにもどしておいてね。
Put the doll back the way you found it.
17歳まで、私の親友は靴下で作った腕人形だった。
Until the age of 17, my best friend was a sock puppet.

mnemonics.meaning: You know 学生 is student, so what is a small student? Think young. That would be an Elementary School Student.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 小学生だからって、あまく見てるとけがするぜ！
I may just be an elementary school student, but if you underestimate me, you'll regret it!
きょうしつのドアをあけると、一人の小学生が石ころみたいにぐっすりねむっていました。
When I opened the classroom door, there was a grade schooler sleeping like a rock.
小学生の頃、いつもコインを投げて自分の行動を決めていました。
When I was an elementary school student, I always made my decisions by flipping a coin.

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 月 can also mean month? If you add 末 on there you have the "month end" aka the end of the month.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 月末までに五キロやせます。
I’m going to lose five kilos by the end of this month.
ここ、ブラックきぎょうすぎるから、月末ににげ出すわ。
This company exploits its employees too much, so I'm bailing out at the end of the month!
私の上司は、コアラで給料を払います。毎月末、わたしには二匹のコアラが支払われます。
My boss pays me in koala bears. I get two at the end of every month.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  Imagine a fish. Now imagine the fish playing soccer, while wearing a nun's outfit. This is a soccer nun (さかな).

sentences: 魚はすきですが、生魚はにが手です。
I like fish, but I don’t like it raw.
バランスのいいちょう食をとるために、いつもグラノーラと魚を食べます。
I always eat granola and fish for a well-balanced breakfast.
もう絶対にメキシコの軽トラの積み荷から魚を買うもんか。
I’ll never buy fish from the back of a pickup truck in Mexico again.

mnemonics.meaning: Your future consists of certain death. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very frantic and desperate.  Another translation for this word is simply certain death, though I'd rather you learn one of the first two before this one if you can.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the on'yomi readings, though 必 (ひつ) gets shortened to ひっ. In your desperate situation just imagine that you're trying to get out of it, and to do so you move the つ only to find a smaller っ blocking your way. It is certain death.

sentences: 必死にがんばっても、どうにもならないこともある。
Even if I try desperately, it might still be futile.
わたしのそ父は、必死のかくごでせんじょうに向かったそうです。
I heard that my grandfather went to the war front prepared to die.
「隊長、私はどうしても火星に戻る必要があるんです。アイフォンを忘れてしまったのです。」彼は必死に頼んだ。
"Captain, I really need to return to Mars. I left my iPhone there," he said desperately.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have self reason, you are able to think for yourself. When you can think for yourself, you have freedom. Very philosophical this vocab is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 一人ぐらしをはじめて、自由なじかんができました。
I started living by myself and I have some free time to spare.
自由になるための道のりはまだまだとおいですが、ぜったいにあきらめません。
To obtain freedom, we still have a long way to go, but we will never give up.
日本のサラリーマンが自由に使えるお金は、毎月平均たった三万五千円だ。
The money Japanese salarymen can use freely every month is, on average, usually only 35,000 yen.

mnemonics.meaning: Both of these kanji have to do with names. You have both family name and name. Both of those names together makes for a First And Last Name... a full name if you will.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 自分の氏名ぐらいは、日本ごでかけるようになりたいよね。
You at least want to be able to write your full name in Japanese, right?
ごさん考までに、わたしの氏名は、高 一子です。
For your information, my name is Ichiko Ko.
そちらの誓約書に氏名をご記入頂ければ、大砲で貴方の頭の上の林檎を撃ちぬいて差し上げます。
If you would please write your first and last name on the waiver, we will proceed with shooting an apple off of your head with a cannon.

mnemonics.meaning: What has not yet come? The future.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: タイムスリップできるなら、未来に行きたいな。
If I could time travel, I’d want to go to the future.
週末は、未来とか去を行ったり来たりしていました。
On the weekend, I was traveling back and forth through time.
コウイチにはうちゅうひ行しとしての大きな未来があるんだから、たのむからじゃましないでやってくれよ。
Koichi has a bright future as an astronaut, so please don't interrupt him.

mnemonics.meaning: The reason the earth is the way it is because of the geography of it. Though it may seem kind of strange that geography is bringing reason to the earth, if you think of geography as a study, then you can think about how you try to get reason through that, as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 一人で地理のべん強をするのもすきですが、友だちとべん強する方がたのしいです。
I like studying geography by myself too, but it’s more fun to study with my friend.
アメリカ人の友人は地理が全くのにが手で、さい近まで日本が中国の首とだとおもっていたらしい。
My American friend is not good at geography at all, so I heard that she used to think Japan was the capital of China until very recently.
俺たちが道に迷ったってどういうことだよ？お前、地理の先公じゃねえのかよ？
What do you mean we’re lost? Aren’t you a geography teacher?

mnemonics.meaning: A gold fish is really just gold in color, but it's still called a goldfish.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これは、五年前の夏まつりの金魚すくいですくった金魚です。
I scooped this goldfish at a goldfish scooping booth during a summer festival five years ago.
金魚もかぜをひくんですか？
Can goldfish get colds, too?
金魚は、三秒間しか記憶がないので、自分たちがお城に住んでいることに気がつく度に驚いています。
Goldfish only have three second memories so they’re always surprised when they realize that they live in a castle.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You're part of a special group. It is the cumin group, and they deal with all things cumin (the spice / seed). Smell the cumin. Touch it. Taste it. You live and breathe the stuff, because you are the president of this cumin group. P.S. This can also be spelled 組み (same overall reading: くみ).

sentences: これから、みなさんを二組に分けます。
After this, we’ll be splitting into two teams.
オレたちの組はこの辺じゃ有名なんだぜ。
Our group is famous around here.
三年二組のコウイチくん、またこく白されたらしいよ。
I heard Koichi in grade 3 class 2 was asked out again.

mnemonics.meaning: When something is hand made, it is handmade!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. Just think of this word as two separate words put together (手 and 作る). The る in 作る gets changed to り because it's an adjective, and the つ in つくり gets changed to づ because of the way the words are combined with each other. You should know most of the reading that is in this word, though it will probably take a little bit of thinking to sort out the little changes in those readings.

sentences: このテーブルは、林さんの手作りです。
This table was handmade by Hayashi.
毎日手作りのバランスのいい食じをとるようにしています。
I try to have a homemade, well-balanced diet every day.
手作りのプレゼントは、どれだけ暇な時間があるかってことがバレてしまうので、結構怖い。
Handmade presents are pretty scary because they reveal that you have too much free time.

mnemonics.meaning: The big thing in the sky is the heavens. The heavens where birds and planes soar, not the one you go to after you die if you've been really good.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that そら becomes ぞら because of rendaku here.

sentences: 大空を見ていたら、いやな気もちがふきとんだ。
The unpleasant feeling vanished when I looked up at the sky.
アイリちゃんは大空にうかぶお星さまになったんだよ。
Airi became a star in the firmament.
鷲が大空を悠々と飛んでいた。
The eagle flew leisurely in the heavens.

mnemonics.meaning: The tall school is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's high school, when most people stop growing taller.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 高校まで、車で行けば十分ですよ。
It only takes 10 minutes to get to the high school if you drive.
高校ではいつも、おひるにどんなものを食べていますか？
What kind of food do you guys usually have for lunch in high school?
高校に行って初めて話をし始めたんです。そして、今は、話を止めることができません。
I didn’t start talking until I went to high school. Now I can’t shut up.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  What do you do in your home? You eat eggs (いえ), that's what. You eat eggs three times a day, every day. You really love eating eggs in your house!

sentences: みなさん、家にあそびに来てください。
Everyone, please stop by my house.
いいかげん、家をかた付けた方がいいよ。
You really need to clean your house.
家とは、みんなの心と食べ物がある場所です。
Home is where the heart is. And the food.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the way to make something. This is how to make something. You'll see this for directions on building something.
mnemonics.reading: You should know the kun'yomi readings for both of these from lower level vocab. Use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

sentences: おいしいマカロニチーズの作り方を教えてください。
Please teach me how to make delicious macaroni and cheese.
麦茶の作り方には、おゆでわかしながらに出す方ほう、ふっとうさせたおゆでジワジワおゆ出しする方ほう、つめたい水でジワジワ水出しする方ほうの三しゅるいありますが、それぞれメリットデメリットがあります。
There are three ways to make barley tea; steeping it in boiling water, steeping it slowly in boiled water, and steeping it slowly in cold water, and each comes with pros and cons.
手裏剣の作り方を知りたいですか？
Do you want to know how to make a ninja star?

mnemonics.meaning: A boat's body is called the hull.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 船体にらくがきをしたのはだれだ！？
Who graffitied the hull?
クラーケンがしょく手で船体をつきやぶったんだ。
The kraken smashed its tentacles through the ship's hull.
船体は思った以上に大きかった。
The hull was bigger than I thought.

mnemonics.meaning: A person's hometown is a human habitation, or a village. This word has a slightly old-fashioned feel, and it's usually used for small villages in the countryside. It's often combined with はなれた (separated) to talk about how far away from the nearest human habitation something is.
mnemonics.reading: This jukugo uses the kun'yomi of the kanji instead of the more usual on'yomi. You learned both of these readings when you learned the vocabulary 人 and 里. Just notice that さと becomes ざと, because of rendaku.

sentences: クマは山から人里に出てくることがある。
Bears sometimes come out of the mountains into human habitations.
ここは人里はなれたところだな。
We're in the middle of nowhere, huh?
人里はなれた山の中からは、月が明るく見える。
The moon was brightly visible from the middle of the remote mountains.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the adverb version of the kanji big. It's a little thing you can put in front of things to say that they are "in a big way" or "on a grand scale."
mnemonics.reading: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 大きい, you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: 大きくいきをついてください。
Please exhale deeply.
このトウフ＆フグのピザチェーンは、大きくきぼをかく大している。
This Tofu & Fugu pizza chain is expanding its franchise in a big way.
円の価値が大きく上昇した。
The value of yen has risen greatly.

mnemonics.meaning: Your inside ポケット is your inside pocket.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi for the kanji. You learned that reading when you learned the word 内.

sentences: このスーツのジャケットには内ポケットがありません。
This suit jacket doesn't have an inside pocket.
このノートは、バッグの内ポケットに入ります。
This notebook fits into the inside pocket of a bag.
見て、あの子、内ポケットに虫を入れてるよ！
Look, that kid's putting bugs in his inside pocket.

mnemonics.meaning: When something is close close (the 々 character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen in the near future, or soon.  This is pretty vague, and it's up to the person speaking to decide how soon soon is. Depending on the person and the situation, it could technically be used for anything up to a few years!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi reading twice; that's the one you learn with the vocab word 近い from the previous level. The second 近 gets converted to ぢか, though, so take note of that.

sentences: それについては、近々はっぴょうがあると思いますよ。
I think there will be an announcement about it soon.
近々雪がふるはずなので、たくさんつもったらかまくらを作ります。
We're supposed to get snow soon, so if we get a lot, I will make a snow igloo.
もしタバコを吸い続けるなら、あなたは近々癌を発症するでしょう。
You’ll get cancer before long if you keep smoking.

mnemonics.meaning: The tree star is the planet Jupiter. Imagine Jupiter covered in very strange trees — the kind that are able to take root in gas! It's a pretty weird image, but will hopefully help you to remember this word. Alternatively, think about how the clouds around Jupiter make patterns that look a lot like wood grain.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いつか、木星に行きたいと思っています。
I'd like to go to Jupiter someday.
火星と木星のあいだには、何がありますか。
What is there between Mars and Jupiter?
木星や土星はこうして生まれたんですよ。
This is how planets like Jupiter and Saturn were born.

mnemonics.meaning: The previous week was last week.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 先週は学校はお休みでした。
School was out last week.
大きくなったねー。先週はまだあんなに小さかったのに。
You sure have grown a lot! You were still tiny last week though.
先週出席した経済相互援助会議で、喋る犬にインタビューされたんだが、あいつは本当に嫌なやつだった。
I was interviewed by a talking dog about the Comecon convention I attended last week. He was so insulting.

mnemonics.meaning: Compared with this, it's below. That's another way to say that what you have is less than it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 五千円以下の本だなをさがしています。
I’m looking for a bookshelf that’s 5,000 yen or less.
コウイチのすきなネコのしゅるいは以下の通りです。
The list of cat breeds that Koichi likes is as follows:
以下同文です。
Those below are the same.

mnemonics.meaning: A hand paper is a letter because letters are generally written by hand on paper. If you want a more graphic image, imagine writing a letter on your hand, and how much it would hurt to chop off your hand and send it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is double kun'yomi (body parts tend to make kanji in words change to a kun'yomi reading). Both kanji in this word had you learn that reading right from the start, though, so you should be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku making it がみ, not かみ.

sentences: 外国に手紙を出しました。
I sent a letter to a foreign country.
その金正日からの手紙、ネットオークションに出しちゃえば？きっとだれかしらかうと思うよ。
Why don't you put up the letter from Kim Jong Il for online auction? I think somebody would buy it.
私はコカコーラ宛に、心のこもった手紙を書いて、どうして彼らの製品にたくさん砂糖が入っているのかについて尋ねたいと思います。
I’m going to write a very heated letter to Coca-Cola and ask why there is so much sugar in their products.

mnemonics.meaning: A small voice is so small that you can hardly hear it. It's a low voice or a whisper.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because, like in 大声, the こえ becomes ごえ thanks to our old friend rendaku.

sentences: 二人とも、どうして小声ではなしているの？
Why are they both whispering?
「ビエトに学ランをきてもらいたいんだ。に合うと思うんだよね。」と、わたしのもうそうの中でコウイチがビエトに小声で言った。
"I want you to try on a school uniform. I think you'll look good in it." Koichi whispered to Viet in my fantasy.
男は、小声で話し始めた。
The man started speaking in a low voice.

mnemonics.meaning: The fire star is Mars. This should be easy to remember, because Mars is the only planet in our solar system that's the color of fire.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今夜は火星と土星が見えるよ！
Mars and Saturn will be visible tonight!
火星には水がありますか？
Is there water on Mars?
オリンポス山は、火星にある火山の名です。
Olympus Mons is the name of a volcano on Mars.

mnemonics.meaning: The reasoning of your heart decides what you do. Probably when kanji was being made people thought that the heart directed our actions, not our brains. So, if you think about it that way, the reasoning of your heart is your mental state. Nowadays that's known as psychology.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ねこの心理を思うがままにあやつれるようになりたい。
I want to be able to manipulate cats' minds as much as I want.
春人には、理子の心理が分からなかった。
Haruto didn't understand what Riko was thinking about.
サーモンと彼女に翻弄される人々の心理を、君の小説で描いてみてもらえないかな？人気が出ると思うんだけど。
Can you depict the mental state of Salmon and those she deceives in your novel? I think people would love it.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen 学生 (means student). Now let's look at a student who's in the middle. Perhaps we can call this a middle school student or a junior high school student, depending on where you're from.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 中学生にもなって、まだお母さんといっしょにおふろに入ってるんですか？
You are a middle schooler now, but you're still taking baths with your mom?
かち目のないたたかいはしない方がいいということは、中学生でも知っているよ。
Even a junior high student knows that you should choose your battles wisely.
中学生の頃、自分自身に、「書かなくても覚えられるから大丈夫」という大法螺をふいてしまいました。
When I was a middle school student, the biggest lie I said to myself was, "I can remember that without writing it down."

mnemonics.meaning: What's part of an hour? A minute, or minutes! This word is the suffix version of 分, so it goes after numbers to say how many minutes, and is used for telling the time too.
mnemonics.reading: How many minutes of fun (ふん) will you have today? Lots and lots of minutes, I hope! Depending on the number before 分, its pronunciation can change to ぷん, because of rendaku. We're looking for the original reading ふん here though!

sentences: 大体、二分くらいかかります。
It generally takes about two minutes.
十五分休みましょうか。
Shall we rest for fifteen minutes?
その一年生はベッドの下に四十五分もかくれている。
That first year student has been hiding under the bed for forty-five minutes.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means family name because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word mister. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji.

sentences: やはり、アベ氏のはつげんはいつも全くブレませんね。
As we all know, Mr. Abe’s statements never change.
コウイチ氏とビエト氏はとても気が合う。
Mr. Koichi and Mr. Viet have good chemistry.
おお、ホワイト氏、ちょっと座れば？
Yo, Mr. White, why don’t you just sit down?

mnemonics.meaning: Compared with this, it's more. That's another way to say that what you have is more than it. That's all. ;)
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このえいがは、十八才以上しか見れません。
Only people 18 or older can watch this movie.
手つづきは以上です。
That's all for the paperwork.
１００歳以上の人は、必ずブラジャーを着用し無くてはならない。
People who are 100 years old or older must wear bras.

mnemonics.meaning: Adding "third generation" to someone's name means that they are the third generation of people with that name. In this case, the person's name is ナポレオン (Napoleon), so this means Napoleon The Third, also written as Napoleon III.
mnemonics.reading: The kanji here are pronounced exactly the same as in the standalone word 三世. That is, it's a jukugo word which uses the on'yomi for both kanji.

sentences: 今日は、ナポレオン三世について学びましょう。
Today, we're going to learn about Napoleon The Third.
ナポレオン三世は1808年に生まれた。
Napoleon III was born in the year 1808.
ナポレオン・ボナパルトはナポレオン三世より有名ですよね。
Napoleon Bonaparte is more famous than Napoleon III, isn't he?

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji near. So it also means near, or in the neighborhood of something.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 近い, so you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: 今は、学校の近くに、姉とすんでいます。
I’m currently living with my sister near the school.
あのアイドル、近くで見るとあんまりかわいくないね。
Seen close up, that teen idol is not pretty at all, huh?
近くの焼き鳥屋で、一杯ひっかけていかないか。
Don’t you want to have a drink at the yakitori shop nearby?

mnemonics.meaning: The ocean king's star is Neptune! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 海王星は、太ようから八ばん目のわく星です。
Neptune is the eighth planet from the sun.
海王星に行くことをずっとゆめ見てきたんです。
I've always dreamed of going to Neptune.
海王星は1846年9月23日に発見されました。
Neptune was discovered on September 23rd, 1846.

mnemonics.meaning: The next week is the next week. It isn't last week or this week, it's the next one!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 来週の日よう日にレストランに行きます。
I’m going to a restaurant next Sunday.
来週はどれぐらい雪がふるかな？
I wonder how much snow we'll get next week.
飲み会は来週に延期になりました。
The drinking party was postponed until next week.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the adverb version of 未, meaning it means the same thing: not yet.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Someone's telling you "not yet... not yet.... not yet..." you have some food on your nose, but you're not allowed to eat it until your ma says it's okay. "Not yet... Not yet..." Why would your mom treat you like a dog like this? Oh well... maybe she'll let you eat the food soon, at least.

sentences: 未だ二百才まで生きた人げんはいない。
There’s still never been a person who’s lived to two hundred years old.
未だ、時さボケがあるんですよね。
I’m still jet-lagged.
仕事が決まったのかどうかは未だ分からないんだ。向こうは未だ、十二人も面接しなきゃいけないみたい。
I’m not sure if I got the job yet. It seems like they still have to interview twelve other applicants.

mnemonics.meaning: An ocean fish is simply an ocean fish. They also happen to be the most delicious kind of fish.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Some people also use the kun'yomi readings, but it's much less common, and generally considered colloquial.

sentences: さけは海魚ですか？それとも川魚ですか？
Is salmon a saltwater fish? Or is it a freshwater fish?
海中には、色とりどりの海魚がおよいでいました。
In the sea, there were a lot of colorful ocean fish swimming around.
水族館には沢山の種類の海魚がいますが、スタッフは僕達に一匹も食べてはいけませんと言いました。
There is a wide variety of saltwater fish at the aquarium, but the staff said we’re not allowed to eat any of them.

mnemonics.meaning: If there's a number before 時, it means o'clock. For example １時 is 1:00, and ２３時 is 23:00 or 11pm.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 三時になったらおやつ休けいにしましょう。
When it’s three o’clock let’s have our afternoon snack break.
コウイチの家の台どころで二時半にまちあわせね。
Let's meet up at Koichi's kitchen at 2:30, ok?
いつも１５時にワニカニのレビューをするんですか？
Do you usually do your WaniKani reviews at 3pm?

mnemonics.meaning: This word starts with an お to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji 兄 which you already know. Lastly, it has さん which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying older brother (versus plain old 兄). It can also be used to refer to a guy that you don't know who has a youthful appearance.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the 兄 part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Your (kind) older brother pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your knee (にい), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you お兄さん!"

sentences: どれがたかしのお兄さんですか。
Which one is Takashi’s older brother?
今日のたっきゅうびんのお兄さんのかおがタイプすぎた。
The delivery guy today had exactly the type of face I go for.
お兄さんのはなげがきになってしかたがない。
I can’t help thinking about my older brother’s nose hair.

mnemonics.meaning: One bread loaf counter is counting one loaf of bread.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening though!

sentences: 一斤のパンは6枚切りか8枚切りで売られていることが多い。
Loaves of bread are often sold in slices of six or eight.
たった一斤のパンで給料日までを生き延びなければいけない。
I need to survive on only one loaf of bread until payday.
食パン一斤と、ニュテラがあれば生きていけるよ。
I can live off of a loaf of bread and some Nutella.

mnemonics.meaning: When it's one o'clock it's one o'clock. It's time to eat lunch, or take a nap, or something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 毎日一時にランチを食べます。
I eat lunch at one o'clock every day.
一時までにおもちゃをかたづけなさい。
Put your toys away by one o'clock.
もし私のところで働くなら、あなたのシフトは午後一時から遅くとも三時までになりますが、よろしいですか？
If you worked for me, your shift would start at one o’clock in the afternoon and end at three o’clock at latest. Sound good?

mnemonics.meaning: Compared with this, it's outside what you wanted. You'll have anything other than that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビール以外ならなんでもいいです。
I’m okay with anything other than beer.
マンガ以外は何もよみません。
I read nothing but manga.
式の間中新郎が花嫁の胸元を上から眺めていたこと以外は、とても素敵な結婚式でした。
Other than the groom looking down the front of the bride’s dress during the ceremony, it was a nice wedding.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but lucky for you that's the reading you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this vocab too.

sentences: 紙とえんぴつとけしゴムをつくえに出してください。
Please put some paper, a pencil, and an eraser on your desk.
あたらしい紙をかうのがたのしみでしかたがない。
I'm so looking forward to buying a new piece of paper.
昨日、紙の切れ端に詩を書いている狼を見かけた。
Yesterday, I saw a wolf writing a poem on a piece of paper.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a period of time and it's called a period or era! Simple!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今の時代は、インターネットで何でもかうことができます。
In this era, you can buy anything on the Internet.
明里は、わたしの大学時代の友人です。
Akari is my friend from college.
紫式部は、平安時代中期の女性作家かつ歌人です。
Murasaki Shikibu was a female writer and poet from the mid–Heian period.

mnemonics.meaning: From before, just means previously or before now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 以前、パーティーで一どお会いしましたよね。
I met you once before at a party, right?
以前はよく船よいしていたんですが、今はさっぱりなくなりました。
I used to get seasick all the time, but not anymore.
私の親友は、以前は天文学者に知られていなかった惑星の出身です。
My best friend is from a planet that was previously unknown to astronomers.

mnemonics.meaning: The reason your heart does what it does is all psychological. The study of that is psychology.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: えいぎょうをするなら、心理学を学んだ方がいいよ。
You should study psychology if you work in sales.
心理学のせつ明によると「あい手にひどいことが言えるということは、その人にいぞんしてるということ」らしいです。
According to the psychology explanation, it looks like when you are able to say something mean to a person, you're actually being dependent on them.
私は大学で犯罪心理学を専攻していました。
My major was criminal psychology in college.

mnemonics.meaning: 本当 is reality or truth (level 5 vocab). If you add on に, this changes the word to an adverb, and we get really or truly. 本当に!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It shares the reading with the level 5 本当 as well, but just has a particle on the end. Really!

sentences: 日本の人たちは、本当にやさしいです。
Japanese people are really kind.
このせいひん、本当に高くなっちゃったねー。
This product has gotten truly expensive.
本当にこの道であっていますか？
Is this really the way?

mnemonics.meaning: A reason reason is a reason! How could it not? Do you have a reason why it shouldn't be? I thought not. This word means "reason" as in the reason you're studying Japanese, or the reason you're late. That's why it can also mean similar words like motive and excuse.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: とくに理由はありません。
I don’t have any specific reason.
未だけいひのせいさんをしてないのには、何か理由があるんですか？
Do you have any reason for not having settled your business expenses yet?
論理的な理由から、彼は行方不明になったゴム手袋の事件の犯人が風船屋であることを導いた。
For logical reasons, he was led to believe that the culprit in the case of the missing rubber gloves was the balloonist.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a counter that can be used after numbers to let you know what number room it is. It's a room number that you use in apartments and hotels to know exactly which room you're looking for.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: おきゃくさまのおへやは、302号室になります。
Your room is 302.
このマンションの444号室はゆうれいが出ることで有名です。
The room 444 of this apartment is known for being haunted.
102号室の坂本と申します。
I’m Sakamoto from room 102.

mnemonics.meaning: When you do something that's your fault and then you say "thanks" after you do it, that's super-duper rude, wouldn't you say? Imagine doing something like this and then thinking to yourself after... wow, I was really rude. This is also often used to mean excuse me, in which case it's usually followed by ですが or します. In casual situations, though, it's sometimes used on its own.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 失礼ですが、日本ごははなせますか。
Excuse me, but can you speak Japanese?
じっさいの会話で「あなた」という言ばを使うと、失礼にきこえることが多いです。
If you use "anata" in an actual conversation, it often sounds impolite.
もし私があなたに太いと言えば、失礼だと思いますか？
Would you think I’m rude if I told you that you’re fat?

mnemonics.meaning: The same time? Okay, let's say what we think this word means at the same time. Whoops, I just said it, sorry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 先生が教室に入ってきたと同時に、しぎょうのチャイムがなりました。
At the same time teacher came in the classroom, the bell rang.
でん子レンジとトースターを同時につかったから、ブレーカーがおちちゃったんだ。
I was using the microwave and the toaster at the same time, and the circuit breaker tripped.
「今日はよくできましたね。それではまた来週同じ時間に。」と、コスプレのプロとアニメオタクが同時に言った。
"Good lesson today. I’ll see you this time next week," the professional cosplayer and the anime nerd said at the same time.

mnemonics.meaning: A study school is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a school.
mnemonics.reading: This jukugo word consists of on'yomi readings, except 学 (がく) is shortened with a small っ to make it がっこう.

sentences: わたしは歩いて学校に行っています。
I go to school on foot.
学校にてい出するので、ちえんしょう明しょを下さい。
I have to submit an absentee notice to my school, so can I have one, please?
今日はどうして学校で授業中にホットドッグをバーベキューするの？
Why are we barbecuing hot dogs at school during class today?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You really want to eat food that's in neat shapes, so you decide to use a cutter (かた) on your cheese (ち) to make it a new shape. Square cheese is so boring. After you cut it up you have mouse shaped cheese! It just tastes better like that.

sentences: つまとそうだんして、形より内ようをおもんじたけっか、この形にきめました。
I spoke with my wife and we decided to go with this shape, because we value substance over form.
これでなんとか形がつきました。
With this, I could somehow manage to keep up appearances.
ねえ、私の、お尻の形をしたお腹、撫でたい？
Hey, do you want to rub my butt-shaped belly?

mnemonics.meaning: You have a lack of points. These are things about yourself you wish were better. These are your shortcomings.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because けつ is being shortened to けっ here!

sentences: だれだって、何かしらの欠点をもってるものさ。
Everyone has some sort of weakness.
そうだ、ちょっと思い出したんだけど、かの女って欠点がないんだよ。
Oh, I just remembered, she doesn't have any faults.
私は欠点がありすぎるので、絶対にプロのサッカー選手にはなれません。たとえば、私には足がありません。
I’ll never become a professional soccer player because I have too many shortcomings, for example, I don’t have any legs.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this vocab word. Enjoy the snow!

sentences: 日本でも、雪がふりますか？
Does it snow in Japan too?
そっちも雪、つもった？
Did you also get snow over there?
私が初めて雪を見たのは、四十六歳の時でした。
The first time I ever saw snow was when I was 46 years old.

mnemonics.meaning: Not to be confused with 会社, which is a company, this is society. When a company meets together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a society.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今家を出ても、社会のじゅぎょうに間にあわないと思います。
Even if I leave home right now, I think I’ll probably be late for social studies.
国さい社会の一員として、めしテロにはだんじてくっしません。
As a member of the international society, I will not yield to food porn.
社会問題として、若者がお葬式で自分撮りをすることについて考える必要がある。
As a society, we need to be concerned about youths taking ’selfies’ at funerals.

mnemonics.meaning: You have strong power. You are strong and powerful. Feel your strength.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このボンドは、かなり強力なので気をつけてください。
This glue is pretty strong, so please be careful.
強力なミニウォーターポンプの作り方をおしえてもらいました。
I was taught how to make a powerful, mini water pump.
彼女を見つめると、まるで十人力ぐらい強力になったように感じる。
When I look at her, I feel as though I have the strength of ten men.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strong? It's also strong.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  So you wanna be strong huh? Well, all you have to do is eat these two yogurts (つよ). One is filled with horse steroids, the other is full of bull steroids. They will make you so strong.

sentences: この中で一ばん強いのはだれですか。
Who is the strongest among these people?
クチバシと羽の色からさっするに、こいつはおそらくめちゃくちゃ強いカラスだね。
By the shape of the beak and color of the feathers, this would probably be a very strong crow.
海流はとても強く、その猫を川まで運んだ。
The ocean's currents were too strong for the cat and it was carried away.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for the vocab.

sentences: 今年の夏は、さく年よりもあついです。
This summer is hotter than last year.
近いうちに夏ワンピをかいに行きたいんだよね。
I want to go buy some summer dresses sometime soon.
夏にして楽しいことは三つだけだ。映画、ビデオゲーム、それから木彫の鴨を作ること。
Summer is only good for three things. Movies, video games, and duck carving.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 夏 means summer and 休 means rest. What is a "summer rest" though? It's a summer break or summer vacation.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are kun'yomi readings because this word is essentially two separate words put together into one word. You should know the reading for 夏 from the kanji and the reading for 休み from the vocab.

sentences: 夏休みは、一ヶ月あります。
Summer vacation is one month long.
夏休みにおきなわでダイビングをした時、しんじられないくらいたく山のしゅるいの魚を見ることができました！
I can't believe all the different kinds of fish we saw when diving in Okinawa during summer break.
小さいころ、夏休みに両親がディズニーランドに連れて行ってくれました。でも、帰り際、両親は何と私のことを忘れて帰ってしまったのです。あの時だけは、迷子になったことを嬉しく思いましたね。
When I was a kid, my parents took me to Disney Land for summer vacation, but they forgot me there when they left. It was the only time I was happy to be lost.

mnemonics.meaning: This word looks like a verb but it's not (sorry!). It's an adverb. The kanji itself means certain and the vocab version means all sorts of variations on that: surely, certainly, and without exception to name a few.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Ra, the Egyptian god asks you: "Can you do it? Are you certain you can build the pyramids?"  "Yes I can ra (かなら). Yes I can," you reply.

sentences: かれは必ずもどってくるので、大じょうぶです。
He’ll definitely come back, so I’m okay.
必ずねる前にコンタクトを外した方がいいよ。でないとし力がさらにおちるよ。
You should always take out your contacts before going to bed. Otherwise your eyesight will get worse.
何があっても必ずさい後までワニカニをやりとげます。
I will certainly complete WaniKani no matter what.

mnemonics.meaning: There are many white birds out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the swan. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 自どりをするためだけに白鳥をみずうみから引きずり出すなんてひどすぎるよ。
Pulling a swan out of the lake just to take a selfie with it is too cruel.
白ワインは魚りょうりに合うっていうけど、白鳥りょうりに合うワインは何か知っていますか？
They say that white wine goes well with fish, but do you know what kind of wine would go well with swan?
白鳥はとても美しいが、汚らしい言葉遣いをする。
Swans are so pretty, but they use foul language.

mnemonics.meaning: This word is almost the same as the kanji, but only half of it. It means tag or amulet. They're about the same shape and size as money, but you can't buy a house with them (...probably).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You can't find your tag anywhere. It was just there, you swear, but now it's nowhere to be found. You search for it everywhere, then you realize... it was right there all along. Seriously? You're such a fool, duh (ふだ)!

sentences: このお札は、げんかんのドアの内がわにはっておいてください。
Please put this amulet on the inside of your front door.
自分の札を見せないようにした方がいいよ。
You should be careful not to show your hand.
ジェロってほんとにキモい。ドクロマークの絵が描かれた札でも付けておくべきだよ。
Jello is really disgusting. There should be a picture of a skull and crossbones on the label.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of tall or expensive? It's the same: tall or expensive.  Weird that this word means both of these things, yeah? Just imagine money piled up to be really tall. That money is tall because it needs to buy something expensive.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  There's a tall dude trying to sell you something really expensive. He's really going off on how great this item is and how you should buy it. This guy is a real salesman. A real talker (たか).

sentences: この店は、高いですがおいしいです。
This restaurant is expensive, but delicious.
わたしには高すぎてとどかないので、とてもせが高いジェームズ・ステュアートを天国からよんできました。
That is too high for me to reach, so I've brought James Stewart, who is very tall, down from Heaven.
どうして、「ビッグアンドトール」のスーツはあんなに値段が高いんだ？
Why are suits from the "Big and Tall" store so expensive?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You've reached the end of the universe. Nothing is there. You step out, and you're surprised because you get greeted by an old Canadian man. Sue, eh?(すえ) he asks you, over and over. The poor man is looking for his wife Sue, and he's searched to the end of the universe. That's true love. As he walks off into the distance, you hear him calling out, "Sue, eh? Sue, eh? Sue, eh?"

sentences: こんなあそびがはやるとは、世も末だな。
If this kind of game is popular, then it’s the end of the world.
おたくのむす子さんは末が本当にたのしみですね。
You must be looking forward to seeing what your son might end up being in the future.
激しい口論の末、末息子は私の金をどこかに埋めるために出て行ってしまいました。
After a heated discussion, my youngest son left to bury my gold somewhere.

mnemonics.meaning: Okay, so this one is really weird, sorry. Each of us only get one body in our lifetimes, right? Well what the heck! What if I want more than one body. Let's all be mad about this together.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because いち is shortened to いっ here!

sentences: 一体どうなっているんだ。
What the heck is going on?
「あいとにくしみはひょうり一体」って、一体全体どういういみなんだ！？
What the heck does, "There's a thin line between love and hate," mean?
一体俺が何をしたって言うんだよ？
What the heck did you say I did?

mnemonics.meaning: The country peoples are the people of your country. They are the people.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 本当に国民はわれわれにさんせいしてくれるのでしょうか。
Will the people really give us their approval?
どうすれば日本国民になれますか。
How do you become a citizen of Japan?
昨夜、PS4の新ゲームを買うために並んでいた国民たちは、凍って死にました。
The people waiting in line for the new PS4 game last night froze to death.

mnemonics.meaning: The now week is this week.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今週は仕ごとがたくさんあります。
There is a lot of work to do this week.
今週の火よう日の午前十一じに、しぶ谷のハチ公前でまち合わせをしましょう。
Let's meet up in front of the Hachiko statue at 11 a.m. this Tuesday.
新しいゲームを４つ買ったので、今週はかなり忙しくなる。
This week is going to be really busy because I just bought four new video games.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a noun version of think. What is "a think"? It's a thought.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading with 考える, just cut off the る!

sentences: いつも自分の考えを上手くせつめいできません。
I can never explain my own thoughts well.
あなたの考えはあますぎます。
Your thoughts are too optimistic.
あなたの考えを百円で買わせてもらえませんか？
Can I buy your thoughts for 100 yen?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  What time is it? It's time to key (とき) your enemy's car. Imagine yourself looking at your watch, waiting until the correct time to perform a synchronized keying of someone's car. Who do you hate the most? Whose car would you like to key?

sentences: れいぼうをつける時は、白いボタンをおしてください。
When you want to turn on the air conditioning, please press the white button.
時がかい決してくれるのをまつしかないよ。
We can do nothing but wait for time to solve this.
幸せな時、いつも時が止まればいいのに、と思う。
Whenever I’m happy, I always think it would be nice if I could stop time.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attach so the verb version is to attach something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this one just fine.

sentences: グリルドチーズにはケチャップを付けるはですか？
Are you one of those people who puts ketchup in their grilled cheese?
どうしてワンちゃんに、ニッカって名前を付けたんですか？
Why did you name your doggy Nikka?
どうして頭に蛭を付けているんですか？
Why are you attaching leeches to your head?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix so the verb version is similar to that, to be fixed. This word is for when something is fixed, but you're not the one fixing it.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to learn the なお part. Think of it this way. Something needs to be fixed. It's urgent! You have to fix it now! (なお). This will also work with the similar word, 直す, which you'll learn soon if you haven't already.

sentences: こしょうした車が直るのはいつですか。
When can I get my broken car fixed?
それでアヤの気げんが直るなら、おれはぜんぜんかまわないよ。
If it makes you feel better, then I don't mind at all, Aya.
農夫の壊れたトラクターは直った。
The farmer’s broken tractor was fixed.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's made up of the kanji for see and right, so what happens when you see the right thing? You manage to come upon what you're looking for or to be found, if you're the one who's lost and you see the right people that are looking for you. Note: This verb is almost always used in the negative form. It is very, very rare for it to be positive. So when you're using it, make sure no one found the thing you're talking about!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: さいふが見当たりません。
I can't find my wallet.
さがしたけど、どこにも見当たらなかったんです。
I looked for it, but couldn't find it anywhere.
俺の老眼鏡が見当たらないんだ。
I can’t find my reading glasses.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji portion means fault, so you would think the verb version is "to fault." It's a little different, though. Think of it this way, if you "fault" something, you're messing up. What's a great way to mess up? By losing something. That's why this word means to lose.  Pretend like you are supposed to hold on to someone's wedding ring. You make the biggest fault of all. You lose it. Ouch.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  So how did you lose the wedding ring anyway? Well... it was eaten by a cow. The 牛 now (うし + なう) has to have it surgically removed. What a mess!

sentences: もうおれには失うものが何もないんだ。
I already have nothing to lose.
トーフグがギャンブルで全ざいさんを失ったというじょうほうは、しんぴょうせいに欠けている。
The information that Tofugu gambled away its entire assets is not reliable.
人生最悪の日は、私がAKB48のフィギュアを失った日です。
The worst day of my life was when I lost my AKB48 Barbie doll.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pass through so the verb vocab version means things like to pass through, to pass, to travel along, and to stop by.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  There's something in front of you that you have to pass through but you can't. It's a wall. In order to pass through it, you decide to kick it as hard as you can to knock it down. Unfortunately, it is way stronger than you, and your toe explodes on contact. You yell: "TOE! OH!" (とお) and then just scream a lot.

sentences: このみちは、ほそくて通りにくいです。
This road is narrow and difficult to pass through.
日本ごがペラペラになるなんてありえないと思うかもしれませんが、それはあたらしい言ごを学ぶだれもが通る道です。
It seems impossible to become fluent in Japanese, but everybody who learns a new language travels along the same road.
お茶会のためのメープルシロップを買うために、カナダを通ってイギリスに行った。
I stopped by Canada on the way to England to get some maple syrup for the tea party.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sunlight, so the verb is to shine or to glitter. Just imagine what happens when sunlight hits things!
mnemonics.reading: Remember how you learned the reading for 光? Well this is almost the same thing. Just change the り to る and you'll know this reading!

sentences: 星がきらきら光っている。
The stars are shining.
右のくつに、光るとりょうが付いてるよ。
You've got some glittery paint on your right shoe.
あそこで確かに何かが光るのを見たんだ。
I’m sure I saw something shining over there.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means teach so the verb vocab version means to teach. It's also used to mean to tell in a more general sense.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Think about your favorite teacher. Now think about them teaching you the following: "Today I'm going to teach you about the ocean (おし)." It is big. Really big. Inside it are krakens, space aliens, and lost cities.  Here is where you continue the lesson in your head, making it the most ridiculous lesson about the ocean you've ever heard. Focus in on the ocean part, since that's the reading, always coming back to it.

sentences: こたえ方を教えてください。
Please teach me how to answer.
ワニカニで日本ごを教える人の中には、「鬼コーチ」はいないよね？
There aren't any "demon coaches" among people who teach Japanese on WaniKani, are there?
皆さん、お早うございます。今日は、皆さんに、茄子を食べることの危険性について教えたいと思います。
Good morning, class. Today I’m going to teach you about the dangers of eating eggplant.

mnemonics.meaning: Town peoples are the townspeople! This can also be singular, so a townsperson.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今すぐ町民をひなんさせるべきです！
The townspeople should find shelter right now!
この町民たちは、みんなちゃんと後かた付けができる。
These townspeople are all able to clean up after themselves.
この町の人達はみんな、この町の町民であることを誇りに思っています。
I feel like all the people in this town boast about being townspeople here.

mnemonics.meaning: Even though it gets mixed up as it passes through itself, modern traffic and transport systems are pretty amazing. This word refers to traffic and transport for pedestrians, bikes, cars, buses, trains, planes... anything that gets us from A to B.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ここでは、交通じこがよくおきるんです。
Traffic accidents happen a lot here.
交通安全のためにシートベルトをしてください。
Please wear your seatbelt for traffic safety.
こうきょう交通きかんに乗れる時はマスクをした方がいいよ。
When you take the public transit system, you should wear a mask.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 三角 means "triangle." Well this means triangle too, but it's the mathematical term. You should use it in math class.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうすれば、三角形のオニギリをにぎれるんですか？
How do you make onigiri into a triangle?
夏の夜空には、天の川をはさんでことざとわしざと白鳥ざの一とう星をむすんだ大三角形が広がります。
A big triangle, consisting of three magnitude stars from Lyra, Aquila, and Cygnus, stretches out in the summer night sky.
そこには、三角形の公園があります。
There is a triangle park there.

mnemonics.meaning: Two bread loaf counters are counting two loaves of bread.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 二斤買えば100円もお得です。
If you buy two loaves of bread it will be 100 yen cheaper.
パンを二斤も焼いたのに、すぐに食べ切ってしまった。
Even though I baked two loaves of bread, we finished it all.
賞味期限が明後日だけど、二斤も食べきれるかな？
Do you think we can finish these two loaves of bread even though they're expiring the day after tomorrow?

mnemonics.meaning: When it's two o'clock and a half what time do you think it is? That would be two thirty.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: そのえいがのかいえん時かんは二時半です。
The film begins at two-thirty.
二時半に大じなやくそくがあるのにねぼうしちゃって、ちょっと今かなりテンパってます。
I have an important appointment at 2:30, but I overslept and now I'm freaking out.
「私は明日午後二時半に、私のお母さんのお父さんの娘の姪っ子に会います。」「なんで、単にお姉ちゃんとランチに行くって言わないの？ありえないんだけど！」
"I’m meeting my mom’s father’s daughter’s niece tomorrow at two-thirty in the afternoon." "Why didn’t you just say you’re meeting your older sister for lunch tomorrow? Jeez!"

mnemonics.meaning: A machine that pumps wind can malfunction and make too much, causing a typhoon. It's a really powerful machine to be able to move that much wind.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Instead of だい for 台 though, this uses the reading たい. Remember it like this: When a typhoon is coming you have to tie (たい) down all of your stuff. Or, you know, if you already know the word typhoon, that's fine too.

sentences: 今回の台風は弱いので、あまり心ぱいしなくてもよさそうです。
This typhoon is weak, so it seems that we don’t have to worry too much.
ひじょうに強い台風トウフ号が、月よう日、西日本に上りくしました。
Strong typhoon Tofu made landfall in western Japan on Monday.
大型の台風が日本列島に近づいています。
A large typhoon is approaching the Japanese islands.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 学生 means "student" and you know that 大学 means university/college. Combine the two and you have a university student / college student.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 男の大学生と女の大学生がはなしています。
A male university student and a female university student are talking.
あの大学生の女せいは、ダイエット中です。
That college girl is on a diet.
マカロニチーズしか食べていないっていうのに、いったいどうして大学生は一日中勉強して夜中中お酒を飲む元気があるっていうんだ？
How do university students have the energy to study all day and drink all night when all they eat is macaroni and cheese?

mnemonics.meaning: You already know 人気 which means "popular." And you also know that 不 means "not." So what do you get when you combine the two? Something that's not popular or unpopular.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今年、もっとも不人気だったアニメは何だと思いますか。
What do you think is the most unpopular anime this year?
コウイチたいマイケルのすもうのし合は、Youtubeで見るとはく力に欠けるので不人気です。
The Koichi vs Michael sumo match is unpopular because it lacks the intensity when you watch it on YouTube.
「お前の母ちゃんに言ってやる」が口癖だったため、彼はクラスメートに不人気だった。
He was unpopular among his classmates because his favorite phrase was, "I’m gonna tell your mom."

mnemonics.meaning: The way of saying something is your way of saying. This could be your accent or simply the way you talk.
mnemonics.reading: You've seen 言う. Let's steal that word's reading. And, you already know 方 and its reading. Combine those together and you have the reading for this word.

sentences: そうは言っても、言い方ってもんがあるだろ！
That makes sense, but you should think about the way you say things!
そうだ、話はかわるんだけど、コウイチのネコって言ばの言い方、めっちゃかわいくない？
Oh, sorry for changing the subject, but don't you think the way Koichi says the word cat is so cute?
あなたの物の言い方はとても馬鹿です。
Your way of saying that is so stupid.

mnemonics.meaning: The think way is really the way someone thinks. That's why this word means way of thinking.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

sentences: 考え方は、人それぞれです。
People have their own way of thinking.
そもそも、父と母は考え方がまったくちがうんです。
My mom and dad's thought processes are totally different to begin with.
自分のことを悪い人間だと思うのは、もし自分が実際に悪女だったとしても、良くない考え方です。
Even if you really are an awful woman, thinking badly about yourself still isn’t a healthy way to think.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of weak? It's also weak.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You just got beaten up because you're weak. Then the bully asks you: "Yo! Why (よわ) you so weak?"

sentences: わたしは、あさに弱いです。
I am not a morning person.
ユイは体は弱いけど、人のいたみがわかる人げんです。
Yui is physically weak, but she is a person who understands others' pain.
インフルエンザにかかると、スーパーマンでさえもとても弱くなります。
Even superman gets really weak when he gets the flu.

mnemonics.meaning: The weak point is your weak point.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ついにアイツの弱点を見つけたぜ！
I finally discovered his weak point!
あの体そうせん手の弱点は、せいかくがじゅうなんせいに欠けているところだ。
That gymnast's weakness is that her personality lacks flexibility.
私の従業員としての弱点は、恐らく弱点が一つも無いことです。
My weak point as an employee is probably that I have no weaknesses.

mnemonics.meaning: The end of the week is the weekend... that is, unless you work on the weekend, but we can't cater to everyone here.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 週末は、おきなわにりょ行に行っていました。
I was in Okinawa over the weekend.
せん週末、雪が十センチつもりました。
We got 10 centimeters of snow last weekend.
宝くじに当たったんだけど、週末ローマにピザでも食べに行かない？
We just won the lottery, so do you want to go to Rome this weekend for pizza?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a good word to know to ask for the time. What is the time? This is how you ask what time it is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 何時のひ行きにのるんですか？
What time will your plane leave?
目まいをかんじはじめたのは何時ですか？
What time did you start to feel dizzy?
今夜何時にボーリングに行くの？
What time are you going bowling tonight?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Do you know the word "kamikaze" from WWII history? Well, it means "divine wind." The "kaze" part is the wind part, and this word uses the same reading, making it かぜ as well.

sentences: 外では、つめたい風がふいていました。
Cold winds were blowing outside.
風が強くなってきましたね。
The wind is picking up, isn't it?
風が彼女のカツラを吹き飛ばした時に、私は自分が坊主の女性にとても魅力を感じることに気が付きました。
When the wind blew the wig off of her head, I realized that I’m really attracted to bald women.

mnemonics.meaning: The year end is the year end aka the end of the year.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: すみませんが、年末は、ちょっとバタバタしてじかんがとれなさそうです。
I’m sorry, but I’ll be super busy around the end of the year and I probably can’t make time for it.
マイケルは、年末にトーフグのだい二えいぎょうぶにいどうになりました。
Michael was transferred to Sales Division II of Tofugu at the end of the year.
年末までには、氷中毒から立ち直れるといいんだけど。
I hope to have gotten over my addiction to ice cubes before the end of the year.

mnemonics.meaning: The yellow color is just the color yellow.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the same as the readings you learned with the kanji meaning you should be able to read this word right off the bat.

sentences: 黄色かみどり色のペンはありますか？
Are there yellow or green pens?
アメリカのカラスは、美しい黄色の羽をもっていることで有名です。
An American crow is well known for the beauty of its yellow wings.
もし尿のいろが透明から黄色に変わってしまったら、もっと水を飲んだ方が良いという合図です。
If your urine changes from clear to yellow, you should drink more water.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is a cage because it's covered on all sides but one (the one open side is where the cage door or gate is). There's nothing inside this cage because there's no gate, and whatever was inside has gotten out. I hope it wasn't rabid...
This is a cape, like the kind a superhero would wear. See how it's hanging to the side? Imagine tying it around your neck and running around so it flies behind you.

This is the radical for cloud. See how the cloud is puffy on the bottom but has two lines up top? That's because a plane flew through it. If humans didn't invent planes, this cloud radical might look different. Really makes you think, huh?

This radical is made up of two slightly different versions of the spoon radical (which you should already know). Look closely at these two spoons. Compare their differences. Like one of those magazines where you compare two similar pictures. But this time it's with spoons.
If you have wings, flying to the sun will be easy. If you try to get there with your wingless, human-body it will not be so easy.

You have a roof on top of what looks like a volcano. What is the roof covering on the top of the volcano? Why, it's definitely covering the hole at the top. I guess someone thought if they built a roof on the volcano hole, none of the lava could come out.
There's a flat line for where the hand was cut off. In it is a hook like a pirate might have. Yarrrr.

Don't confuse this radical with the bird 鳥 radical. It looks similar, with the wing on the bottom and the shape on top, but it doesn't have a feather sticking out of the top of its head and it has a long, thick neck. So while it moves fast like it has wings, it's no bird, it's a horse.
This is a net, spread out over the water. Imagine all the fish you can catch in this net!

Most of this radical is just the rice radical, but the top part is something coming to cut the rice from its stalk. That, my friend, is the sickle. See how the rice is still there? That's because it's in motion. The sickle is literally doing the cutting RIGHT NOW! (And don't confuse this with the grain 禾 radical!)

There's two ways to remember this one. First, you could look at this and see it's a coiled up snake. Or, if you want, you can imagine it as a snake head, with its face facing to the right (see its open mouth?). We may use either when learning a kanji, but for now you can pick the one that fits best with your memorization style. Just make sure you get to snake when you see this radical. *Also note that sometimes the coil isn't totally completed (where it connects in the middle of the vertical line).

You find a hat on the ground with a mouth as the design on the front. You think it looks weird, but when you put it on, you find it suits you quite well. Imagine yourself feeling not so sure about this hat at first. But, once you put it on, you feel pleasantly surprised.

Stick a table on top of a stool and you end up with a very dangerous weapon. Imagine hitting someone with this thing! Or, even better, imagine making someone sit on it. They'd be crushed mentally and emotionally and whatnot. Now that's a scary weapon.

"Does the bamboo shirt suit me?" you ask... but nobody will answer. Shout "PLEASE ANSWER ME!" a few times to get the idea of "answer" in your head. What you really want is an answer, whether it's bad or good, but nobody's willing to say anything because you look so terrible.
mnemonics.reading: You pull out a quarter (こた) and offer it to whoever will give you an answer. With this shiny quarter in your hand, everyone is giving you their answer. Yay for bribery!

mnemonics.meaning: The stool is in the cliff. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty anti society, hiding away like that. Imagine someone who looks super antisocial (and a little feral). Ask them why they're sitting on this stool inside a cliff... they reply because they hate people. They are anti people!
mnemonics.reading: Turns out, when you go to this guy and pull off his beard, he's Han (はん) Solo, the anti-hero from Star Wars! What is Han doing here, so hidden away? He's obviously hiding from Jabba because he doesn't want to get frozen in carbonite again. Make sure you get to the point where you pull this anti-social guy's beard off, to reveal Han Solo beneath. Be surprised... not just because he's Han Solo, but because he's real, too! Maybe you can yell out "Han! Your people need you!"

mnemonics.meaning: A wolverine is going down a slide into your mouth. Why is he going into your mouth, though? You're opening it really wide, because you're screaming "BUDDY!!! You're so excited to see your wolverine buddy-pal again. You thought he was dead. Make sure you feel super happy. Even yell "Buddy" out loud while imagining this wolverine coming at you, if you're not in a quiet-zone.
mnemonics.reading: As you're about to embrace your buddy wolverine, a raccoon tackles the wolverine off the slide, preventing your mouth embrace. "RaCCOON!" you yell. "THIS IS NONE OF YOUR BUSINESS. Get out of here." Feel some hate for the raccoon. He ruined everything.

mnemonics.meaning: Your nation's flag sits on top of a caped mouth. This is the symbol for the "Bureau of Secret Things." It's a special department of your government made to keep things hidden. The cape covering the mouth represents how this bureau never talks about their secrets. The flag represents your country. Think about all the cool secret things the Bureau of Secret Things must have.
mnemonics.reading: The bureau's best-kept secret is cloaking devices that cloak you (きょく) with the press of a button. Now, this mnemonic isn’t perfectly close, but the goal is to get you close enough in your brain so that you can remember きょく later. If you can get to CLOAK YOU, then you can get to きょく much easier than just trying to get there from scratch. So imagine working in this bureau and getting to cloak yourself all the time.

mnemonics.meaning: There are some shellfish in a net that you can buy. You can't just buy loose shellfish. You can only buy the ones that are in the net, bagged up and ready for your money. Imagine looking over a bunch of different kinds of shellfish wrapped in nets. Think about which ones you want to buy.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to buy as many shellfish as you can fit in your car (か). You keep buying until your car is completely full of shellfish before you stop. Cars are totally a realistic unit of measure. Imagine buying an entire car's worth of shellfish. Mmm delicious.

mnemonics.meaning: A rain cloud is still a cloud! It's probably going to rain on you soon though, so I hope you have a jacket or an umbrella. Picture all of the different types of clouds in the sky. There are puffy white ones, heavy dark ones, and wispy thin ones. But they're all clouds.
mnemonics.reading: You lie down and try to figure out what the clouds are shaped like. The first cloud is shaped... like a cool mom (くも). She's wearing high pants, and holding a kid on each hip, but she's also listening to the latest music and using slang. Huh. You look to the next cloud and see... wait, another cool mom? You look at each cloud and each one is a different cool mom. They're each doing different cool mom things. You suddenly don't want to look at the clouds anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: The white ice tree is a magical tree. When you eat its ice flowers it gives you incredible amounts of comfort, ease, and pleasure. Imagine yourself picking the white ice flowers off the tree. Then, put it in your mouth. Make it taste comforting... It puts you at ease. Then, swallow it. Feel your head go nuts with comfort. This is the greatest drug in the world when it comes to comfort. So much pleasure!
mnemonics.reading: You want more of this, You gather as much as you can, and create an entire rack (らく) at your store with this tree. You sell out immediately, and have to refill your rack. Imagine setting up the rack. Make it look beautiful. Shift around the flowers. Fill up the entire rack. Of course, your focus should be on the rack portion.

mnemonics.meaning: In the winter, the woman has to go through all the rice and count each individual grain. Once she's counted all of them, she'll have an amount / number so that she can split them up accordingly. She has to count each grain out in order to divvy up the supply to last through the winter. Imagine yourself getting just a few grains today for food. It's not a good time for you guys :(
mnemonics.reading: Why are you so low on rice? It's because someone sued your farm and took everything you owned. So, you had barely enough rice (or not enough). Come up with a story about why your farm got sued for everything. Go to the court  case. Listen to the judge come up with your verdict. Be angry. This has ruined everything.

mnemonics.meaning: You have at your disposal a tsunami and a hook to assassinate this person. Which weapon will you choose. Decide now! Have trouble with the decision. Which one? Tsunami will be big and cool, but a hook will be more discreet. How can you decide? Can you think of a neat way to decide this, like Two-Face on Batman?
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading けつ we always use the word "ketsup." It's a special mix of ketchup and catsup (yum!) You finally decide. You're going to go with the tsunami... but not just any tsunami. You'll kill him with a tsunami of ketsup (けつ). Get everything ready to take your target down. How will you plan this? Where will you put it? Go ahead and watch your plan unfurl, too.

mnemonics.meaning: Using just thread meeting the paper (with a little ink on the end) you create a masterpiece of a drawing (or a painting). It's unbelievable the kind of drawing you're able to draw with just the tip of a thread. So much detail. So artistic. If it helps, imagine that you drew the Mona Lisa, better than the original, only using this floppy thread tool.
mnemonics.reading: You tell someone that you drew this drawing only using a thread. Their response? "EH?!?!?" (え) Tell a few more people how you drew this. Have them all do the same "Eh!!??" reaction.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of the masters gets the biggest dwelling. She resides in a huge mansion on the top of the mountain, surrounded by all the other masters in their smaller dwellings. Picture the leader master's big, beautiful dwelling. Everyone else is jealous.
mnemonics.reading: She needs this big dwelling so she has somewhere to store all of her jewels (じゅう). Masters always have lots of fancy, expensive things, and she has jewels. Imagine opening the door to the leader master's dwelling and thousands of jewels come pouring out, whisking you off, down the mountain.

mnemonics.meaning: You're standing in the middle of a rice paddy in the rain with an umbrella. You're standing here because there's nothing else that's very tall around you. You want to get hit by electricity (aka lightning) to show that it exists. Get hit by the electricity. How does it feel?
mnemonics.reading: After the electricity hits you, you feel your face. In it is a huge dent. Feel the indent in your face. It doesn't hurt, strangely, but it is pretty huge. Panic about this dent a bit.

mnemonics.meaning: This kanji is just the tree radical three times. Just based off this, you should be able to figure it out. This kanji means "forest." Makes sense, because a bunch of individual trees is what makes up a forest!
mnemonics.reading: One tree? No. Two trees? Not enough. I want more (もり) trees, please! Keep repeating this pattern over and over, continually focusing in on how you need "more" trees to make this forest. For some reason the person working with you only goes up by one at a time, though, so you have to say it a lot (it'll help you to remember, anyways!).

mnemonics.meaning: With top hat power, you're able to help anyone. Imagine putting on your top hat and getting power from it. Then, you use that power to help someone. It's important to make the association that it's the top hat giving you the power to help that person. You're basically Frosty the Snow Man.
mnemonics.reading: The person you help with your top hat power? It's Jo-Anne (じょ). You can imagine saving her however you like. Perhaps she was under a car, and you used your top hat powers to help her out of that situation by lifting it above your head. Note: Jo-Anne is the character we're using with じょ reading mnemonics. She is short compared to Jourm (じょう), the giant farmhand, which is how you'll differentiate the two similar readings.

mnemonics.meaning: The horse radical and the horse kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
mnemonics.reading: You are looking at a horse. It's looking at you. You try making horse noises at it, to get a reaction. Instead of reacting with a normal horse noise, it just makes sheep noises: "Baaa," (ば) it says. "Baaaaa." Feel the shock of this. It sounds just like a sheep, it's strange.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a gate that the sun goes through at a regular interval. There is an interval of time in the sense that the sun goes through it at the same time every day. And there is an interval of space in the sense that it has to go through the space between the gate posts. "Interval" is a weird word to remember, but just think of the sun going around the earth and through the gate like clockwork. Every 24 hours it passes through the gate, and each interval is exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: This method of keeping track of intervals of time was invented by the great Khans of Mongolia, specifically the most famous Khan of all: Genghis Khan (かん). Genghis Khan has had a huge impact on the world as we know it, especially the Eurasian continent of the past, so he's going to come up a lot from now on. Be prepared to get very familiar with him and his friends! Picture Genghis Khan ordering his most skilled inventors and builders to create this special sun gate so they can harness the power of intervals, and all people under his rule can benefit from the accurate telling of time.

mnemonics.meaning: Dirt makes it easy to identify your location. If you know that, you can go from place to place. Imagine looking at the dirt. It's a distinct color and texture, and you're able to identify your location just from that alone.
mnemonics.reading: Knowing your location from dirt is quite a feat! Who taught you that? It was Jourm (じょう), the big local farmhand. Despite being a bit weird, he does really know his dirt and can tell you the place from which any dirt came. Remember Jourm? He's our local farmhand who only has nine toes (from the 上 mnemonic). Imagine that guy explaining to you how to know your location from dirt. He may be a bit clumsy, but the man really does know his dirt.
