Yesterday I had a dream that my house caught on fire.

mnemonics.meaning: A fish shop is a fish shop, a place from which you buy fish. Especially in Japan, very important.
mnemonics.reading: The kun'yomi reading is used for the 魚 (so it's さかな) and the kun'yomi reading is used for 屋 (や). You'll have to use the reading of 魚 from the vocabulary from a couple levels ago to remember the reading of this one.

sentences: 魚屋で金目だいを買ってきたの。
We went to buy splendid red bream at the fish store.
この魚屋のゆかはすべりやすいから気を付けてね。
This fish shop floor is very slippery, so be careful.
あの魚屋さんは百円おまけをしてくれた。
The fish shop gave me a 100 yen discount.

mnemonics.meaning: You want things to depart from your store so you have to sell them. You put all these things up for  sale. You are selling these items.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この夏、Tofuguから、「ベーコンとおこのみやきのチーズタルト」が発売されることが決定しました！
We’ve decided to sell bacon and okonomiyaki cheese tarts from Tofugu this summer.
コウイチのつめのあかをせんじたポートランド名物トーフグ茶がトーフグのウェブサイトででぜっさん発売中です！
Portland's famous Tofugu tea, with the dirt of Koichi's nails, is now on sale on the Tofugu website!
トーフグのデート用抱きまくらが発売されるのが待ち遠しい。
I can’t wait until the Tofugu dating pillows are on sale.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji express. If you want to understand what something is trying to express you usually look at its front or its exterior. This word is usually used for the exterior face of buildings.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're standing in front of a building, staring at its front. You spend some time gazing at it before you realize what it is. "Oh, motel (おもて)", you say aloud. A little time looking at the exterior and you're able to figure it out.

sentences: 表はピンク色にぬってください。
Please paint the front pink.
コウイチの表のかおはトーフグ社長であるが、うらのかおは世界でも有数のジャグリングせん手である。
Koichi's public face is the president of Tofugu, but his private face is the most well-known juggler in the world.
十円玉の表はどちらですか？
Which side of a ten yen coin is the face?

mnemonics.meaning: Your house tools aren't the tools you use to build a house. They're more like the things that are a part of your house that you use like tools. Those things would be your furniture. So, remember, your house tools are just furniture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今週末は、新きょの家具を買いに行く予定です。
I plan to go buy furniture for my new house this weekend.
王女の家具は本当にすばらしいですね！さすがです！
You have such wonderful furniture, Princess! Very impressive.
家具はあなたの家にお運びしましたが、もう少し腰を軽くして扉と窓を早く取り付ける方がいいのではないかと思います。
We moved the furniture to your new house but you should act quickly to get the doors and windows installed.

mnemonics.meaning: The さん on the end is the name honorific さん. It's there to show some respect. It's like saying "Mr. Guest!" or something like that. But that sounds dumb in English. We'll just call this word guest, visitor, or customer. You'll hear this word a lot when you're at a store or you're a customer somewhere in Japan. You are the お客さん, in that situation. Alternatively, you'll also hear お客さま which is a more polite version of this word (because it ends in さま and not さん).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just add the hiragana on the end and you'll be good to go.

sentences: お客さんが入ってくると、このベルがなります。
When customers come in, this bell rings.
東京えきで、お客さんと会いました。
I met up with my guest at Tokyo Station.
お客さんを獲得するにはどうすればいいと思いますか？
What do you think I should do to get customers?

mnemonics.meaning: A guest's room is the guest room (the room you put guests in, duh!).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大すきなアイドルと、ろ天ぶろ付の客室にとまることがゆめなんです。
My dream is to stay in a guest room attached to an open air bath with the idol I love.
このホテルでは全ての客室にコンシェルジュサービスが付いてきます。
In this hotel, all the guest rooms have concierge service.
ちょうど客室のリフォームが終わったところなんですの。是非うちにいらして、ご意見を聞かせてくださいな。
I just finished renovating the guest room. Come over and tell me what you think.

mnemonics.meaning: ハート is of course "heart" and you know that 形 means shape. You've probably already figured this one out. It's heart shaped.  You can add this kanji to all sorts of other things too to say "____ shaped." Give it a try!
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the kanji portion uses the kun'yomi reading. This is kind of like the reading you already learned for 形 just without the ち part. And rendaku happens too, so it becomes がた. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this reading too!

sentences: ネイル用に、ハート形のストーンをさがしています。
I’m looking for a heart shaped stone to use on my fake nails.
クリスティンは、くぎをくわえながら、ハート形のハンマーをふり回していた。
Kristen was swinging a heart shaped hammer around while holding nails in her mouth.
フラミンゴがキスをする時、二羽の頭と首がハート形を描く。
When flamingos kiss, their heads and necks form a heart shape.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of heavy? It's also heavy.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You're lifting something that's really heavy. Oof! You lift it above your head. You're so awesome. You scream: "OH! MORE!" (おも) they put more. You yell it again: "OH, MORE!" and again: "OH, MORE!" Go ahead and act this out wherever you are, pretending like you're holding a couch or two or three over your head, saying "OH MORE!"

sentences: そのにもつは重そうですね。
That luggage looks heavy.
この車、重すぎてうでがもげそう。
This car is so heavy that my arm is about to fall off.
「足を踏んでしまってごめんなさい。」「ちょっと重かったけど、どうってことないよ。」
"I’m sorry I stepped on your foot." "No problem. It was a little heavy, but no harm done."

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen the word 高い from a couple levels ago. This word is related to that. It's like 大きい versus 大きさ, where one describes the other. In this case, the 高さ is the height of something (while 高い is tall). This word isn't "price" though. For that you'd ask いくらですか？ (how much is it?).
mnemonics.reading: Use the reading of 高い (たかい) to help you to learn and remember the reading for this one. They are the same with just the hiragana at the end different.

sentences: あいつのテンションの高さはやばいよな。
His excitement levels are dangerously high, right?
トーフグのサボテンは、1.5メートルの高さにまでせい長しました。
Tofugu's cactus has grown to a height of 1.5 meters.
「この建物の高さについてどう思いますか？少し高すぎますかねえ？」「申し訳ありませんが、分かりません。私には難しすぎます。」
"What do you think about the height of this building? Is it too high?" "Sorry, but I don’t know. It’s over my head."

mnemonics.meaning: You know 高校 means "high school." So, a "life" that does high school is a high school student. This is like how 中学生 are middle school students and 小学生 are elementary school students!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Use the reading of 高校 from before to learn the reading of this word as well, if it helps.

sentences: 今日は、高校生たちが、このパン工場の見学に来ます。
Today, high school students are coming to this bread factory on a field trip.
わたしは高校生の時、毎日のように海に行っては魚をとって食べていました。
When I was a high school student, I would go to the sea every day to catch fish and eat them.
あいつはただの高校生デビューだよ。
He's just trying to look cool because he’s in high school now.

mnemonics.meaning: The only action you should be doing in my house is the housework and my chores. This isn't a hotel. Get moving! Clean my dishes!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 家事、本当にめんどくさいけど、がんばる。
Housework is really annoying, but I’ll do my best.
主人はいつもわたしにばかり家事をおし付けてくるから本当にこまります。
My husband has me do chores all the time and I'm not happy about it at all.
家事全般が苦手なんですよね。
I’m bad at all of the housework.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone asks you what occurrence or what degrees they're really trying to ask you how many times something happened. Sometimes they're asking what temperature it is too.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

sentences: 人生には本当に大切なしゅん間が何度かおとずれる。
We all have really important moments, a few times in our lives.
トーフグは、おなかが空いたサメに食べられそうになったことが何度もある。
Tofugu has almost been eaten by the hungry shark many times.
何度同じことを言えば分かるんだ？
How many times do I have to say the same thing before you understand?

mnemonics.meaning: A big action means something big is going down. This is no ordinary action. It is an action that is important.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大事なのは、きちんとあいさつをすることです。
The important thing is to greet them properly.
日本ごのべんきょうのために、毎日ワニカニにログインしてレビューをするのはとても大事なことです。
Logging onto WaniKani and doing your reviews every day is very important for your Japanese learning.
リラックスする時間をとることは、とても大事だよ。
Taking time to relax is important.

mnemonics.meaning: The Japanese style style. The Japanese often like to think they're very unique and have a very special kind of style (and often times they do). So, you'll hear this word used when someone wants to describe this unique sense of style. Wafuuuu!  Note that this word uses alternative kanji meanings in both of the kanji. They're in the kanji explanation, but they're not the primaries, so it may take a little extra effort to learn this word depending on what you studied!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 和風のあじ付けがすきなんですよ。
I do like Japanese flavors.
かえりにスーパーで、和風ごまドレッシングを買ってきてください。
Can you get Japanese sesame dressing from a grocery store on the way back?
これが和風ホットドッグです。
This is the Japanese style hotdog.

mnemonics.meaning: Japanese style clothes (Japanese Style Clothes). We're talking kimonos and yukata and things like that. Basically, this differentiates Japanese clothing from Western clothing.  What kind of clothes will you wear to the festival tonight? Oh, probably some 和服.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 和服もに合ってるね。
You look good in Japanese style clothes too.
何ちゃく和服をもっていますか？
How many Japanese style clothes do you have?
和服でマラソンをする日本人を見たことがありますか？
Have you seen Japanese people running marathons in Japanese style clothes?

mnemonics.meaning: Japanese style eat ... well, let's change "eat" to "food" and you have Japanese style food. This is a good way to differentiate between an American style restaurant and a Japanese style restaurant. What kind of food you feeling like tonight? Oh, how about some 和食?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 朝ごはんは、和食がいいですね。
Well I like having Japanese style food for breakfast.
アメリカ人の中にもさい近、よう食よりも和食がすきな人がふえている。
There's been an increase in Americans who prefer Japanese cuisine to Western cuisine.
和食イコール寿司ってわけじゃない。
Japanese style food doesn’t always mean sushi.

mnemonics.meaning: A Japanese style room tends to be pretty small. This mainly refers to the kind of room that's covered in tatami mats, though. If you're looking for places to stay in Japan, a 和室 will be something like that. You'll pull the futon out of the closet and sleep on the floor. So comfy, these Japanese style rooms!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 和室でねるのは、これがはじめてです。
This is my first time sleeping in a Japanese-style room.
この和室、ドッグフードとコウイチの足のにおいがまざったようなにおいがしない？
Don't you think this Japanese-style room smells like a mix of dog food and your feet, Koichi?
私のお兄ちゃんは、和室で大きな蜘蛛を飼っています。
My older brother has a huge pet spider in his Japanese-style room.

mnemonics.meaning: The temporary names. These are the kana (that's hiragana and katakana). Why are the "temporary names" kana, though? Perhaps they were never meant to be a main way to write the names of the kanji... They are just a temporary way to write the name of kanji you don't know how to write the "correct" way (aka kanji)? That's just a guess, but it should help you to remember that this word means "kana," at least.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 仮 is the one you learned with the kanji. The 名 portion is not, however, and uses its kun'yomi reading (な), which you saw with the kanji 名 (な). How to remember all this, though? Think of it this way:  The people who made kanji really don't want you to know kana. It's bad for business. They want anyone who uses the word "kana" to suffer, so they decided to make one part on'yomi and another part kun'yomi. Don't let them get you!

sentences: まずは、仮名をかくれんしゅうから始めましょう。
First, let’s begin by practicing writing kana.
ワニカニでかん字をべん強するのに、まずは仮名を全部知っている必要がある。
In order to study kanji on WaniKani, you must first know all of the kana.
この書類の漢字全部に、振り仮名を振ってもらえませんか？
Could you add furigana to all the kanji in this document, please?

mnemonics.meaning: What can you do with empty hands? Karate, that's what. Karate is practiced without weapons, so with empty hands!
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji, and you haven't learned this kun'yomi for 空 yet. As long as you know the meaning, the reading should be easy, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: Karate comes from (から) Japan!

sentences: 大学では空手をやっているんですか。
Are you doing karate at university?
その女の子は空手の先生になりたいと思っていた。
The girl wanted to be a karate teacher.
子どもでも大人でも空手を学ぶことができます。
Both children and adults can learn karate.

mnemonics.meaning: A Life guarantee is something you get on someone else. If their life ends, it's guaranteed with money. That's a life insurance policy, for yah! (A.K.A. life assurance in some parts of the world!)
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 生保はもちろんつみ立てですよね？
Well of course your life insurance is the reserve type, isn't it?
日本ではけんこう保険のせい度が整っているんだから、わざわざ生保に入る必要はあまりないよ。
In Japan, the health insurance system is all-inclusive, so you don't really need to purchase life insurance separately.
日本では、女性の生命保険販売員は「生保レディ」と呼ばれます。
Life insurance saleswomen are called "seiho ladies" in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: A life thing is a living thing, a creature, or an organism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: かわらでなぞの生物を発見した。
A mysterious creature was discovered at a dry river bed.
地きゅう上でもっとも大きい生物はシロナガスクジラではなく、シロナガスフグです。
The largest living thing on the planet isn't blue whale but blue blowfish.
こないだの生物の授業のノート、見せてくれないかな。
Can I see your notes from the other day in Bio?

mnemonics.meaning: The famous thing of an area is their famous product, but it sounds better in English if you say it's the local specialty. When you're traveling around Japan, be sure to be on the lookout for the 名物! It's always fun.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ポートランドの名物は何ですか。
What is Portland’s specialty?
トーフグの名物社長から、東京名物の東京ばななをおみやげにもらいました。
I got Tokyo's famous "Tokyo Banana" from the Tofugu's famous-for-being-unique president.
たこ焼きは絶対に大阪名物の一つです。
Takoyaki is definitely one of the most famous foods in Osaka.

mnemonics.meaning: The needed point is the main point. It's the gist of what you're trying to say.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: もう少し要点をせいりしてからいけんをのべてください。
Please state your opinion after rearranging your main point a bit more.
ユウサクが要点をはあくしているとは思えないんだけど。
I don't think Yusaku got the gist.
いいから！早く要点を言ってよ！
Come on! Get to the point!

mnemonics.meaning: Win, lose... both will happen in tonight's match! What a showdown it will be!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that ふ becomes ぶ because of rendaku here.

sentences: 勝負は引き分けにおわった。
The match ended in a tie.
これは、一発勝負のコンテストです。
This is a contest decided by a single round.
この一年は、勝負の年だと思っています。
I think this is the year things happen for me.

mnemonics.meaning: The action of eating is when you have your meal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今、食事中なので、後でまたかけます。
I’m in the middle of eating a meal, so I’ll call you back later.
どうぞごゆっくりお食事をお楽しみください。
Please relax and enjoy your meal!
もし残りの人生毎日同じ食事しか食べられないとしたら、何を選びますか？
If you could only have one meal every day for the rest of your life, what would you choose?

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 学校 means school. So, people who are in the middle school are in... wait for it... middle school.  And, of course, if you're one of those people that call it junior high school you can do that too.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a combination of 学校 and 中. Really, it's all on'yomi too, so you should be able to read this one. Take note of the がく turning to がっ, though.

sentences: それより、中学校の前でとった写しんがいいよ。
All that aside, you should choose the photo taken in front of the junior high school.
ちょっとまってて。その中学校のば所を今しらべてあげる。
Give me a sec, I'll look up the location of the middle school for you.
ええっと、私は中学校の教師ですよね。そこで、時間を無駄にしないためにも、とりあえず私は絶対に間違ったことを言わない、ということにしておいてください。
I’m a middle school teacher, right? To save time, let’s just always assume that I am never wrong, okay?

mnemonics.meaning: The place that's famous for old roofs. I don't know why, but it's the city of Nagoya. Just associate the two things together and it'll be hard to forget (so long as you've heard of Nagoya before - if not, read up about it!).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji (except for 名 and 屋, which are kun'yomi here). If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. For な just think to 名前 (なまえ) which uses the な reading. The "name" (名前) of this city is what? It's Nagoya. Watch out for rendaku changing こ to ご too.

sentences: 名古屋にはおいしいものがたくさんあります。
Nagoya has a lot of delicious food.
今日も名古屋で仕事があった。
I had work in Nagoya today again.
名古屋にいる友人を訪れた際、矢場とんというとても美味しいトンカツをご馳走してもらいました。
When I visited my friend in Nagoya, I was treated to a delicious pork cutlet called yabaton.

mnemonics.meaning: It's certain that you need it. This thing is necessary. It is needed.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: バスをおりてから、少し歩く必要があります。
I have to walk a little while after getting off the bus.
JETのめんせつに合かくするために必要なことって何ですか。
What is necessary to pass the JET interview?
日本に行ったら必要になるものって何だろう？
What would I need if I went to Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: If you attach things near you, they end up being in the same neighborhood as you. They're attached nearby so they can't go much further.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 付 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your neighborhood is full of fools (ふ). Fools everywhere. You're probably one too, since you live nearby.

sentences: この付近に、コンビニはありますか？
Does this neighborhood have a convenience store?
付近には、外国人見物客もたくさんいました。
There were many foreign viewers nearby as well.
この付近に公衆便所はありますか。
Is there a public restroom in this neighborhood?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of new? It's new.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Your family buys you a new Atari! You're so excited! But wait... what's this? This is no Atari. This is an Atara... a knockoff video game system :(

sentences: 新しいえんぴつですね。
This pencil is new, isn’t it?
じゃあ、あの新しいスタバでね！
I'll see you at the new Starbucks!
あの男、バンジージャンプするのに私の新しいスカーフを使うなんて、信じられない！
I can’t believe he used my new scarf to bungee jump!

mnemonics.meaning: A new year is a new year. Hope you had / have / are having a good one, depending on when you read this.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 新年、明けましておめでとうございます。
Happy New Year!
新年のほうふはもう決めましたか？
Have you decided your New Year's resolution yet?
新年の挨拶に、親戚の家を回りました。
We went around to our relatives houses exchanging New Year’s greetings.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You visit the sea. Strangely, it asks you who is visiting. You're so full of yourself (even in front of the sea/ocean) that you reply: "um, me?" (うみ). Imagine yourself feeling this full of yourself.

sentences: 海で泳ぎました。
I went swimming in the sea.
海の公えんで、先生が学生に話しています。
The teacher is talking to her students in Marine Park.
映画「水の世界」は、実は、海の底に住んでいる超頭のいい魚によって書かれた作品だ。
The movie Water World was actually written by a race of super-intelligent fish that live at the bottom of the ocean.

mnemonics.meaning: The exit that somebody starts from is one's origin, one's hometown, or one's birthplace.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the つ of 出, which becomes っ.

sentences: どこの出身ですか。
Where are you from?
私たちは二人とも中国出身です。
We are both originally from China.
夕べのパーティーに、同じ出身の人がいました。
At the party last night, there was someone from my hometown.

mnemonics.meaning: This word ends in い, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. In fact, it ends in しい, which makes it even more likely it's an adjective. The kanji 苦 means suffering, so what could a related adjective be? This word means painful or agonizing.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Everything is really painful right now. Why? You have something heavy on top of you, crushing (くる) you.

sentences: 食べすぎて苦しい。
I ate too much and it’s painful.
トーフグにあいをこく白できなくて苦しいよ！
I'm agonizing over the fact that I'm not able to confess my love to Tofugu.
正直に言えば、それはかなり苦しい状況だ
To speak frankly, those are pretty agonizing circumstances.

mnemonics.meaning: Your mutual hand is someone else's hands (or just someone else, if you remembered that 手 can also refer to a person as well). Whose hands are these? These are your partner's or companion's hands. That's why everything is mutual. Note that when playing a game, your 相手 is actually your opponent!
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 手, that's no problem for you. For 相, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way:  Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: I (あい) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."

sentences: まずは、相手の話をちゃんときいてあげようよ。
First, you will listen closely to what your partner has to say.
うらないによると、わたしのけっこん相手はどこかの国の王子さまだそうです。本当かな？
According to my fortune, my future partner is a prince in some country. I wonder if it's true.
馬鹿な話し相手は欲しくない。
I don’t want a stupid talking companion.

mnemonics.meaning: The flat peace. This is a peace that will last, because there's no waves... no ripples... just flat. This is plain old peace.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: いつになったら、世界は平和になるんだろうか。
So when do you think the world will find peace?
安全で平和な地いきに住みたいです。
I want to live in a safe and harmonious community.
どうして日本ではみんなあの平和のシンボルを写真にかざすの？
Why does everyone in Japan use the peace sign in pictures?

mnemonics.meaning: Something has been determined beforehand. What is this thing? This action? It is a plan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ねえ、日よう日、予定を入れてもいい？
Hey, can I make plans on Sunday?
その小わく星は地きゅうに向かっていて、北大西ようのどこかにしょうとつする予定だ。
The asteroid is on a direct path to Earth and is estimated to hit somewhere in the North Atlantic Ocean.
私がせっかく予定を立てても、誰もその通りに動いてくれないことが嫌です。
I hate when I schedule out my day, but nobody follows the script.

mnemonics.meaning: Part of a part? That's a portion, a section of that part, and even a part in itself!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

sentences: この部分は、何色にしますか？
What color do you want for this part?
のうの前の部分の名前って何だっけ？
What was the front part of the brain again?
この映画、共感出来る部分だらけでめちゃくちゃ泣けた。
The movie was full of parts I sympathized with and I cried all over myself.

mnemonics.meaning: Attach this word onto the end of a prefecture place name and you have the prefecture portion of _____ prefecture. These are a lot like states or provinces.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's always attached to things (so it's like jukugo). Don't write the 〜 when you're writing in the answer, just the けん portion, and you'll get this one correct.

sentences: 何県の出身ですか。
What prefecture are you from?
なら県の小学校では、せい服をきないといけない学校が多いです。
There are many elementary schools in Nara that require students to wear uniforms.
今まで日本の何県に行ったことがあるの？
Which prefectures in Japan have you been to?

mnemonics.meaning: The sound that departs from your mouth is you talking. Imagine yourself saying things and words departing your mouth. They are bent in different ways and have different colors, highlighting your pronunciation of certain words and phrases.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このたんごの発音を教えてください。
Please teach me the pronunciation of this word.
タイラーさんは日本ごの発音がとても上手ですね。
Taylor, your Japanese pronunciation is so good.
わあ！スペイン語の小さな家って言葉の発音、日本語の「お腹すいた」にめちゃくちゃ似てる！
Wow, the pronunciation of the Spanish word "una casita" sounds similar to "I’m hungry" in Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: Picture the part of your body that makes up your neck. Are you picturing it? That's a building block that makes up your body. A really important one. If you didn't have that neck, you wouldn't look like a person at all. Sound familiar? It should! Because that part of your neck is a radical! Just like part of your neck is a building block of your body, the radical is a building block of kanji. Get it? I sure hope so!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 首 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you need a radical to make a new kanji, you just press a button and the radical comes tumbling down the radical chute (しゅ). There's definitely no rhyme or reason to radical picking, it's just whatever pops out of the ol' chute.

sentences: このかん字の部首は何ですか？
What is this kanji’s radical?
部首をわらうものは部首になく。
Someone who laughs over radicals will eventually cry over radicals.
私は全部の部首を覚えています。
I remember all of the radicals.

mnemonics.meaning: The action of returning. That is a reply or a response.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: まだ返事をおくっていません。
I haven’t responded yet.
出せきのお返事、ありがとうございます。
Thanks for your RSVP.
私は、お金が欲しいというメールを百通以上ビル・ゲーツに送りましたが、まだ返事をもらっていません。
I sent Bill Gates over one hundred messages about giving me money, but he still hasn’t replied.

mnemonics.meaning: The peoples who make their dwelling here are the residents.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 市はひなん所をかいせつして、住民にひなんをよびかけています。
The city established a shelter and appealed to the citizens to take refuge.
住民たちは、みんなすぐに打ちとけました。
The residents got along with each other right away.
あのアパートの住民には無料のエアコンが与えられるが、何故か冬の間だけなのである。
The residents of that apartment are given free air-conditioning, but only in winter for some reason.

mnemonics.meaning: When you hold on and preserve something you are doing the act of retention or maintenance on it. This is preservation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: コウイチは何かの世界記録保持者だと聞きました。
I heard that Koichi is some kind of world-record holder.
かくへい器の保持についてどうお考えですか？
What do you think about the retention of nuclear weapons?
トーフグは、火星の治安を保持することに、微力ながら貢献したいと思います。
Tofugu will contribute our humble efforts to maintain Mars peace.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a part of a roof, that part is your room. Just imagine a roof divided into sections in a house, with the sections going all the way down to the ground. Each section is its own room, right?
mnemonics.reading: The reading is kind of an exception. The 屋 is normal (や) but the 部 is weird. It is へ. Just imagine that you rent out a room and the only one they have is just the hay (へ) room in the barn, so you sleep there for the night. Imagine the smell of hay and how scratchy it is to sleep in this room.

sentences: 妹は部屋のそうじをしました。
My younger sister cleaned the room.
わたしの学校には、音楽室の中に夜だけにあらわれる部屋があるそうです。
I heard that there is a room that only appears at night in the music room of my school.
部屋を片付けようとすると、いつも途中で見つけた別のものに気を取られてしまって、片付けることができません。
I can’t clean my room because whenever I try I just get distracted by all the stuff I find.

mnemonics.meaning: Go ahead and try an eat. How was that little try? That little sample? That little taste?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 文句を言う前に、試食してみてよ。
Try a sample before you complain about it.
コウイチの昔なつかしいソフトクリームチーズ商店の試食会におよばれしました。
I was invited to the sample party for Koichi’s Old-Timey Soft Serve Cream Cheese Emporium.
スーパーで試食販売をしている人は、日本の食品業界では「マネキンさん」と呼ばれる。
The person who offers food samples in grocery stores is called "Ms. Mannequin" in the Japanese food industry.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A star is just a whole sheep (ほし) floating in the sky. If it wasn't a whole sheep, it wouldn't shine so brightly and you wouldn't be able to see it from Earth. Don't let anyone tell you stars are made of gas. The whole thing is sheep, okay?

sentences: 夜には、星がとてもきれいでした。
That night the stars were really pretty.
今夜はたくさんながれ星が見れるといいんですが。
I hope we can see a lot of shooting stars tonight.
お父さん、どうして今日は星型のメガネをかけているの？
Dad, why are you wearing star-shaped glasses today?

mnemonics.meaning: You'll see this attached to other words... like "meat" or "fish." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ store, making this word mean store (same as the kanji).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

sentences: 近くにくすり屋と肉屋もあります。
There is a pharmacy and a butcher shop nearby too.
王女にてんしょくする前は花屋ではたらいていました。
Before I changed my job to being a princess, I was working at a flower shop.
焼肉屋さんを経営している人と結婚するのが夢です。
It’s my dream to marry someone who owns yakiniku restaurants.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji itself means temporary. When you add the に, we're asking you to imagine a situation temporarily, so the meaning changes to supposing or if.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is kun'yomi, so here's a mnemonic to remember it:  If you don't mind, could you carry (かり) this for me? Supposing it's not too much trouble, of course.

sentences: 仮にコウイチが『トーフグはめすだ』と言っても、多くのユーザーはそのいけんに反対するんじゃないだろうか。
Even if Koichi said, "Tofugu is female," I believe many users would have opposing opinions.
仮にトーフグにさいあくのじたいがおきたとしたら、ライフタイムメンバーの人たちはどうなるんですか？
Supposing the worst were to happen to Tofugu, what would happen to lifetime members?
え？あの娘の胸は風船で作られているって？仮にそうだとしても、だから何なんだよ！
What? Her boobs are made of balloons? Supposing that were true, who cares?

mnemonics.meaning: A certain win sounds like a great thing. When these two kanji are put together, a certain victory is inevitable.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the つ in ひつ is turned into a small っ, though.

sentences: じん社で必勝をきがんしてきました。
I prayed for certain victory at a shrine.
空手のし合で、「必勝」とかかれたハチマキをしている人を見ました。
I saw a person wearing a headband that said "Sure Victory" at the karate match.
もし虎と七面鳥が戦争することになったら、それはもう虎の必勝になるだろうね。それから、ついでに、養鶏所で働く人も喜ぶだろうね。
If tigers were to go to war against turkeys, it would mean certain victory for the tigers. Chicken farmers would be happy, as well.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji swim, so it means swimming.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: マイケルは魚よりも泳ぎが上手です。
Michael's swimming is better than the fish's!
カエルの泳ぎにあこがれて必死に平泳ぎをれんしゅうしていたら、手と足がほそ長くなりました。
I admired frogs' swimming so I frantically practiced the breaststroke until my arms and legs got longer.
泳ぎはあまり得意ではありません。
I’m not very good at swimming.

mnemonics.meaning: When you accept a test you are taking an exam or taking a test. Good luck! A++++!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 兄は来年大学受験です。
My older brother is going to take university entrance exams next year.
最近は、毎日朝から晩までずっと受験勉強をしています。
I've been studying to take the exam from morning to night every day lately.
私は受験票を持って行くのを忘れてしまいましたが、母が届けてくれました。
I forgot to take the exam admission slip, but my mom dropped it off for me.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji teach. So it means teaching.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 教える, so you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: あなたは、父さんの教えをしっかりまもって生きるのよ。
You keep my father’s teachings alive and well.
それはすばらしい教えですね。
It's such a great lesson, isn't it?
君の教えに従うと、ろくなことがない。
When I follow your teachings nothing goes well.

mnemonics.meaning: A tea shop is a tea shop. Mmm, delicious, delicious tea.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ポートランドでは、トーフグ茶屋の、ふぐもちが人気です。
The Tofugu tea shop in Portland has popular fugu mochi.
きょうとにりょ行したとき、コウイチは毎ばん茶屋あそびを楽しみました。
When Koichi traveled to Kyoto, he enjoyed teahouse entertainment every night.
日本人は現代的なカフェを「カフェ」、昭和の香りのするコーヒーラウンジを「喫茶店」、伝統的なお茶屋さんを「茶屋」と呼びます。
Japanese people call modern cafes "Cafe," slightly old fashioned coffee lounges "Kissaten," and traditional tea shops "Chaya."

mnemonics.meaning: The generations (and society!) that make up the world create our world. So this is the World, society, or the Universe.　 This word is used more like "the biggest dog in the world" or "the fattest cat in the world." For example, you'll hear words like 世界一番 (number one in the world) thrown around a lot.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: しかし、この世界にはどちらもありません。
However, neither of them exist in this world.
ふじ山は世界いさんにとうろくされています。
Mt. Fuji is registered as a World Heritage Site.
あいつは自分の世界に閉じこもっていて、そこから出てこようとしないんだ。
He lives in his own world and doesn’t want to leave it.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Additionally on top of thing there are the meanings matter and action as well. Like the kanji, this word has to do with action things... things that you do, for example, rather than physical things.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  It's hard to start a mnemonic with the word "thing" or "action," so let's continue off the kanji mnemonic where you've put a cross in the mouth of a wolverine.  Why did you do it? You knew that feisty wolverine was going to eat your coat (こと).

sentences: スモモさんが、ピンク色のいしょうをきる事が多いのはなぜですか？
Why do you think Ms. Sumomo wears so many pink clothes?
後はいが言っている事がいつもよく分からなくてこまっています。
I often have trouble understanding what my junior colleague is saying.
すまないが、ちょっと今はする事がたくさんあって、忙しいんだ。
I’m sorry but I’ve been busy recently because I have a lot of things to do.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Besides thing, it has the related meanings of object and item.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: What game has the most things in it? Monopoly (もの). You can choose from a bunch of random things to play as, you know? And no one actually knows what those things are. What's a thimble anyway? Just call it a thing.

sentences: マサルさんが持っている物は何ですか。
What is that thing Masaru has?
うちのワンちゃんを物あつかいしないでください！
Don't treat my dog like a thing!
私の好きな物を三つ挙げるなら、チキンと揚げ物とご飯です。
My three favorite things are chicken, fried foods, and rice.

mnemonics.meaning: In the now occurrence you'll learn your kanji, no? This word means this time. Despite being "this time" it has the feeling of next time, though. It's like saying "okay, this time we'll get it" where "this time" really means "next time," making it a little bit different from 今回.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: じゃあ、やっぱり今度にしよう。
Okay, then let’s do it next time.
今度は本当に本気の本気で日本ごをべんきょうします！
I'm really, really serious about studying Japanese this time.
今度俺がお前を泣かせる時は、嬉し泣きだ。
The next time I make you cry it will be because you are happy.

mnemonics.meaning: You know what 千円 is (1000 yen). So if you add a bill to that you get a thousand yen bill. That's just the little rectangular piece of money that is worth 1000 yen.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 千円札のおつりが不足しています。
I don’t have change for a thousand yen bill.
これは、水そうから紙のひしゃくで千円札をすくうゲームです。
This is a game in which you scoop thousand yen bills with a paper scoop from a water tank.
「千ドル札を燃やしてるの？」「いや、ただの千円札だよ。」
"Are you burning a thousand dollar bill?" "No, it’s just a thousand yen bill."

mnemonics.meaning: You know that the word 付ける means "to attach" and you know that the kanji 付 means attach. So, this word probably has something to do with attaching. This is the intransitive version, though, where something is attached (and you're not doing the attaching). You can use the く as a hint. You see something attached on the wall. You say "Coo'"
mnemonics.reading: The reading can be derived from 付ける, a word you should have seen a few levels ago. If you know that word's reading you should be able to figure out this word's reading as well (and vice versa).

sentences: 今このパソコンを買うと、オマケが付くので、おとくですよ。
If you buy this computer now, you’ll get something thrown in, so it’s a deal.
マイケルのTシャツにはドレッシングのしみがたくさん付いています。
Michael's t-shirts have a lot of salad dressing stains on them.
あなたの耳たぶに付いてるそれ、何？
What’s that thing attached to your earlobe?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means both music and bend. In the case of this word, we're looking at "bend." So, the verb form of bend is to be bent. This is when something bends on its own, not when you're doing the bending. It's just bending.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Something, let's say a road, starts out straight. But, with some magic, a witch causes it to curve.

sentences: 三つ目のしんごうを、右に曲がってください。
Please turn right at the third light.
そのカレー色のネクタイ、ちょっと曲がってるよ。
Your curry colored necktie is a bit crooked.
野球のボールが当たってから、僕の小指はちょっとだけ左に曲がっています。
Since getting hit with a baseball my pinky finger bends slightly to the left.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means lack, and this verb has several meanings related to that. It can mean to be lacking, like "imagination is really lacking in this movie." It can also mean to not be present, like when you realize your Japanese teacher is missing. When talking about something like a tea cup or your teeth, it can mean to get chipped. I guess if you chip a teapot it is lacking in...perfection?
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Something is lacking... it's a car (か). You can't stop thinking about this because you have to walk 40 miles to get to your destination. If only that car wasn't missing, this would be easier. Imagine the sweat... the pain... the thirst... all because that car's not present.

sentences: 自てん車でこけて、前ばが欠けてしまった。
I fell off my bike and chipped my front teeth.
その予定は確実性に欠けています。
That plan is lacking in reliability.
私には、セーラームーンを見るのを止めるための強い意志が欠けている。
I lack the willpower to stop watching Sailor Moon.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means express and the verb vocab version is transitive, meaning that it's done to something. So this verb means to express something or to show something.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're trying not to say it directly, but trying to figure out how to express something. That something is that you are a wuss (あらわす). Sorry, had to be expressed.

sentences: でも、ろこつに不かいかんを表すのはよくないよ。
But it’s not okay to express your discomfort so bluntly.
国民はみんな、高がくのぜい金に不まんを表していますよ。
All citizens are expressing some dissatisfaction with the high tax.
このアップルシナモンウィスキーがどれだけ美味しいかを言葉で表すことはできない。
I can’t begin to express how good this apple cinnamon whiskey is.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 付ける means "to attach" and that 見 means "see." So, when you attach your seeing to something, it's like you're looking around trying to find something. When you find what you're looking for, imagine your eyeballs flying out and attaching to that item, then yelling "I FOUND IT!" You'll usually see this word with the 付 in kana, so 見つける.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 見る and 付ける. If you use those readings, you'll be able to read this word too.

sentences: むしさされって、見付けるととたんにかゆくなるよな。
The moment you find a bug bite it makes you itchy, don't you think?
このぼう子は、コウイチのかつらを見付けるための手がかりになるかもしれません。
This hat might help us find Koichi's wig.
私は今朝、虹の端にあると言われている金の壺を見付けるために四時間以上も費やしました。
I spent over four hours this morning trying to find the pot of gold that they say is at the end of the rainbow.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hold and the verb version is to hold something, to carry something, to own something, or to keep something. This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You hold something, like chopsticks, have something, like power, or keep something, like your friend's book over the weekend.
mnemonics.reading: If you try to hold something in your hand long enough it will mold (も). And then that mold will cover your hand, then your arm, then your entire body. Basically, you should never hold anything for too long or you'll become a mold person.

sentences: あらきさんは、けしゴムを持っていますか？
Do you have an eraser, Araki?
コウイチは、実はなんしきやきゅうしんぱん員のしかくを持っています...というのは実はうそです。
Actually, Koichi has a license to be a soft baseball referee ...actually, that's a lie.
一等に当選したことを知った時、宝くじを持つ手の震えが止まらなかった。
When I realized I won the grand prize, the hand I was holding the lottery ticket with couldn’t help but shake.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that the kanji means mix and the word 交ぜる means "to mix," so it probably has something to do with that. This word means to intersect, which is kind of like mixing. When two things intersect with each other, they're getting mixed up, so that's where this word gets its meaning.  To remember that this one means "to intersect," remember the わ as walk. You're walking around, and then you intersect with some people on the street.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is almost the same as 交ぜる which you should be familiar with by now. It has the ま but it also has an extra じ in there. That じ is there because you intersect with a group of mages (まじ) that catch you on fire as you walk past.

sentences: オレンジとあい色が交わる、夕ぐれの空が大すきなの。
I love the evening sky when orange meets indigo blue.
このオフィスでは、時々、日本とアメリカの文化が交わります。
In this office, Japanese and American culture sometimes intersect.
婆ちゃんの乳はとても長いので、たまに相互に交わることすらできる。
My grandma’s boobs are so long that they sometimes cross over each other.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 通る means to pass, but this is a little different. You aren't the one passing, Sue (す) is. So you have to let Sue pass. In other words, this verb is transitive, meaning it has an object. That's why it means to let something pass or to put something through. The way this verb is translated into English changes a lot depending on the noun it's paired with. For example 火を通す is literally "to let the fire pass through", and means "to heat through". 針に糸を通す is literally "to put thread through a needle", so means "to thread a needle".
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 通る. Switch the る for a す and you'll be all set!

sentences: ガラスは光を通します。
Glass lets light pass through it.
お肉には、しっかり火を通してください。
Please heat the meat thoroughly.
針に糸を通すのは難しい。
Threading a needle is difficult.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lose so the verb vocab version means to lose.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You lose your tournament/soccer game/whatever (you decide something applicable to you). You're sad about this. Who's there to comfort you? Your Ma (ま). She's a nice lady.

sentences: すきなチームが負けたので、くやしいです。
My favorite team lost, so I’m frustrated and heartbroken.
食パンマンは、アンパンマンに、チェスでこてんぱんに負けました。
Breadman was badly defeated in a chess game by Anpanman.
「今夜は、どこで食事したい？」「あなたが決めてよ。私はじゃんけんに負けたんだから。」
"Where do you want to eat tonight?" "It’s your call. I lost the rock-paper-scissors."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means need and the verb vocab version is to need. This one's a little tricky, because although it's usually translated as "to need" in English, it's used more like to be needed or to be necessary. That is, it's an intransitive verb in Japanese, so it doesn't take a direct object.
mnemonics.reading: Since the reading isn't like the one you learned, think about what you are going to need... like, what you're really going to need, more than anything. Then, think of an eagle, because you really need an eagle. You'll need to come up with the reason why you need an eagle though, so hopefully it's a good one.

sentences: 玉ねぎとトマトと大こんが要ります。
You need onions, tomatoes, and daikon.
ふくろは要りますか？
Do you need any bags?
要るものと要らないものをリストに書き出しなさい。
Write out a list of things you do and don’t need.

mnemonics.meaning: The tools you use on the road of life are important to have. What is your most important tool?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これが、ロブさんがかりたいと言っていた道具です。
This is the tool that you told me you wanted to borrow, Rob.
ドラえもんの道具の中で一番使ってみたい道具は何ですか。やっぱりどこでもドアですか？
Out of all of Doraemon's tools, which one would you want to use the most? Obviously the Anywhere Door, right?
昨日買った道具入れの中に、なんとベイブ・ルースのルーキーカードが一枚入っていたんだ！
I bought a tool pouch yesterday that had a Babe Ruth rookie card hidden inside it.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means preserve and the verb vocab version is to preserve something, to keep something, or to maintain something. This is a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. You preserve something, like your youth.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you want to learn how to preserve something like fruits and veggies, you should start with tamots (たも), that's slang for delish tomatoes. Once they're preserved, you get to make everyone you love eat those yummy tamots. Mmm!

sentences: わかさを保つひけつは何ですか？
What's the secret to preserving your youth?
ビエトのおかげで、コウイチはメンツを保つことができた。
Thanks to Viet, Koichi was able to maintain face.
あのお医者さんに、「体調を保つためには、日々の運動が大切だよ」なんて言われたけど、そのお医者さん自体がすっごく太ってるんだよね。
The doctor told me that it’s important to exercise regularly to maintain your physical health, but he is so fat.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means receive, and this verbs means just about the same thing: to receive something! This is a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. You receive something, like an education.
mnemonics.reading: You want to receive something more than anything else in the world. It's a ukelele (うけ), of course. Then you can live your Hawaiian paradise fantasy... after you learn to play of course. By the way, you better say ukelele the correct way, like "ooh kay lay lay," not the Anglicized way!

sentences: しけんを受ける人は、13:00までに大学の受付に来てください。
If you’re taking the exam, please come to reception at the university by 13:00.
トーフグの言ばをまともに受ける必要はないよ。
You don't have to take Tofugu's word as is.
僕の手は他の人のよりも15倍も大きいけど、それでも野球ボールをうまく受けることができないんだ。
Even though my hands are fifteen times larger than anyone else’s, I still can’t catch a baseball very well.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return so the verb version means to return something.  This is more like "to return a thing" rather than returning home, which would be 帰る, a word you haven't seen yet (but will soon, I'm sure!).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to return the Car egg (かえ) you found on the side of the road. It will birth a little car, but it needs its mother. So, you try to figure out how to return it. Go ahead and think through that process in your mind. Also think about how weird a car egg would be.

sentences: 今日、としょかんに本を返しに行かなくちゃいけないんです。
Today I have to go to the library to take back a book.
返す言ばが見当たらないよ。
I have nothing to say back to you.
「昨日あげたクッキー返してくれない？」「えっ、吐きだせってこと？」
"Could you return the cookies I gave you yesterday?" "Huh? You mean, I should throw them up?"

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ride so the verb vocab version means to ride.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. Enjoy the ride!

sentences: バスに乗って、海へ行きました。
I took a bus to go to the sea.
東京・しな川方めん行きではなくて、上野・池ぶくろ方めん行きに乗ってください。
Make sure you take the train headed to Ueno and Ikebukuro and not Tokyo and Shinagawa.
ジェットコースターに乗るのは大好きなんだけど、どの席もいつもゲロ臭いんだよね。
I love to ride on roller coasters but they always smell like vomit.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sell, so the verb version of that is to sell something.
mnemonics.reading: You want to sell something, but what? What can you sell that will take the least amount of work? Uni (う)! They're just hanging out in the ocean, ready for the taking. Go scoop some up, watch out for the pointy bits, and sell them for some quick cash!

sentences: ここに、日本ごのじしょは売っていますか。
Are Japanese dictionaries sold here?
この村では、人々は大麦を売って生けいを立てています。
In this village, people make a living by selling barley.
請求書の支払いをするために車を売る必要があるが、そうすれば今度は仕事にいけなくなってしまう。
I need to sell my car to pay the bills, but if I do that I won’t be able to get to work.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means send, and the the vocab verb version is to send something. If the object of this verb is a person, it means "to send" in the sense of to escort someone, maybe to the station, or to the door.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You need to send an entire oak (おく) tree in the mail, but it's too big. Imagine yourself dragging one to the post office. They tell you that you can't send that here... Go to the oak sending facilities.

sentences: スミスさんに手紙を送りました。
I sent a letter to Mr. Smith.
後で写しんLINEで送るね。
I'll send you the photos later on LINE.
遅くなったね。今日はここまでにしよう。家まで送るよ。
It’s getting late. Let’s call it a day. I’ll walk you home.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swim so the verb vocab version is to swim.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana sticking out?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ここで泳いではいけません。
Do not swim here.
あんた、目が泳いでるよ。
Hey, your eyes are shifty.
私はベッドの上にある見えないプールで泳いで運動しているんです。
I exercise by swimming in an invisible pool on my bed.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means try so the verb vocab version is to try to do something or to attempt something. This verb is transitive, meaning it takes a direct object. Here, the direct object is whatever it is that you're trying to do.
mnemonics.reading: You know how when you try to do something you put your whole heart into it? Well, think of that in Japanese. You put your whole 心 (こころ) into it.

sentences: ビエトに言われた方法を五度試みたんですが、ダメでした。
I've attempted the method that Viet told me about five times, but it never worked.
ビエトの手下が、けいむ所からのだっ走を試みたらしい。
Apparently Viet's follower tried to escape from prison.
トーフグは、常に新しい事を試みる人を探しています。
Tofugu is looking for someone who always tries to do something new.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means use so the verb version is to use. If you're talking about money, this can also mean to spend.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Two cars (つか), are what you have to use because you're so huge you don't fit into one. You've got a British car on your left and an American car on your right, and you're driving them both at the same time.

sentences: 友だちのじしょを使いたいです。
I want to use my friend’s dictionary.
いたいのはとても苦手なので、ますいを使ってください。
I'm not good with pain, so please use anesthetics.
そんなに屁っ放り腰にならないで！知ってる日本語をできるだけ使うようにしなよ。
Don’t be afraid of that. You should use the Japanese you know as much as possible.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means win so the verb version is to win.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What did you just win? You won a new car (か)!

sentences: サッカーのし合では、1対0で勝つことができました。
At the soccer game, we managed to win 1-0.
四才の時に、し合には勝ったが勝ぶに負けた。
When I was four, I won the match but I felt like I lost anyway.
明日のドッグ・レースにペットのウサギの参加を申し込むつもりなんだけど、確実に勝てると思うんだよね。
I’m entering my pet rabbit in tomorrow’s dog race and I guarantee it's going to win.

mnemonics.meaning: The truth behind someone's strength is their true strength. It is also their true ability.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチのフラダンスの実力は本物です。
Koichi's hula dancing abilities are genuine.
ビエトが本気の実力を出した所を見た人はまだだれもいません。
There is no one who has witnessed Viet's true power yet.
運も実力のうちってよく言うだろ。
They usually say, "luck is what you make of it."

mnemonics.meaning: The action of truth is just truth itself, though it's also facts and reality as well. Really, it's the idea of "truth" in a way.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 事実かもしれないけど、なっとくはできないな。
That may be true, but I'm still not convinced.
あのせいじ家の言っていることは、事実に反します。
What that politician has been saying contradicts the facts.
口髭を生やした男が気味悪く見えるのは、科学的な事実です。
It is a scientific fact that a man with a mustache looks creepy.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the on'yomi reading, same like you learned with the kanji. That is the truth, I promise.

sentences: 実は、わたし、こうみえてもオリンピックに出たことがあるんです。
Well actually, even though I don’t look like it, I used to be an Olympian.
実のところ、おれたちはお前の実のおやじゃないんだよ。
To tell you the truth, we are not your real parents.
すまない、お前。実は、俺達の貯金を全部、プロ野球カードと風船ガムにはたいちまったんだ。
I’m sorry, Honey. The truth is I spent all of our savings on baseball cards and bubblegum.

mnemonics.meaning: Something you use that has a use has... well, use. You can even use it for practical applications.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このクーポンの使用の仕方が分かりません。
I don't know how to use this coupon.
明日、九時から会ぎ室を使用したいんですが、空いていますか？
I want to use the meeting room at nine tomorrow. Is it available?
「へー！使用人って被雇用者のことも言うんだ。てっきり召使いって意味だと思ってた。」「そうだよ。使用者も、利用者だけじゃなくて雇用主って意味もあるしね。」
"Oh! Shiyounin is used for an employee too? I always thought it just meant servant." "Yup. And shiyousha not only means user, but employer too."

mnemonics.meaning: A weak insect. This is what people call weaklings in Japan. This is a good word to know if you're a bully, or something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is a weird one. It uses the kun'yomi readings for both, meaning you'll have to pull your knowledge of the word 弱い from earlier and apply it here. 虫 should be okay, though, as this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, only weak bugs use kun'yomi, and that weak bug is you in this instance.

sentences: あんなに弱虫でなき虫だったむす子も、もう一人前の大人です。
My son, who was such a weakling and a crybaby, is already an adult.
多くのアメリカ人はなっとうごときが食べられない弱虫です。
Many Americans are cowards who can't even eat a bit of natto.
弱虫毛虫は、挟んで捨てろ！
Cowards should be treated like hairy caterpillars - picked up and thrown out!

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is double weak is probably pretty weak. You also know that this is an adjective because it ends with い. You know that 弱い is weak, so it probably isn't that. Instead, this one is weak looking or frail. If you know the grammar らしい you can kind of use that as a hint. The しい on the end reminds me of らしい which is like "seems to be." So, "seems to be weak" = "weak looking."
mnemonics.reading: The reading is double kun'yomi, as you can probably guess due to all the hiragana involved. So, you double up on よわ and then add the しい to read this vocabulary word.

sentences: なんか、弱々しいうたごえだったから、ちょっと心ぱいになっちゃった。
I was starting to worry about you because you had such a weak singing voice.
むかしは強く見えた父が年とともにだんだん弱々しく見えてきました。
My father, who used to look strong, gradually began looking weaker year after year.
その弱々しい患者は河豚の毒で苦しんでいた。
That weak looking patient is suffering from puffer fish toxins.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who wins is the winner / victor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 勝者だけが次のステージにすすめます。
Only the winner will advance to the next stage.
せんそうに勝者はいないのですから、どうかそんなむいみなたたかいは止めてください。
There are no winners in wars, so please stop such a meaningless fight.
ビエトは、72時間耐久スクラブルゲームの勝者となった。
Viet emerged the victor in the 72 hour Scrabble game.

mnemonics.meaning: See the west radical on top of the mouth radical? Think of the mouth of someone from the wild west (like in a cowboy movie). What is always in their mouth? It's alcohol.

This radical has a pod (the square in the middle) between the ground and some roots. That pod is going to turn into a plant someday. What plant will it be? Great big beans, like the ones from Jack and the Beanstalk.
This is a tree with something wrapped around its middle, holding it tight. If you unwrapped that middle part you'd realize it's actually a bunch of trees tied in there. It's a bundle of trees!

Why is your husband putting flowers in his mouth? It's because he's Chinese. It's just something they do over there, you explain. Tea is flower water, this isn't that weird. Chinese people just thought of doing it first.
Doesn't this radical look like one of those old-fashioned dynamite plunger things that gets pushed to set the fuse? That makes this dynamite!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means fault.

This radical consists of a shellfish with a leaf on it. What is it? The mysterious geoduck. It's a very distinct clam-like creature. If you don't know what a geoduck is, look it up. It's quite bizarre. It has a long, leaf-shaped protrusion coming out of its shell body.

When you combine winter and mouth you get... winter mouth! Or at least a mouth that tastes like winter because it's coming in for a kiss. Before you go kissing people you eat mints, right? It's common courtesy so you don't give them a mouth full of bad breath. So when you think of a winter mouth, think of a nice, minty kiss!
If you kick a cliff you'll start a landslide! Oh no!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means music.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means sell.

This is the canopy radical with ice running down the back. If you hang out in a cold canopy like this you'll definitely get sick. Imagine being sick and alone inside a cold canopy. Brrrr, oh no... ACHOO!
See the stairs shape on the right side? Also note it's being held up by a pillar or beam or something, to make sure the stairs don't just collapse as you walk up them.
There is a stool sticking out of the dirt. You walk up and realize it has writing on it. It's actually a tombstone. You can sit on it and remember the people who are below the dirt now.

This looks kind of like the top of the bird radical, but not quite. It's kind of a dumb-looking bird radical top. What's a dumb bird, so dumb that it would look into the sky to drown itself with its mouth open? A turkey.

You give your scooter to a turkey so that it can advance. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance. Imagine picking up the turkey and putting it on your scooter. Of course, you give it your helmet as well, safety first.
mnemonics.reading: You wave as the turkey advances into the street at top speeds, collides with a car, and scrapes up its shins (しん) almost immediately. Ah! Silly turkey, you can't advance that fast, of course you'll hurt your shins. It's better to advance slowly, but I guess I couldn't expect you to know that.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami is an alcoholic beverage containing a lot of alcohol. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it. It’s made with spiced rum, coconut rum, and dark rum. Imagine yourself on a sandy beach drinking this cocktail. Feel the sun on your face and the wind in your hair as you sip on this fruity and rummy alcoholic beverage known as a tsunami. You could even picture an actual tsunami in the water coming right for you. I wouldn’t recommend it though—actual tsunami are scary, not drinkable and delicious.
mnemonics.reading: As you lay on this beach, the alcohol keeps coming down a chute (しゅ), straight into your mouth. You can feel the sand in your toes and the alcohol sliding down your throat from this special tsunami chute. Picture the alcohol flowing down this long chute from somewhere far away. You try to see where it's coming from, but all you can see is this long, long chute stretching along the entire beach, until it disappears into the distance. You should probably be concerned that you're nonstop drinking alcohol from a random chute, but it tastes so good!

mnemonics.meaning: If you give a woman a machine she'll begin learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to start before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines! Picture a woman seeing a new machine and beginning work on it right away to see how she can start it up.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, before she can begin, she has to shear the sheep (し) over there. The machine is going to turn wool into yarn, but you can't just start that process by shoving the sheep in there. You have to keep the little sheep safe! Picture a machine starting up as the woman begins to shear the sheep. Picture the sheep staring at you, staring at it.

mnemonics.meaning: If a sheep is having trouble trying to eat a fish with spikes on its fins, then the sheep probably has no business trying to eat it in the first place. Don’t sheep usually eat like, grass and stuff? What is this sheep doing trying to eat a fish with spikes on its fins? What silly business this is. Imagine this crazy sheep. Why is it trying to eat this fish? This sheep is blood crazed. Blood crazed for fish meat, especially the meat from fish with spikes on their fins. This crazed sheep means business.
mnemonics.reading: What’s this? The sheep is also trying to eat some gyoza (ぎょう) dumplings! Where will this sheep’s madness end? First spikey finned fish and now gyoza? This is some crazy business. Imagine you’re at an Asian style restaurant and you just ordered a big plate of gyoza dumplings. Next thing you know, this crazy sheep busts through the front door and starts devouring all your gyoza! Where did this sheep come from and why does he love gyoza so much!?

mnemonics.meaning: If you get stabbed in the eye twenty times with bamboo, you’re going to have a hard time beginning to calculate where anything is. Taking a bamboo shoot to the eye is no pleasant experience, especially if done twenty times. You’d be blinded for sure. And a newly blinded person is going to have one heck of a time calculating where everything is without the power of sight. Imagine getting jabbed with a bamboo shoot. Now imagine getting jabbed in the eye with a bamboo shoot. It’s going to hurt. Try and calculate exactly how painful this would be and imagine it happening to you.
mnemonics.reading: Do you know how Santa-san (さん) punishes naughty boys and girls in Asia? He doesn’t give them coal, Santa-san tortures them with twenty bamboo jabs to the eye. Yikes. Do you know how Santa-san calculates who is naughty and who is nice? By their school grades, of course. Picture this evil Asian Santa-san, clad in blood red garments and brandishing pointed bamboo shoots in each hand. He’s a cold and calculating madman! You’d better start studying! Santa-san is watching!

mnemonics.meaning: While riding your scooter, you bang your forehead on the car in front. Your scooter's wrecked, so you have to carry it home. You'll need a lot of luck to get that scooter home safely. Imagine trying to carry your scooter down a busy road, with all the cars whizzing past. Your forehead is still hurting from that nasty bang. Good luck!
mnemonics.reading: As you carry the scooter, your luck turns, and it starts to rain, so you pull out your umbrella (うん). Now you're holding your scooter, your forehead, and an umbrella. It's hard enough to carry a scooter in heavy traffic, but now you have to try to keep yourself and it dry with an umbrella too.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami hit ancient China and formed the Chinese country we know now as... China! Picture the world way far away, from space. You see a giant tsunami carve out a massive chunk of land to the west of Japan on the main continent. Slowly the tsunami waters recede, leaving the outline of China.
mnemonics.reading: You peer closer at China and realize the borders are inching inward, even though the tsunami is already gone. You look even closer and see the Mongols, being led by Genghis Khan (かん) moving in to conquer all of the Chinese people living in China! Watch as the Khan takes China for himself. A tiny little flag with a horse on it is raised in the middle, for all of the Chinese people to see. Hmm, this could be a problem.

mnemonics.meaning: When a bird opens its mouth, you’re most likely to hear a chirp. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp! Imagine yourself out in the wilderness on a sunny spring day. The weather is perfect and the scenery is beautiful. The only sound you can hear is the chirp of birds throughout the woods around you. It’s very peaceful.
mnemonics.reading: The best way to experience the chirp chirping of birds is to offer them nachos(な). Birds love nachos so much, it's a guaranteed way to make them chirp with delight. Picture yourself surrounded by birds of all kinds, handing out nachos. Just listen to their happy chirping. They're sitting on your arms, shoulders, and even your head, trying to get closer to the nachos. That chirping is so loud!

mnemonics.meaning: You chase a turkey up a tree to collect it. At least, you will once you've gathered enough turkeys into this one tree. Collect another turkey, send it flying and gobbling up into the tree next to the other one.
mnemonics.reading: Once you've collected enough turkeys, you're going to turn them into a shoe (しゅう). Maybe even two shoes, but that will mean gathering even more turkeys! Picture the nice, feathered shoes you'll be able to make once you've gathered all of these turkeys together. Ohoho, you can't wait! Go collect another turkey!

mnemonics.meaning: You don't want to keep all the alcohol to yourself (oneself), so you distribute it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find! Don't be that person who keeps the alcohol all to themselves. Distribute it to all of the legally-aged people you know!
mnemonics.reading: As you distribute the alcohol you say a haiku (はい): Here you go my friends Alcohol for everyone Never drink alone This becomes the haiku you say before every party, every potluck, and every night out at the bar. You even get it tattoo'd to your arm.

mnemonics.meaning: You can eat all you want, but you'll still lack something to drink. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too! Imagine eating and eating and lacking a delicious, cold, thirst-quenching drink. Your mouth is dry. You have to drink something, anything!
mnemonics.reading: You get desperate for a drink and put some nori (の) seaweed in a blender, trying to create a drink of your own. Luckily, this nori isn't dried and pressed like they usually are, and you manage to make a bright green nori drink. You gulp it down, and even though it tastes like the ocean, it hits the spot!

mnemonics.meaning: The thread of winter splits in two when the year comes to an end. One half symbolizes the year you were just in, and the other symbolizes the new year beginning, cutting winter in half and finishing off the year. Picture the threads that symbolize winter splitting in two to mark the end of the year. Winter isn't finished though, it's only half done.
mnemonics.reading: Right as winter ends you grab the two threads and lace them into your shoes (しゅう). Oh, you thought these were metaphorical? No they're real threads, although, they're technically shoe laces now. It's the end of the year, so it's time for new shoe laces!

mnemonics.meaning: Here you stand, a hair’s breadth away from the edge of a cliff, when out of nowhere a geoduck slaps you right in the face. Geoducks are gross, and you back away from the edge of the cliff you were standing but a hair’s breadth away from just before. Your face is all gooey from the geoduck’s slimy residue. Imagine being slapped in the face with a geoduck. It’s probably one of the worst things that could ever happen to someone. Those things are disgusting. Now you have geoduck goo all over your face. It’s sticky and slimy and gross.
mnemonics.reading: But where did that geoduck come from anyway? As you turn around from the cliff edge, wiping the goop from your face and out of your eyes, you see an angry cow (かお). This cow is the one who hit you in the face with this geoduck. I know not the reason, but this cow is most definitely not happy with you. Cows are big animals. So you probably got hit in the face with that geoduck pretty hard. Feel the geoduck shaped welt starting to form on the side of your face. It’s very painful and stings a lot.

mnemonics.meaning: A violent tsunami causes flowers to be ripped from the branches of trees and they swirl around and kiss your face gently as they fall. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew many flowers all about. It’s a pretty sight amongst all the destruction. Imagine being out in this tsunami induced storm. You can feel the rain and wind on your skin – you’re wet, cold, and scared. But you see some flowers being blown to the ground and you are mesmerized by the dance they do on the wind before they finally fall to the ground.
mnemonics.reading: You want to save these flowers you see falling in around you, so you take out a drying rack (らく) and place them carefully on it. Now whenever you feel scared, you can look at the flowers on this rack and you won't be scared anymore. Imagine running around catching the flowers as they fall. Imagine placing each little petal onto the rack to keep it safe and dry.

mnemonics.meaning: You blast your music loud so it causes a landslide, revealing the perfect soil for farming! Musically moved dirt is perfect for agriculture. Imagine slowly turning up your big boombox until your ears hurt and the ground beneath your feet is vibrating with the beat. Soon you and the boombox are sliding with all of the earth down the hill and onto your farmland. Hooray, now the farming can begin!
mnemonics.reading: The first person to come up with this farming method was Nostradamus (のう), the famous seer and prophecy man. He predicted humans of the future would use special "yell cubes" to "move that good earth." Picture Nostradamus flailing his arms and trying to explain his vision to the farmers at the time. He knows that if they listen their farming techniques will improve, but they're looking at him like he's nuts.

mnemonics.meaning: You jump on your scooter with a big bundle to go as fast as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there! Imagine how fast you can go on your scooter holding this bundle. It's way faster than trying to go on foot, that's for sure!
