mnemonics.reading: You were going so fast, you only put on socks (そく). So now you're barreling down the street at top speeds in just your sad, white socks. Imagine riding the scooter as fast as you can in just your socks. You can feel the wind pulling them off your feet!

mnemonics.meaning: If a geoduck eats lots of beans, its head will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, a geoduck’s head will grow incredibly large. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads. Imagine, if you will, a geoduck. Now imagine that same geoduck with a massive head. It looks ridiculous, and more disgusting than ever. It’s actually really creeping you out, because the head keeps getting larger as the geoduck eats more beans. Ew.
mnemonics.reading: As the geoduck eats more and more beans, its head gets bigger and bigger until finally the geoduck’s head explodes like an atomic (あたま) bomb. BOOM! Geoduck parts go flying everywhere and pieces of the geoduck’s massive head float to the ground as atomic fallout. Remember how gross geoducks are? Of course you do. Now imagine one exploding right in front of you. You’ve got geoduck mess all over yourself. It’s gross, slimy, sticky, and covering you from head to toe. It’s wretched.

mnemonics.meaning: If you press your ear up to a gate, you’re likely to hear what’s going on on the other side. The other people on the other side won’t know you are listening to their conversation because you are so sneaky and clever. They’ve no idea you’re on the other side of the gate hearing every word they say. I’m sure you’ve pressed your ear up against a wall, door, or gate at sometime to hear what’s going on on the other side of it. Remember back to a time you did this and how sneaky you felt listening in on people without them knowing. You sneaky frood, you.
mnemonics.reading: From the other side of the gate, you hear one of the people on the other side start to play a song on a recorder. You recognize the song as “Hot Cross Buns (ぶん).” You haven’t heard this song in a long time. “Hot cross buns… hot cross buns~” I’m sure many of you were forced to play the recorder in school at some point and were made to play the song known as hot cross buns. Picture yourself playing this song and remember the melody when you see this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: This building has a roof and will teach you about the origin of many things. It's an institution! Institutions are places of learning, but they have to be a physical place with a roof and all that. If you're learning out in a field somewhere, that's probably not a proper institution.
mnemonics.reading: What does institution start with? In (いん)! Just remember, it's an IN-stitution, and you'll know this reading easy-peasy.

mnemonics.meaning: You say something about the circumference of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to investigate something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet tone of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them. Because the radical circumference is in play, you can think of the crime scene you're investigating as a statue of a giant globe, and you're doing a circumference around it. Then, in the reading, we'll think about what you'll say.
mnemonics.reading: "I came here to investigate this place, and I did indeed find out who the criminal is... it's none other than Mrs. Chou (ちょう)!" From what you know about evil Mrs. Chou, you probably could have guessed it was her. The "Circumference Investigation" is now over, though you do still have to catch the perp, Mrs. Chou.

mnemonics.meaning: You look at some gold and notice a fault in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless iron! You think you've found a ton of gold bars! Imagine being so happy about this. Then, imagine your heart dropping in your chest when you notice the fault. Then, it dropping down even farther when you figure out it's merely iron.
mnemonics.reading: Do you know that movie, Tetsuo (てつ) the Iron Man? We talked about it on Tofugu a while back. It’s one of the wackiest Japanese movies of all time. If you don’t know about Tetsuo the Iron Man, you should definitely look it up (if you aren't averse to horror/violent films). Tetsuo is one of the most insane movies in the history of ever. Watch a trailer on YouTube for Tetsuo the Iron Man. Go ahead, do it now – I’ll wait. Did you watch it? Remember that nonsense every time you see this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: What you say between five mouths is a language. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language. Picture these five mouths saying the same language to each other. They can understand each other! The mouths are smiling and laughing too.
mnemonics.reading: Another mouth joins in speaking the language, but it's green and scaled and... it's Godzilla's (ご) mouth! Godzilla speaks this language too. Godzilla speaks a language some people understand! You wish you knew this earlier, then you might have been able to stop some of his destruction. Try to say, "Hey Godzilla, please stop destroying my city," in his language. It's a lot of growling and yelling. He doesn't seem to understand you. You better practice your pronunciation.

mnemonics.meaning: In the world of flowers and trees, the most important thing is the leaf. Leaves are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun!  Leaves, no matter how little, are the most important thing in the world for them.
mnemonics.reading: Picture a little flower working really hard to grow its first leaf. The leaf pops out and it shouts, "Ha (は)!" は is the sound of a leaf coming into existence. Whenever you see a plant from now on, hear the little ha sound it makes when each leaf pops out of its body.

mnemonics.meaning: You find some white feathers and you want to learn more about where they came from and what they're made of. Picture yourself in a library poring through huge tomes on birds, feathers, and the history of white birds. You want to learn everything you can!
mnemonics.reading: You learn that you should tie these white feathers to your shoes (しゅう). You do it before you learn what it will do, and then suddenly you're jump-flying out of the building. Oh geez, oh no. You better learn how to control these shoes before you—CRASH!!! Welp, you just shot through a plane. You need to learn more before you act next time.

mnemonics.meaning: For a car, a tombstone is lightweight. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be light and easy to transport. Picture yourself trying to move a huge slab tombstone. It’s difficult, no? I bet you wish you had a car or some other vehicle to make the process much less painful. Your arms are getting sore from carrying the tombstone and you’re getting sweaty and hot from all the work. What you would do for a car with air conditioning.
mnemonics.reading: What do you wish you had to transport this tombstone? Oh, that’s right, a car. So you need some kind of car loophole (かる). If you had a car, this tombstone moving business would be no problem. To cars, tombstones are naught but lightweight pebbles! But the rules say you can't use cars to carry tombstones, so you need to find a car loophole. Remember all that hard work you were doing before and how you got all sweaty and gross? Now imagine yourself inside of a nice car with air conditioning, and the tombstone in the trunk. It feels great doesn’t it? The air conditioning is perfect, and driving a car is much easier than carrying a tombstone around. Thank goodness you found a car loophole in the tombstone carrying rules.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone falls overboard while you're white water rafting, you can use a long piece of thread as a life line. Sure it might be thin, but a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard! Those white water rapids are vicious. Imagine you're the person who fell overboard. The white water is rushing violently and it is deathly cold. Feel the water and freezing temperature on your skin. But look! Someone has thrown you a line of thread! You're saved!
mnemonics.reading: The person who threw you that line of thread is actually a centaur (せん). How kind of him. After you are safe you hop on the centaur's back and ride around to get the wind to dry you off. Coming out of the rushing water, this centaur is like an angel sent from heaven. He's just saved your life. Imagine the happiness and gratitude you feel towards this centaur as you are pulled to safety by that line of thread.

mnemonics.meaning: Let the sun shine into your ear while sitting on a stool and make sure most of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone has ever. Most of the sun is getting into your ear, but not all of it. Darn, maybe you should try angling yourself a different way.
mnemonics.reading: Most of this is for your cyborg (さい). You're testing out a new way to power it, but if you can't get most of the sun into your ear, it won't be enough to power most of the cyborg's robo-parts. Install the part into your cyborg. As long as most of the sun gets into its human ear, most of its cyborg bits will have power.

mnemonics.meaning: A gate with a lantern is open for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help. Imagine being a traveler, walking around the outside of a huge walled city. You really need to get inside but all of the gates are closed. Finally, you see a single, bright lantern marking the open gate! What a relief.
mnemonics.reading: This open gate is in the water though, so you'll need a kayak (かい) to get in. Luckily, you've been carrying your kayak with you just in case. Imagine kayaking in the dark toward an open gate. Finally, you've made it!

mnemonics.meaning: Did you know that those strange geoduck creatures were once used to make pages? Okay maybe not, but it makes for a memorable image! Imagine the strange, gooey books you'd end up with if you used geoducks for pages. Now imagine flicking through one of those books, and getting the slimy geoduck residue on your hands as you look at the pages.
mnemonics.reading: A page is a page (ページ). Since the reading comes from the English word "page", this one shouldn't be too hard to remember, especially if you've already come across it in katakana.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see a tree that you want to stand under to take a break while hiking, a good parent will stand under the tree with you. This is a kind and caring parent who can see that you are tired and want to relax by standing in the shade of this tree. Imagine that you’re on a long mountain hike and so far you’ve been hiking all in the sun with no shade. Feel the sun beating down on your back, the sweat getting in your eyes. Finally you see a tree to seek refuge under. It’s like an oasis in a desert. You’re saved!
mnemonics.reading: Once you get closer to the tree, you and your parent see that it has some pretty crazy roots coming out of it. While making your way into the shade, you manage to bang your shin (しん) on one of these roots. Your shins already hurt from walking so much, and this is just icing on the cake. Busting your shins on things really hurts. I'm sure you've hit your shins on coffee tables and the like all your life. Remember that pain and think how much worse it would be banging your bare shins on pointy tree roots after you've been hiking all day in the hot sun. Not enjoyable.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to say what you’re selling because people don’t like to read. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them. Imagine reading what you have for sale out loud to people walking by because they’re too lazy to read it for themselves.
mnemonics.reading: What are you forced to read aloud to sell? Yo-yo (よ) instructions! You’d think they’d be self explanatory, but there are actually a lot of rules and tricks that you have to read to get good at yo-yoing. Read all of these out loud so you can sell them. Imagine reading through your list of yo-yo tricks. Do you know how to pronounce those weird yo-yo names?

mnemonics.meaning: On the ground is a water drop you spilled, so I request you wipe it up. I would do it myself, but you're the one who spilled it, so I'm requesting you do it and take responsibility for your mistake. It's a simple request, really. Just wipe up that water drop off the ground.
mnemonics.reading: Oh, one more thing. I request that you wipe up the water with this cucumber (きゅう). "But cucumbers are already mostly water, this isn't going to absorb anything!" you cry. Well too bad. That's my request, so you better do it. Figure out how to make the cucumber work.

mnemonics.meaning: If your car runs into a cloud you'll revolve around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway. Imagine driving your car around and around the cloud, instead of going through it. At least it's soft and cool.
mnemonics.reading: You have to revolve around the cloud ten (てん) times before it disappears and you're able to go through. Unfortunately, not long after you get through that cloud another one comes down and gets in your way. Now you're counting each revolution, one... two... three... all the way up to ten.

mnemonics.meaning: If you’ve been walking all day, nobody is going to want to kiss your foot if you’ve been walking barefoot down a dirt road. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet. Imagine kissing someone’s foot. Now imagine kissing someone’s foot after they’ve been walking down a dirt road for hours. It’s disgusting. Smell the stench of dirt and sweat wafting up into your nostrils as the foot approaches your lips. It’s wretched.
mnemonics.reading: What was this person walking down again? Oh, that’s right – a road (ろ). They were walking down a dirt road. Walking down a dirt road barefoot like this is a sure way to dirty up your feet. Feel the dirt, rocks, and twigs under your feet. The road is hard and dry and is not making your journey very comfortable at all.

mnemonics.meaning: A sick stick of dynamite is going to be sick forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good. Imagine if you were a sick stick of dynamite. Every time you sneezed you ran the risk of blowing up. It would be a terrifying way to live. Just imagine it.
mnemonics.reading: Being nervous all the time about spontaneously exploding would probably make you sweat profusely. And you know what sweating causes? B.O. (びょう). You’d be one smelly stick of dynamite. B.O. is a very unpleasant smell, and being sick is no excuse. Picture this as your life. You could explode at any moment, you’re sick, and you have B.O. Nobody wants to be around you because you might explode and kill them, and you stink. What a terrible way to live!

mnemonics.meaning: The tree marked with a yellow X on the side of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm. Picture the scene of a woman with a chainsaw cutting down this tree marked with a yellow X. Hear the sound of the chainsaw buzzing and the grinding of wood as it meets the side of the trunk. It’s very loud. Woodchips go flying everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: Wait, that woman with the chainsaw is Yoko (よこ) Ono! Yes, the same Yoko Ono who’s married to John Lennon of the Beatles. What’s she doing chopping down trees on the side of your house? Who can say. Silly Yoko. Now picture the same scene as before only imagining Yoko Ono wielding that chainsaw. Maybe she’s dancing. Maybe there’s some Beatles music playing in the background. Either way it’s a strange sight – remember it.

mnemonics.meaning: If you lack a lip ring (or two in this case) it's going to make it way easier for you to sing a song. Imagine a song with lip rings. Then imagine one without. Sing them, pretending you have lip rings. It doesn't work as well.
mnemonics.reading: You're singing a song with all these lip rings in your mouth and you sound terrible. You're on the side of the road singing. People are freaking out. Finally, someone drives into you with their car (か). Imagine yourself getting hit by this car. All the air flies out of you as you sing your song. You think "I shouldn't have tried to sing a song with all these lip rings..."

mnemonics.meaning: Run into oneself in a dream and you'll definitely wake up. If you run into yourself, it really messes you up, you know? You won't be able to handle what you're seeing so you have to wake up.
mnemonics.reading: If one runs into oneself and you don't wake up, just look down at your waist. If you're wearing an obi (お) you know it's a dream and you'll eventually wake up. If you aren't wearing an obi then it isn't a dream and you don't have anything to wake up from. Your obi is like a special object you only have in dreams. If you have your obi, it's okay, it's a dream and you can wake up now! Make sure you memorize exactly how it feels so dream-you can't trick you or something.

mnemonics.meaning: A study institution is an academy. That's where all the fancy people study, anyways.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 2014年に、トーフグ学院をそつぎょうしました。
I graduated from Tofugu Academy in 2014.
かん西学院大学の多くの学生はざい学中にりゅう学をけいけんします。
Many students from Kwansei Gakuin University get to study abroad while at college.
やあ！こいつはワニカニ。あだ名はクラビゲーターだよ。トーフグ工業学院で働いてるんだ。
Hey! This guy is WaniKani, a.k.a. the Crabigator. He works for Tofugu Institute for Industrial Education.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 足す means "to add?" Add calculate to that and you'll have addition! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you add.
mnemonics.reading: This is the kun'yomi reading for 足 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

sentences: わたしは足し算ができない。
I can’t do addition.
その足し算コンテストに、かん客としてさんかすることはできますか？
Can I participate in the addition contest as a spectator?
今日、学校で足し算の勉強をしました。
Today we studied addition in school.

mnemonics.meaning: When something advances and goes, it is moving forward. If you do this you will advance. You will progress.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: げんざい、六つのプロジェクトが進行中です。
Six projects are currently progressing.
おいしゃさんに、進行がんがあると言われました。
The doctor told me that I have advanced cancer.
フグエキスから作られた新しい薬がその病気の進行を抑えた。
The new drug made from Fugu extract has suppressed the progression of the disease.

mnemonics.meaning: What's another way to call the farming business? If you encapsulated it into one word (assuming we're talking about plant farming, here), you could call it agriculture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしたちは、さく年、む人とうで農業を始めました。
We started farming the deserted island last year.
最近日本では、農業にきょうみのあるわか者がふえています。
In Japan, there have been more young people who are interested in agriculture recently.
僕は今はセックスにあまり興味が無いんだよ。しばらくはただ農業に集中したいんだよね。
I’m not interested in sex right now. I just really want to focus on agriculture.

mnemonics.meaning: If you think about it, an earth road isn't going to be the main road. It will be the road less traveled. You could call it a path (you know, like a dirt path!) or a dirt road. Alternatively, another less traveled street that would probably be made out of dirt back in the day (before everything was paved) would be an alley. Imagine yourself walking down a dirt alley at night with no shoes. Scary!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too! And remember, that it's the じ reading that you learned with 生地 here.

sentences: うちのお店は、ウェスタン通りから、少し路地に入ったところにあります。
Our store is in an alley just off Western Street.
その路地は、夜は少しきけんだから気を付けてね。
That path is a bit sketchy at night, so be careful.
警察官は、路地まで苺泥棒を追いかけた。
The policeman chased the mugger who stole the strawberries down the alley.

mnemonics.meaning: How many times do I have to tell you that an answer is an answer? Well, okay, it can be a reply or a response, too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 答 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Give me your answer and I'll take you to とうきょう. How does that sound? All I need is your reply, and we'll be in とうきょう before you know it.

sentences: こちらに回答を入力してください。
Please enter your answer here.
ご回答お待ちしています。
I look forward to your reply.
アンケートへの回答、ありがとうございました。
Thank you for your response to the survey.

mnemonics.meaning: What is it called when you calculate numbers? That is the study of math and arithmetic.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 明日の算数のじゅぎょう、定ぎと分度きわすれずにね！
Don’t forget a ruler and a protractor for math class tomorrow.
立ち入ったことをお聞きしますが、よみ・かき・算数、どれが一番とくいですか？
I need to ask you a personal question. Between reading, writing and arithmetic, which one are you the best at?
「連絡するのに時間がかかっちゃってごめんなさい。最近、仕事で忙しかったものだから。」「君の仕事って何だっけ？」「小学校の算数の先生よ。」
"I’m sorry it took me so long to get back to you. I’ve been tied up with work." "What was your job again?" "I’m a math teacher at an elementary school."

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who gives you a helping hand is an assistant.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi reading of 手 with the vocabulary word 投手.

sentences: ワトソンはかせは、シャーロック・ホームズの助手ではなく、あくまで友人です。
Dr. Watson isn’t just Sherlock Holmes’ assistant, he’s his friend till the end.
わたしの助手は、年末に肉ばなれになりました。
My aide got a torn muscle at the end of the year.
もし私が今首になった助手の助手だとしたら、それってつまり私も首になっちゃったってこと？
If I’m the assistant to an assistant who was just fired, does that mean that I’m fired too?

mnemonics.meaning: Doing something both fast and early probably requires you to do it at once or immediately. Whatever it is, be sure to do it without delay.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is strange. The reading for 速 (そく) is what you'd expect (on'yomi), but 早 gets a reading you haven't seen before, meaning you should treat this as an exception. Just think about how you're learning this word at once and without delay so there's no time for any sass (さっ), just kanji learning.

sentences: 早速使わせていただきました。
I used it immediately.
早速のごへんしん、ありがとうございます。
Thank you for your immediate response.
私はその茄子を早速彼に送ります。
I will send the eggplants to him at once.

mnemonics.meaning: When you distribute your heart around you, it's like your heart is everywhere at once, but not in your body. You feel frantic, you don't know what to do because your heart is out there. This represents the feeling you have when you have a worry or concern. 心配しないでね！
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the ぱい in 配 got rendaku'd from はい, as well.

sentences: かれが元気がないのはめずらしいので心配です。
I’m worried because it’s unusual for him to be so down.
この船の進行方向が西なのか東なのか心配になった。
I got worried about whether the ship was heading east or west.
心配しないで。すべて上手くいくよ。私の言うことを信じて。
Don’t worry, everything is going to be fine. You can believe what I say.

mnemonics.meaning: A self revolving car. You'd think this would be a regular car, but bicycles were probably introduced before cars were, meaning the self revolving car is the bicycle, not the car. Just imagine yourself on a bike, and you don't even have to move the pedals. They revolve themselves, but now you're going too fast and it's scary.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしは自転車で会社に行っています。
I go to work by bike.
自転車を買ってあげるよ。お返しは要らないからね！
I'll buy you a new bicycle, no strings attached.
「ごめん。てっきり君が僕の自転車を壊したのかと思ってたよ。」 「何それ！ひどい。私がそんなことするはずないでしょ。」
"I’m sorry. I thought for sure you were the one who broke my bike." "What? That’s awful. You know me better than that."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji for 苦 means suffering. This word, however, is a bit different, but you'll see how it's related. It means bitter tasting. Think of putting the most bitter thing in the world in your mouth. You feel sick, your mouth gets all weird, and you try to spit it out but the bitterness remains. Obviously eating bitter tasting things will cause you to suffer.
mnemonics.reading: This reading of the kanji is unique to this meaning of the word, so here's a mnemonic to help you out! The taste is so bitter tasting that you fall to your knees really, really hard. Luckily, you were wearing your knee guards (にが). Feel the relief that you were wearing them. Ack, no relief now. It's still bitter in your mouth.

sentences: このベーコン、なんか苦い。
This bacon is a little bitter.
このくすりはすっごく苦いから、気をつけてね。
This medicine is very bitter, so brace yourself!
カラメルは、焦がさないように気を付けてください。でないと、苦い味になってしまいます。
Be careful not to let the caramel burn or it will taste bitter.

mnemonics.meaning: There is only one place in Japan that has a thousand leaves and that's Chiba. Picture all of those leaves swirling around you on your vacation to Chiba. Beautiful.
mnemonics.reading: This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned kun'yomi for 千 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: While you're admiring all of the leaves in Chiba, you realize you're craving something. What goes well with watching leaves? Why, cheese (ち) of course. Delicious Chiba cheese.

sentences: かれは千葉県人です。
He’s from Chiba.
わたしの母は、千葉県さんの落花生が大すきです。
My mom loves peanuts made in Chiba.
ここから千葉までだと、片道1時間30分から2時間はぐらいかかりますね。
It usually takes an hour and a half to two hours for a one way trip from here to Chiba.

mnemonics.meaning: A friend who is like one of your parents is someone who will look out for you. They are like family, in fact! That's why this word means best friend or close friend. Just imagine someone who watches over you like a parent would. This is the way to describe them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ま、親友には反対されたんですけどね。
Well, I was objected to by a close friend.
コウイチとビエトは親友で、友だち以上、こい人未まんのかんけいです。
Koichi and Viet are good friends. They are more than friends, but not lovers.
「ねぇ、知ってる？サラがベスと付き合ってるのよ。」「え、知らなかった。サラのこと親友だと思ってたけど、私そのこと何も聞いてないわ。」
"Hey, you know what? Sara is going out with Beth." "What? I didn’t know that. I thought she was my best friend but she never told me about that."

mnemonics.meaning: When you collect gold you are collecting money (or doing money collection). Of course, back in the day gold was like money, which is why this word works the way it does. Hopefully you don't have to deal with too much 集金 in your daily life. We'll try to keep WaniKani nice and reasonably priced for you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: みんなから集金して、花たばと色紙を買いました。
We collected money from everyone and bought a bunch of flowers and a message board.
集金のことはもう心配するなよ。なるようになるさ。
Don't worry about collecting money anymore. What will be, will be.
やらなければならない仕事が山のようにあるよ。とりあえず、お客さんから集金することから始めようかな。
I’ve got tons of work I have to catch up on. Anyway, maybe I should start collecting money from my clients.

mnemonics.meaning: When you collect to the middle of yourself, you are collecting towards your brain. All energy is going towards there, massing up in the middle, giving you extreme concentration abilities. Now you're really, really good at focusing. Just imagine a light in the middle of your brain, so concentrated that you're able to concentrate, shooting a little laser out of your forehead onto the thing you're concentrating on.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 会ぎに集中しすぎて終電をのがしてしまいました。
We were too concentrated on the meeting and we missed the last train.
集中集中！気合いを入れろ！
Concentrate! Focus! Give it your all!
もう！まとわりつくのは止めてよ！集中できないでしょ。
Hey! Stop breathing down my neck. I can’t concentrate.

mnemonics.meaning: Imagine yourself investigating a child. You heard this child was having a rough time, so you need to come check on the condition of his home and life. You find the condition to be terrible, and you tell the parents you have to take the child away because of these conditions (imagine them being ridiculously bad... perhaps they raise raccoons in their kitchen?).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この調子でがんばるぞ！
I’ll keep doing my best!
最近、トーフグの調子はどう？
How's Tofugu doing lately?
あの男はみんなに調子のいいことばかり言うから嫌いよ。
I hate that guy because he only says things that flatter the listener.

mnemonics.meaning: A bend in a line is merely a curve.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このドレスは、曲線を美しく出してくれます。
This dress gives me beautiful curves.
ブーメランパンツから出てるコウイチのおしりの曲線…いいね！
The curve of Koichi's butt protruding from the speedo is very... nice!
あなたが怒った時の、ほおの柔らかく歪んだ曲線が好きよ。
I really love the soft, slanted curve of your cheek when you get mad.

mnemonics.meaning: You need this request to happen, so you don't just request it, you demand it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 労働者たちは、ちん上げを要求した。
Laborers demanded higher wages.
会社からの要求が前近代的すぎて気持ち悪いんだけど。
The company's demands were feudalistic and disgust me.
この要求はいくらなんでも無茶だ。
These requirements are absurd!

mnemonics.meaning: You are now open for departure. You get on your boat and leave this place. You are going to another place to start its development where you will create a new world.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 開発チームがみなさんのごしつもんにお答えします。
The development team will answer everyone’s questions.
トーフグの開発ひ話を教えてください。
Please tell us about the story behind Tofugu's development.
コウイチは新しい日本語学習サイトを開発するために徹夜をした。
Koichi pulled an all-nighter to develop a new Japanese learning site.

mnemonics.meaning: As you can probably imagine, when you add the kanji sick to another word, you're saying what kind of sickness it is; you are mentioning what disease it is.
mnemonics.reading: Since this is attached to other words, it's treated like jukugo and gets on'yomi treatment. This is the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: メニエール病をわずらっているので、よくめまいが起きるんです。
I suffer from Ménière’s disease, so I often get dizzy.
ぼくがワニカニレベル1から全ぜん進めないのはきっと外国語できない病にかかったからにちがいない。
The reason I haven't been able to get further than Level 1 on WaniKani must be because I have "can't-learn-foreign-language" syndrome.
彼の言ったことを大袈裟に考えないで。難病で苦しんでるなんて明らかに嘘なんだから。
Don’t make a big deal out of what he said. It’s definitely a lie that he’s suffering from an incurable disease.

mnemonics.meaning: The electricity iron sounds scary, but if you think to back in the day and to where iron was used a lot, you probably think of the railway systems... big hunky pieces of iron on the ground to make the railway. So, you can advance this by adding electricity instead of coal, creating an electric railway.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 東きゅう電鉄によりますと、東きゅう東よこ線は人身じこのえいきょうで、げんざい運転を見合わせています。
According to the Tokyu Corporation, the Tokyu Toyoko line has currently suspended operations due to an accident involving personal injury.
電鉄会社ではたらくのがゆめです。
My dream is to work for an electric railroad company.
「はい、どうぞ。あなたが好きな阪急電鉄の写真よ。」「うわぁ！やったぁ！俺の大好きな阪急電鉄じゃん！」
"Here you are, dear. Some of those Hankyu Railway pictures you like." "Oh wow, I absolutely love the Hankyu Railway!"

mnemonics.meaning: If you use a strong tone on certain words, then you are putting emphasis on whatever it is you're talking about. It's the stress you put on things that are important because your tone gets stronger on those words or syllables.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: トーフグの記事は超ドきゅうにおもしろくて役に立つことを強調しておきたい。
I'd like to emphasize that Tofugu articles are super high quality, interesting, and helpful.
大事な用語は、けい光ペンで強調するとおぼえやすいよ。
Highlighting important words with a highlighter helps you memorize them.
この仕事では身支度をきちんとしていることと礼儀正しいことが重要になることを改めて強調させて頂きます。
I’d just like to stress again that dressing neatly and being polite are very important for this job.

mnemonics.meaning: It's the end. It's the finish. This word means end. Or finish! How convenient.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大さか公えん1日目終了しました！
The first day of the Osaka performance has ended!
主人公が死んでゲームが終了してしまいました。
The main character died and the game was over.
「もし私がまたデブになったらどうする？」 「まぁ、俺達の関係が終了しないのは確実だね。」
"What if I got fat again? " "Well, our relationship wouldn’t end, that’s for sure."

mnemonics.meaning: Think of things that advance and change. Does this sound familiar? Does this sound like evolution?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日に日に進化してるのが実かんできて、うれしいです。
I’m glad I’m able to recognize how much I progress every day.
みなさんのおかげで、トーフグは大きな進化をとげることができました。
Thanks to you all, Tofugu made such tremendous progress.
おい、お前って本当に阿呆だな。ダーウィンの進化論はディズニー映画のタイトルなんかじゃねえよ。
Jeez, you’re really dumb. Darwin’s theory of evolution is not the title of a Disney movie.

mnemonics.meaning: The thing that is attached to your face isn't a big booger or anything like that. It's something that's always there. It's your expression.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are both kun'yomi, but they're the readings you've already learned when you learned the kanji.

sentences: このころのたえ子ちゃんは、まだ顔付きが子どもっぽいね。
Taeko still looked like a kid back then.
あのミニチュアハスキーは、とてもりりしい顔付きをしているね。
That miniature Husky has such a gallant facial expression.
うわぁ、すっかり大きくなったね！顔付きはお父さんそっくりそのままだ。
Boy, have you ever grown up, young man. You are the spitting image of your father.

mnemonics.meaning: Do you remember 医者 (doctor)? What happens when you add eye on there? You have yourself an eye doctor.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the vocab word 医者 (いしゃ) plus the reading 目 (め), the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: きのう目がいたくなって、目医者に行ったら、ものもらいだった。
My eye started hurting yesterday, I went to the eye doctor, and it was a sty.
週末も開いている目医者をさがしています。
I'm looking for an eye doctor who is open on weekends.
「よお、目医者さん。もう何もかもばれているんだよ。だから、目について何も知らないふりをする必要はないぜ。」
Listen, Mr. Eye Doctor. The cat's out of the bag, so there's no need to pretend you don’t know anything about eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is kun'yomi, since it's a kanji all alone with nothing attached. Luckily, that's also the reading you've already learned, so associate that with this vocab word.

sentences: きのう会ったりょ行会社の人の顔をもうわすれました。
I already forgot the face of the travel agent I met yesterday.
コウイチって、顔がこいよね？
Koichi has very defined facial features, don't you think?
「おい、お前。何か文句でもあんのか？ジロジロ見てんじゃねぇぞコラ。」「えっと、あなたの顔、かなり青く見えるんですが、大丈夫ですか？」
"Hey, buddy. Are you picking a fight with me? Why are you staring at me like that?" "Well, your face looks really pale. Are you okay?"

mnemonics.meaning: The place you do your farming is a farm!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日よう日、小麦のしゅうかくを体験しに、農場へ行ってきました。
I went to a farm on Sunday to experience the wheat harvest.
農場で、引きつづきはたらかないかと聞かれました。
I was asked if I'd like to keep working at the farm.
オーガニック農場を始めるつもりです。
I’m planning to start an organic farm.

mnemonics.meaning: Just like the meaning of the kanji (fast) this adjective also means fast.
mnemonics.reading: Remember how 早い means "early"? If you are early to something, it probably means you moved fast to get there. These two words share a reading (and have similar meanings, in a way, as well!).

sentences: 新かん線はふつうの電車より速いです。
The shinkansen is faster than a normal train.
ポートランドから東京まで、だれが一番速く泳げるかきょうそうしました。
We had a competition to see who could swim from Portland to Tokyo the fastest.
うちの家族は、ご飯を食べるのがとても速いです。
In my family, we eat dinner really fast.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen 一番 (number one), so what in the world is this eye on the end? This eye (目) signifies the order. So, add this to "number one" and you have the first thing / the first.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is just the vocab word 一番 plus the word 目. If you know both of those readings you'll be able to read this one as well.

sentences: このごうかな朝食を食べ終わって、一番目のかんそうは、やっぱりベーコンはおいしい、です。
The first thing that comes to mind after finishing this wonderful breakfast is that bacon is delicious, as we all know.
一番目のらんには、すきな人の名前をかいてください。
Please write down the name of the person you like in the first column.
「僕は毎朝一番目に、5キロのランニングをするんだぜ。」「大したことないよ！僕は10キロ走るよ。」
"The first thing I do every morning is run five kilometers." "That's no big deal! I run ten!"

mnemonics.meaning: You know the word 外来 to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for language and you have an imported word, aka a borrowed word. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a 外来語, in fact.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: げんざいの中国語では、たくさんの日本語が外来語として使われています。
Many Japanese words are used as loanwords in modern day Chinese.
リュックサックは、外来語ですか？それとも和せいえい語ですか？
Is rucksack a foreign word, or Engrish?
ねえ、煙草って外来語なのに漢字があるって知ってた？
Hey, did you know that there's kanji for the word tobacco even though it’s a loanword?

mnemonics.meaning: I bet you can guess that フランス means "France." So what happens when you add language to it? You get the "France Language" aka the French Language.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the on'yomi reading for 語 which is the reading you learned with the kanji. This is probably because it gets added onto a lot of other words so it's treated like a jukugo. For example: 日本語 = "Japanese Language." 中国語 = "Chinese Language." スペイン語 = "Spanish Language."

sentences: わたしのむすめは、フランス語もえい語も話せます。
My daughter can speak both French and English.
アフリカの多くの国では公用語にえい語とフランス語が使用されています。
In many African countries, both English and French are used as their official languages.
フランス語の学習は僕には難しすぎるよ。もうたく山だ！勘弁してくれよ！
Learning French is too difficult! I can’t take it anymore. Give me a break!

mnemonics.meaning: So there's this weird thing with Japanese people. Many things that most people would consider "green" are actually "blue" in their eyes. So, things like plants and street lights are "blue" even though you may think of them as green. Remember that for this word, where we talk about a blue leaf. In your head, though, think "green leaf." Now think of all things that have green leaves. This is greenery.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi readings. Since you've already seen the word 青, hopefully you can just combine it with 葉 (you learned the reading for this part with the kanji). Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku, though. は goes to ば in this word, making it あおば.

sentences: 青葉が目にしみるきせつとなりました。
It's that time of year again when the leaves make my eyes burn.
家のにわの青葉に虫がいっぱい付いてる！
There are a lot of bugs on the young leaves in our garden!
お前の頭、ちょっと変なにおいがするぞ。 乾燥した青葉か何かみたいな。
Your head smells a little weird. It’s like dried up leaves or something.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 大学 means "college?" Well the institution you go to after college is graduate school!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大学院をそつぎょうしたんだけど、仕事が見つからないんだ。
I graduated from grad school, but I can’t find a job.
この大学院の自どうはん売きは、つめたい飲み物しか売っていません。
You can only buy cold drinks from the vending machines at this grad school.
私は大学院進学を考えております。
I’m thinking about going to graduate school.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji earlier. No problem!

sentences: 頭をあらってあげましょう。
I’ll wash your head.
ひるねをすると、いつも頭がすっきりします。
Taking a nap usually refreshes my mind.
頭が痛いので、喋らないでください。
I have a headache so please stop talking.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're requesting people you're seeking workers. "Help wanted!" is what this word is basically saying.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 求人については、後ほどあらためてせつ明をいたします。
We will explain the job offer later.
近年は、ほぼ全てのき業が求人にインターネットを使います。
Nowadays, almost all companies use the Internet for recruiting.
トーフグのブログで拝見した求人の件でお電話しました。プログラマー職に応募したいのですが、ビエトさんはまだ生きていらっしゃいますか？今朝方刺客を送り込んでおいたのですが。
I’m calling regarding the position advertised in the Tofugu blog. I’d like to apply for the programmer position, but is Mr. Viet still alive? I sent an assassin after him this morning.

mnemonics.meaning: A sick institution is a place where sick people go. That is a hospital.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 病院までタクシーで、千円ぐらいです。
It takes about a thousand yen to get to the hospital by taxi.
この病院の院長は、九九もできない。
The head of this hospital can't even do his multiplication tables.
この病院で医者をすることには本当に嫌気が差すね。患者は馬鹿ばっかりなんだ。
I hate being a doctor in this hospital. The patients are all idiots.

mnemonics.meaning: If you end up in a situation where you have to enter an institution it's called hospitalization. Hopefully you aren't there for very long.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 病じょうがあっ化し、入院する事になりました。
His condition deteriorated and they decided he's to be hospitalized.
入院中は、たいくつであくびが止まらなかったよ。
While I was hospitalized, I was so bored that I couldn't stop yawning.
今度、乳癌で入院することになったんです。
I'm going to be hospitalized due to breast cancer soon.

mnemonics.meaning: The business of industry is... well... industry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本では工業が発たつしています。
Japan has an advanced industry.
工業デザイナーの中山さんは、ワニカニをストレス発さんに使っています。
The industrial designer, Mr. Nakayama, uses WaniKani for stress relief.
「工業技術プロジェクトの進み具合はどう？」「今のところは順調だよ。」
"How is your industrial technology project going? " "So far, so good."

mnemonics.meaning: Your parents are very close to you, most likely. They are your closest relatives. They are the ones who are intimate and friendly with your affairs. They want to know everything!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Those who are most intimate with you hang out with you even when you're doing gross things, like sitting on the sh*tter (した). Gross, your family is.

sentences: まだ親しい友人にしか話してないの。
I've only told this to close friends.
「親しき仲にも礼ぎあり」って言うでしょ？いくら親しいからってトイレはのぞかないで！
They say, "A hedge between keeps friendship green," right? We're good friends, but don't peek at me when I'm on the toilet.
ちょっと、コウイチ。落ち着いてよ。 親しい友人たちに誰か80セント貸してあげれる人がいないか聞いてみてあげるから。
Oh Koichi. Calm down. I’ll ask my close friends if anyone can lend you the 80 cents.

mnemonics.meaning: You know 日本 is "Japan." So, when you add language onto the end of that you have Japanese language.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the vocab word 日本 (にほん) plus the reading that you learned for 語. Combine them together to get the reading for this word.

sentences: いいですか。英語じゃなくて日本語ですよ。
Okay? Not English, Japanese.
今ワニカニを買うと、もれなく日本語でかかれたトーフグのサインが付いてきますよ。
If you subscribe to WaniKani right now, it will come with Tofugu's autograph in Japanese.
間違うことを恐れるなよ。日本語で喋ってみろって。やってみろよ。君ならできると思うよ。
Don’t be afraid of making mistakes. Speak in Japanese. Give it a shot. I think you can do it.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 日本 is "Japan" so when you add alcohol onto the end of that you have Japanese Style Alcohol (what's the big Japanese style alcohol that everyone knows? That's sake).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the vocab 日本's reading plus the reading you learned for 酒, put together. The alternative reading にっぽんしゅ is really rare, but you might come across its abbreviated version ぽん酒, or ポン酒.

sentences: 日本酒はあまりすきではないんです。
I don’t really like Japanese alcohol.
その日本酒のボトルから、値札を外してもらってもいいですか？
Could you remove the price tag from the Japanese sake bottle for me?
「何飲んでるの？」「日本酒だよ。一口飲んでみる？」「それじゃ、お言葉に甘えて一口もらってみようかな。」
"What are you drinking?" "Japanese rice wine. Would you like a sip?" "Well, I suppose I’ll give it a try."

mnemonics.meaning: The Chinese letters... you're finally learning the word for them, the thing you've been studying this whole time for so long! This is kanji, your new best friend (they came from China, which is why they're Chinese letters).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしは漢字をかくのが下手です。
I’m bad at writing kanji.
わたしの名前の漢字には、ウィスコンシン州でくらせますように、といういみが込められています。
The kanji for my name includes the meaning, "you may live in Wisconsin."
「これ、君への誕生日プレゼントだよ。」「わあ！漢字のテキストじゃない！どうもありがとう。あなたのおかげで本当に幸せな気分になったわ。」
"Here is a gift for your birthday." "Wow! A Kanji textbook! Thank you so much. You really made my day."

mnemonics.meaning: When your parents cut you you'd think they are being mean... but they're not. They are bleeding all the bad blood out of you. They are truly being kind.  Just think of how crazy it would be for your parents to cut you... then think about some kind of twist to make it so they are being kind instead.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: いつも親切にしていただいて、ありがとうございます。
Thank you for always being kind.
トーフグのような親切な会社と出会ったのははじめてです。
I've never seen a company as kind as Tofugu.
今まで食べた中で一番のチーズケーキだわ。 あなたってとても親切だから、きっと最後の一切れは私にくれちゃうわよね？
Oh my gosh, this is the best cheesecake I have ever had. You're so kind, so I'm sure you'll give me the last piece, right?

mnemonics.meaning: What place in your house has most of the machines in it? Your kitchen! Just think about it. Refrigerator, freezer, dishwasher, stove, microwave, WOW! That's so many. The kitchen definitely has the most machines.
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 台 and the kun'yomi reading for 所. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

sentences: 母は、台所でりょうりをしています。
My mother is cooking in the kitchen.
マイケルの家の台所にはなっとうの空きばこが三百万八千九百十七こおいてあるんだって。
I heard that in Michael's kitchen, there are 3,008,917 empty natto boxes.
台所から焦げ臭い臭いがするよ。
I smell something burning in the kitchen.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 研究 means “research?” Well the room where you do research is a laboratory!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしは子どもの時、研究室ではたらくのがゆめでした。
When I was a child, my dream was to work at a laboratory.
くどいようですが、山田さんのかつらについて話すのは、この研究室ではタブーですからね。
Excuse me for repeating myself, but talking about Mr.Yamada's wig is a big no no in this study room, okay?
蛙の解剖を始めるので、皆さんには研究室に移動して頂きたいと思います。
I’d like everyone to move into the laboratory now so that we can start dissecting the frogs.

mnemonics.meaning: When you say words in a language, you are speaking a language. Not sure what that language is, but since you're saying it it must be real.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今人気のプログラミング言語は何ですか？
What are the popular programming languages right now?
言語オタクたちが朝まで言語について語りつくすオフ会にさんかしてきました。
I joined an offline gathering where language geeks got together and talk about language all night long.
新しいコンピュータ言語の勉強を始めました。
I started to study a new computer language.

mnemonics.meaning: The most end thing is the last thing. It is mainly used to refer to the last of an ordered sequence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大すきなドラマの最終回を見のがして泣いた。
I missed the last part of my favorite drama and cried.
今乗ってきた電車が最終だったから、もうかえれないよ。
The train we just took was the last one of the day, so we can't go back anymore.
これが我が社の最終提案です。後はあなたの決断次第です。
This is our final offer. Now the ball is in your court.

mnemonics.meaning: The thing that is the most after everything else is at the very end. It is the last.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: お前に金をやるのは、これが最後だ。
This is the last time I give you money.
うちのつま、いつも最後に一言多いんですよね。
My wife always ends up with one word too many.
とにかく、最後まで聞いてよ。そうすれば分かるから。
At any rate, just listen until the end. Then you’ll understand.

mnemonics.meaning: The end point is where everything ends... but for this example, think of a map with a route on it. The last spot on the route is the "last point." It is the last stop.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 電車でばくすいしてしまって、終点でうん転手さんに起こされたことはよくありますね。
I often fall asleep on the train and have to be woken up by the driver at the last stop.
このシカゴ発のアムトラックの終点の駅は何て言う名前ですか。
What's the name of the last stop on the Amtrak leaving from Chicago?
お願いがあるの。私がたとえ何と言っても、何をしようとも、終点に着くまで私が電車から降りないようにして。分かった？
You have to do me a favor. No matter what I say, no matter what I do, please do not let me get out of the train until it gets to the last stop. Okay?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: きのうは風が強かったので、木から葉が全部落ちてしまいました。
Yesterday, the wind was so strong that all the leaves fell off of the trees.
あきになって、木の葉の色が色んな色にかわってきた。
In fall, the leaves on the trees had changed to different colors.
大根の葉でふりかけを作りました。
I made furikake with daikon leaves.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of lightweight? It's also lightweight.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned with the kanji is the reading you'll be using here. Because of that, this word is kind of a lightweight.

sentences: このはこは、あのはこよりも軽い。
This box is lighter than that one.
この毛ぬき、びっくりするぐらい軽いんだけど。
This pair of tweezers is surprisingly light.
毎日軽い朝ごはんを食べる。
Every day I eat a light breakfast.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This also works for "train lines" as well. You'll see this attached onto the ends of names describing them.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same for this vocab word. Enjoy it!

sentences: 分数をかく時にまん中に引く線の名前は、かつ線です。
The line in the middle of a fraction is called the "vinculum."
しぶ谷で山手線に乗ってください。
Please get on the Yamanote Line at Shibuya.
本当にこの線が完璧だって思ったの？しかも、全然真っ直ぐじゃないじゃない！
You really thought this line was perfect? It’s not even close to straight!

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." This is obviously very similar looking, though this one means looking forward to. Why? Because it has a み on the end, saying "who is going to have fun? It's me! That's why I'm looking forward to it!"
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just like 楽しい, so make sure you know that and you'll be able to read this one as well.

sentences: あなたに会うのが楽しみです。
I’m looking forward to seeing you.
夏休みの楽しみと言えば、海にキャンプに色々あると思いますよ。
I think there are lots of different fun activities during summer break, like going to beach and camping and stuff.
私達、みんな亀を燃やすのを楽しみにしているんだよね？
We are all looking forward to burning turtles, aren’t we?

mnemonics.meaning: The いい portion means "good." So, when what you carry is good you are lucky. Just think of it in terms of luck being a physical item you carry in your hands. Now imagine yourself carrying it. Now think to yourself "what I'm carrying is good, it's lucky!"
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the kanji in this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this.

sentences: 最近みょうに運がいいんだよな。
I’ve been really lucky lately for some reason.
こんな美人のよめさんもらって、お前って本当に運がいいな。
You are so lucky to have such a beautiful wife.
日本語の授業でAが取れたんだけど、ただ単に運がよかっただけだと思うの。
I got an A in Japanese, but I think I was just lucky.

mnemonics.meaning: You've hopefully seen 向く and 向ける by now. They mean "to face" and "to turn toward." This has a similar idea. When you add 向け to something imagine you're turning it, aiming it at someone. It's aimed at them, meaning it's made for them. Turn a book toward someone, now it's aimed at them, it's made for them. See the connection?
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the word 向く so work off of that word to be able to read this one.

sentences: これは子ども向けの作ひんではないですよね。
This work isn’t intended for children.
このカレーは、日本人向けのあじですね。
This curry was made for Japanese tastes.
コウイチが履いてるパンツは、子供向けなんじゃないのか？ツンツルテンだよ。
Aren’t the underpants Koichi is wearing for children? He’s outgrown his clothes.

mnemonics.meaning: A mountain road is a mountain road! Or a mountain trail, or a mountain path.
mnemonics.reading: Both the kanji in this word use the kun'yomi, which you learned when you learned the vocabulary. When it uses this reading, it sounds casual, and is common in conversation. It can also be read using the on'yomi, though, in which case it has a more formal feel to it. That's typical of on'yomi, which tends to add formality to a word!

sentences: 子犬と山道を歩きました。
I walked the mountain trail with my puppy.
そこから山道になる。
From there on, it becomes a mountain path.
その先で山道に入る。
Beyond that point, the road enters the mountains.

mnemonics.meaning: The place you live near is your neighborhood!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you remember the rendaku on しょ making it じょ.

sentences: 近所の人はしずかですか？
Are the neighbors quiet?
トーフグのオフィスの近所には、おしゃれなお店が多く集まっています。
Many chic shops are gathering in the neighborhood of the Tofugu office.
近所にコインランドリーがあるわよ。
There is a laundromat in the neighborhood.

mnemonics.meaning: The new hear is what it sounds like. It's new things that you're hearing about in your ear... at least that's what it was back a long time ago. Now those new things that get to your ear get to you via other mediums. In this case, a newspaper.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 父は、毎朝新聞を読みます。
My father reads the newspaper every morning.
今朝の地元の新聞の一めんでトーフグとどーも君がコラボしていたよ。
Tofugu and Domo-kun were collaborating on the front page of the local newspaper this morning.
この新聞すっげー専門用語だらけじゃん。スコットがこの新聞を何回も読まなきゃいけないのは当然だな。
This newspaper is so highbrow. No wonder Scott had to read it so many times.

mnemonics.meaning: You know 番号 means "number" so add a tag to it and you have a numbered tag.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word (番号) with a single-word kanji added. That means you have two on'yomi readings from the jukugo word and the kun'yomi reading from the single kanji (ふだ). Put them all together and you have the reading of this kanji!

sentences: 番号札をとって、お待ちください。
Please take a numbered ticket and wait your turn.
すみません、この辺りに番号札は落ちていませんでしたか？
Excuse me, wasn't there a number tag left around here?
こちらがお客様のお荷物の番号札となります。
Here is the numbered tag for your luggage.

mnemonics.meaning: This is one of those words that has kanji that basically tell you the meaning. You open a business... aka opening a business.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: うちも、開業当時はしゃっ金だらけだったんだよ。
We also had a ton of debt when we opened our business.
この目医者は、今年で開業して三十五年になります。
As of this year, this eye doctor has been in practice for 35 years.
コウイチの開業準備を手伝うために、昨日は学校をサボったんだ。
I blew off school yesterday to help Koichi prepare for the opening of his business.

mnemonics.meaning: When something is public open it is open to the public. You can go look at things that are 公開. You can also use this when you're releasing something to the public.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: どうがが公開されるのはいつですか？
When will the video be released to the public?
Etoeto発売を記ねんして、コウイチの半生をドキュメンタリーにしたえいがが公開になりました。
A documentary movie of half of Koichi's life has been opened to the public to commemorate Etoeto's release.
「この写真を公開したのは、写真より実物の花子の方がずっと可愛いんだってことをみんなに教えたかったからだよ。」「あんたって本当口からでまかせばっかりよね！」
"I only published that picture to show people that you look much better in person, Hanako." "That is such a lie!"

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the vocabulary are exactly the same, so they share meanings as well. This word is often written in katakana as ページ, especially in informal writing and online. But you'll also see the kanji version, especially to refer to the pages of printed texts and in more formal writing.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: PDFの次頁がエラーになって見れません。
I cannot see the next page of the PDF because of an error.
全頁カラーのマンガをかきました。
I drew a full-page color manga.
毎日一頁ずつ読み進めた。
I read through one page each day.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  Just imagine your parents saying oh yah (おや) over and over at you. What did you do at school today? I beat up this kid. "Oh yah?"

sentences: わたしの親は、先週病院の近くに引っこしました。
My parents moved near the hospital last week.
うちの親、かほごすぎると思うんだよね。
I think my parents are overprotective.
これって、すごく不公平だわ！ ミドリは私が欲しいものを全部手に入れて、その上私のパパとママが親じゃないなんて！
This is so unfair! Midori gets everything that I want. And, on top of that, she doesn’t have my mom and dad for parents.

mnemonics.meaning: A road road is obviously the best kind of road. It's double road, after all. So, what is this ultimate road? It is a paved road.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大雪で、高速道路が通行止めになっているそうですよ。
They're saying the highway is closed because of the heavy snow.
ミネソタ州は夏に道路工事ばかりしています。
So many roads are under construction in Minnesota during the summer.
この町は本当につまらない。基本的に道路と家しかないし。あぁ〜もう！どこか楽しいところはないのかな？
This town is really dull. There are basically only paved roads and houses. Ugh! Where can I get some action?

mnemonics.meaning: The peoples who work in the farm are the farmers... the peasants.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: え戸時代の農民でも、全てがまずしかったわけではないはずだ。
That doesn't mean all peasants in the Edo period were poor.
この村の農民たちは、クロールの泳ぎ方を知りたがっている。
Farmers in this village want to know how to swim the forward crawl.
おぉ！あの農民の腹筋すげぇな。
Wow! That farmer has some amazing abs.

mnemonics.meaning: 当て means something like to guess correctly. 字 means letter. So, this is a letter you guessed correctly. This refers to phonetic kanji, which are kanji that are used in words simply for their sounds, not for their meanings. They are there to be phonetic, and that is all. That is why this word refers to phonetic kanji.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the on'yomi reading for 字 and the kun'yomi reading for 当て. You've seen 当てる in the past, though, so you should be able to read this portion as well. Combine the two together and you have yourself a nice reading.

sentences: 「リキュール」には、「利休酒」という当て字が使われます。
"利休酒" are the phonetic kanji used for "liqueur."
近ごろは、当て字を使ったキラキラネームを持つ子どもがたくさんいます。
Lately, there've been a lot of kids with bizarre names using phonetic kanji.
時々、漢字は、亜米利加 (アメリカ)のようにそれぞれの意味を無視して、読み方だけで選ばれます。これらの漢字を当て字と言います。
Sometimes kanji are selected solely for their sounds and the meaning is ignored as in 亜米利加 (アメリカ). These are called phonetic kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 私 can mean private and how 大 is the first half of 大学? Well, combine those together and you have the shortened version of private college or private university.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私大の授業料は高いもんね。
Private college tuition sure is expensive.
とある大阪の私大で英語を教えています。
I'm teaching English at a private uni in Osaka.
こないだ言ってた私大の学園祭の件なんだけど、今回は私の事数にいれないで。ごめん。でも悪く思わないでね。時間ができたら連絡するから。
As for the school festival at the private university you told me about the other day, could you count me out this time? I’m sorry, don’t get mad at me. I’ll contact you when I have free time.

mnemonics.meaning: A private iron (remember how 鉄 often has to do with railroad tracks and the like? Same goes here) is a private railway. There are a good number of these in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 東京の私鉄はふくざつでよく分かりません。
Private railways in Tokyo are too complicated to understand.
JRで新宿駅まで行ったら私鉄に乗りかえてください。
When you arrive at Shinjuku Station by JR, please transfer to a private railway.
私は、とある日本の大手私鉄会社で働いております。
I work for one of the major private railway companies in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: A line that runs on a road is a railroad track. First you have to get into your mind that the "line" in question is a railway line. Then, what railway line runs on a road and what kind of road is it? It's a railroad track.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大雨で、線路わきの土しゃがくずれ、線路が土しゃでうまってしまっているもよう。
It seems that the earth beside the train track collapsed from the heavy rain and covered the tracks.
だれかが線路に立ち入ったため、電車が止まってしまった。
The train has stopped since somebody trespassed on the train tracks.
「あぁ、ごめん。今はあんまりそういう気分じゃないんだ。」「あなた、どうしたの？」「実は、さっきそこの線路で男が飛び込み自殺をするのを目撃したんだ。」
"Well, sorry. I’m not really in that kind of mood right now." "Honey, what’s going on? " "Well, I just saw a guy commit suicide on the railroad track over there."

mnemonics.meaning: You know that this has something to do with reading and you know that 方 means way or method. So, when you think of a "way of reading" you can think of a couple other better words, such as reading (aka the reading of a word) or pronunciation. Anytime you need to know how something sounds, this is what you'll ask for.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're the readings you've learned with the kanji. 方 is like many other words you've come across as well, such as 見方 or 作り方.

sentences: 楽ふの読み方を知らない。
I can’t read sheet music.
三だんらく目の七行目のこのたん語の読み方は、なんですか？
How do you read this word in the 7th line of the 3rd paragraph?
あなたの名前の漢字の読み方を教えてください。
Please tell me how to pronounce the kanji in your name.

mnemonics.meaning: The most nearby is something that happened close to now. It happened recently.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 女の人は、最近、どのぐらい本を読んでいますか。
How many books has she read recently?
最近のトレンドファッションにはもう付いていけません。
I can't follow the latest fashion trends anymore.
「ござる」という言葉は最近はあまり使われなくなったようだ。
The term "Gozaru" doesn’t seem to be used as much lately.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen that 研究 is research from previous vocab. So, a "place" that is a research place could be many things, though mainly a research institute or research laboratory.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know the reading of 研究 already. Also note that 所 is normal for one reading, but also gets the rendaku treatment, meaning しょ becomes じょ, for the secondary reading.

sentences: とあるアメリカの研究所が、日本語がペラペラになるくすりを開発したそうだ。
I heard that a certain American lab has made a pill that will make you fluent in Japanese.
今日は、みそしる研究所で、ぼうさいくんれんがあります。
There is an emergency drill in the Miso Soup Research Facility today.
私はバーガーキング研究所で働いています。私の仕事は、フライドポテトを食べ、その後自分の体重を測ることです。
I work for the Burger King Research Institute. My job consists of eating french fries and then having my body weighed.

mnemonics.meaning: You revolve X number of times. Really, the times isn't so important, but the revolving is. That's why this word is revolve or rotate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. P.S. Ever heard of "回転ずし?" That's the kind of sushi that's on conveyer belts, rotating around and around, bringing you delicious plates of things.

sentences: ペットのハムスターがものすごいいきおいで回し車を回転させています。
My pet hamster is vigorously rotating his hamster wheel.
あそこの回転ずし、もう行った？なんか、そこのすししょく人は皿がきらいらしく、すしが回転してあつくなってるコンベアベルトの上に直でおかれているらしいよ。
Have you been to the conveyer belt sushi restaurant over there? Apparently their sushi chefs hate plates there, so the sushi is directly on the rotating, hot conveyor belt.
月は地球の周り回転していて、地球は太陽の周りを回転している。
The moon revolves around the earth and the earth revolves around the sun.

mnemonics.meaning: This is just the noun version of the kanji 酒 - it has an お there to be nice. This word can mean both alcohol (like the parent kanji) or sake (the main kind of Japanese alcohol, at least back in the kanji days).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is kun'yomi, which isn't what you learned with the kanji. But, it should be pretty easy. You know what Japanese alcohol is called already, right? It's さけ, simple as that. So long as you've heard of sake you should be A-Okay with this reading.

sentences: わたしはパーティーでお酒を飲んだ。
I drank alcohol at the party.
今、そのお酒はシーズンではないので、申しわけありませんがご用いできません。
That sake is out of season now, so I'm afraid it's not available.
「割り勘にしよう。」「いや。今日は俺の奢りだよ。しかも、俺はお酒をたくさん飲んだけど、お前は一滴も飲まなかったじゃないか。」
"Let’s split the bill." "No, it’s on me this time. I drank a lot of alcohol, but you didn’t drink anything"

mnemonics.meaning: Taking the nearby road will get you to your destination more quickly (because it's more close by!). This is a shortcut, aka the short way.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a bit weird in this one. It uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, even though it looks just like it should be all on'yomi reading. It's like you're taking a shortcut with your kanji readings and doing the native Japanese readings (kun'yomi) instead of the more intellectual Chinese ones (on'yomi). Luckily, you've hopefully seen both of these kanji as vocab already. You have ちか for 近 (short for 近い) and you have 道 (みち), just like the word "street" you learned before. Combine these together and you have the reading for this word. Perhaps it's like this because you're combining a couple concepts together into one word, at least when it comes to "short + way."

sentences: 上手な絵をも写する事は、上たつの近道です。
Tracing a good picture is a shortcut for improvement.
ワニカニで漢字をおぼえることは、本当に日本語習とくの近道になると思いますか？
Do you really think memorizing kanji on WaniKani is actually a shortcut to Japanese acquisition?
「ありえねぇ！お前って本当脳みそ無いのな。なんで一方通行を逆走してるんだよ。」「近道になると思ったんだよ。」
"Oh my God! You are such an airhead! Why are we going down a one-way street?" "I thought it would be a shortcut!"

mnemonics.meaning: When your energy is that of sickness, you are probably sick.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 母の病気は、まだよくなりません。
My mother’s illness still hasn’t improved.
おしりからおならが止まらない病気にかかってしまい、外に出られなくなってしまいました。
I got a disease that makes me fart all the time, so I've haven't been able to go outside.
「先生、僕のママの病気、直せるの？」「やってみるけど、当てにしないでね。」
"Can you fix my mom’s illness, doctor?" "I’ll give it a try, but don’t count on it."

mnemonics.meaning: A person who is sick is a sick person. They are also a patient, at least we can hope they are, for their sake.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that this uses the にん reading for 人. This is because every sick person enjoys laying in bed playing nintendo.

sentences: うつったらいやだから、病人には近よりたくない。
If you don’t want to catch something, you shouldn’t go near sick people.
うらないしに、前世は病人だったと言われました。
The fortuneteller told me that my previous life was as a sick person.
「調子はどうだい？」「絶好調だよ。」「それは良かった。病人からその言葉を聞けるとは思ってもみなかったがな。」
"How’s it going?" "Couldn’t be better." "Good. I’m surprised to hear that from a sick person though."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Please note that this word refers to "the side of something." Not "the right side," for example. That would be 右側.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, lucky you!

sentences: きっ茶店の横に、食どうがあります。
There is a diner next to the cafe.
もし強とうがトーフグのオフィスにやって来たら、コウイチのデスクまで走ってその横にしゃがみこむんだ。そこが最も安全な場所だからね。
If a robber breaks into the Tofugu office, just run to Koichi's desk and crouch down next to it because it's the safest spot.
午後の仮眠の間に横向きに寝る。
During my afternoon nap I sleep on my side.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 手 can sometimes refer to a person? In this case, we have a song person (or perhaps a "person who handles songs"). What is a song person also known as? A singer.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are on'yomi readings. You've learned them both already (you learned 手's on'yomi reading with word 投手), so you should be able to read this like a singer sings with a bunch of cashews かしゅ in their mouth. FAST AND LOUD!

sentences: 歌手になったのは、母のえいきょうが大きいです。
My mother had a large influence in my becoming a singer.
あの歌手、かなり日やけしたね。
That singer got quite a tan, didn't she?
子どもの頃は、歌手だったのよ。なんちゃってね。今でも歌手なんですけど。
I used to be a singer when I was kid. Well, who am I kidding, I’m still a singer now.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  Think about a song... but not just any song... think about the utter (うた) song, and make it up right now and sing it out loud. What does the utter song sound like? Why do you love utterances so much that you made a song about them?

sentences: でも、日本の歌はあまり知りません。
But I don’t know Japanese songs very well.
これはたんなる歌じゃなく、ひみつのあん号でもあるんじゃないかという気がしています。
It feels like this isn't just a song, but a secret code too.
「ジェイソン！あんた、アマンダのために歌を作ったの？」「えーと、これはそういうのじゃないんだ。」「もう！とぼけないでよ。」
"Jason! You made a song for Amanda?" "Ah, this isn’t what it looks like." "Come on! Don’t give me that."

mnemonics.meaning: You can probably figure out that スペイン is "Spain" just by reading it. Add the kanji language on there and you have the Spanish language (or just Spanish), if you'd like.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the kanji portion is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Since it's attached to something, it's like a jukugo word.

sentences: 明日はスペイン語の小テストだぜ！
There’s a Spanish quiz tomorrow!
そのスペイン語のテキストは今売り切れているので、ご用いできません。
That Spanish textbook is currently sold out, so it's not available.
ニンニクはスペイン語で「ajo」っていうんだけど、「アホ」って発音されるんだよ。「アホ」は日本語で「stupid」って意味だよ。
Garlic in Spanish is "ajo," which is pronounced "aho." "Aho" means "stupid" in Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: The degree of fastness is a measurement of speed, plain and simple.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: インターネットの速度がおそすぎてイライラしています。
The internet speeds are too slow and it’s pissing me off.
もう少し速度をおとして走行してください。
Please drive a little bit slower.
ドアを開けたら、冬の突風が物凄い速度で吹きこんできた。
When I opened the door, a wintry gust rushed in with great speed and force.

mnemonics.meaning: The meaning is the same as the kanji. When you stand and drink, you're standing and drinking. Or indeed, drinking while standing.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are from the words 立つ and 飲む put together.

sentences: 夏には、テラスせきで立ち飲みもできます。
In summer you can stand and drink on the terrace.
東京の新ばしえき近辺には立ち飲み屋がたくさんあります。
There are a lot of stand-and-drink bars near Shinbashi Station in Tokyo.
昨日、あの立ち飲み屋の後、誰かとやった？
Did you get any action last night after leaving the standing bar?

mnemonics.meaning: The open of the start is the start or beginning.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このゲームは、明日はいしん開始です。
This game will be released tomorrow.
先行予やく受付を開始しました。
We've started accepting preorders.
現在、トーフグは枕業界で巻き返しを図っており、新しいモデルの枕の販売を開始した。
Tofugu is currently still working to catch up in the pillow market, so they started selling new models.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji version of 話 means talk. This word also means talk, but it means a few other things as well. This can refer to a speech or story as well. Basically anything that involves a talking session. So, before you go, I hope you stay awhile and listen to my 話.
mnemonics.reading: Who tells a great story? Hana, she (はなし) tells a great story! If you know someone named Hana or Hanna you can use that person to help you to remember this one better too.  You can also use 話す's reading to help you to remember this one, as well.

sentences: それから話を聞いて、もんだい用紙の１から４の中から、一番いいものを一つえらんでください。
And then you will listen to the story and choose the best answer between 1-4 on the answer sheet.
話がちがうよ！
I didn't sign up for this!
「それから、私、他にも言いたいことがあるのよ、ブリタニー！」「ジェレミー、いい加減黙ってくれないか！君の話はもう聞き飽きたよ。」
"Now, I’d also like to say something else, Brittany!" "Jeremy! Give it a rest! I’m tired of listening to you."

mnemonics.meaning: A man made of iron is a strong man... aka a huge badass. Have you seen "Iron Chef?" The Japanese translation is 料理の鉄人, which means "Chef Iron Man" aka "Chef Badass," at least in my book.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: うちの社長は、鉄人すぎます。
My company president is way too much of a macho man.
わたしが一番すきな番組はりょうりの鉄人です。
The TV program I like most is Iron Chef.
私はスーパーで赤ちゃんに「いないいないばぁ」をしている鉄人を見た。
I saw a tough guy playing peak-a-boo with a baby in a grocery store.

mnemonics.meaning: The main thing you talk about in your language becomes the subject of the sentence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 主語をハッキリさせてくれないかな。
Can you make the subject clear?
この主語を明かくにする新サービスは、本当に役に立つ。
This new service that clarifies the subject is very useful.
日本語は、主語ー目的語ー動詞の言語ですが、英語は主語ー動詞ー目的語の言語です。
Japanese is a subject-object-verb language whereas English is a subject-verb-object language.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 引く means "to subtract?" Add calculate to that and you'll have subtraction! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you subtract.
mnemonics.reading: This is the kun'yomi reading for 引 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

sentences: もちろん、わたしは引き算ができます！
Of course I can do subtraction!
この引き算のじゅぎょうは長すぎて、あくびが止まりません。
Subtraction class is so long that I can't stop yawning.
引き算を習うのは、小学校何年生ですか？
What year of grade school will we learn subtraction?
